0679422714|4.0|Mao: The Unknown Story is a gripping account of the life of history's greatest tyrant. Jung Chang and Jon Halliday have written a very accessible biography of Mao, who caused untold misery on his people, all in the name of trying to satisfy his own ego to have China (and therefore himself) as a superpower in world politcs. The Unknown Story explores and debunks many aspects of recent Chinese history which are tied in with the Chinese Communist Party and the establishment of the People's Republic of China, and Mao's role within the Party.  <br /> <br />For example, as Chang and Halliday relate, some of the battles of the Long March transpire to be nothing more propaganda thought up by Chairman Mao as he was carried by porters on his recliner through the mountains evading the Nationalist army. He lead his army all over vast tracts of inner China in a bid to keep it out of conflict while other Chinese Communist leaders (and thus potential rivals) engaged the Nationalists and suffered losses. Mao was not above lying and decieving others, on more than one occasion ignoring radioed instructions from his superiors when those instructions did not suit him, even though his men would suffer horribly as a consequence. Mao also downplayed the extent to which the Russians supported the CCP.  <br /> <br />Mao was a superb manipulator, and one of the secrets to his success in gaining and maintaining the leadership of China was the playing off of opposing parties. Although being nominally on the same side as the Nationalist during the war, he actually welcomed a Japanese invasion of China in the late 1930's as a way of reducing the Nationalist grip on power, at a time when they were substanially stronger than the Reds. Another example of his machinations was getting President Nixon to visit China in a bid to gain access to military technology, a position the US were to take seriously due to Mao expressing fear of a Russian invasion, even though he knew this threat to be nearly non-existent, all the while maintaining the Chinese anti-American stance. Mao had also successfully used this ploy in the past against the Russians to gain nuclear weapons capability, using Taiwan and the US as the potential agressor.  <br /> <br />The callousness and blatant disregard of Mao for his people is staggering in the extreme, especially when one considers that he was asking his people to sacrifice what he himself was not prepared to. Mao lived a life of luxury, with numerous houses and villas around China especially prepared and maintained around the clock for the offhand chance that he may stay a night or two. At the same time, untold millions were starving to death due to Mao exporting much of China's agricultural products overseas to try and garner influence with the recipient countries. Needless to say, although the recipients of China's wheat and grain (including East Germany) were quite happy to accept the grain, they took no brook with Mao's attempts to influence their policy decisions.  <br /> <br />I'm no scholar, but to me the authors have certainly done their research, using extensive sources, which naturally include substanial use of Chinese sources. Russian sources are also used, which allows the authors to show the inner machinations of the Sino-Russia relationship, particularly in the early days of the CCP, when the Soviets were bankrolling the Red cause in China, and when Mao was forced to aceed to Stalin's will. I normally stay away from biographies of political leaders as I usually find them heavygoing, but unusually for a political biography, I found \\"Mao: The Unknown Story\\" easy to follow. This is helped by the fact the authors refrain from adding too many supporting characters, so it is relatively easy to avoid getting ovewhelmed by numerous characters popping in and out of the narrative.  <br /> <br />For me, and so it would seem for many other reviewers, this book is too biased against Mao to be taken seriously by many historians and academics. There is precious few positives (if any) that are offered by Mao, but that could be simply because there aren't any - Mao was really that unpleasant a man. However, rather than accept this, many will consider Mao: The Unknown Story to be nothing more than an attempt at character assassination even though it is nothing more than the subject deserves. However this does still detract somewhat from the book's credibility which is a shame, as I don't think the authors are expressing anything other than the truth.  <br /> <br />Despite the reservations expressed in the previous paragraph, this should not alter the fact that \\"Mao: The Unknown Story\\" is a well written, engaging biography of one of 20th century history's most pivotal characters. This is strongly recommended for anyone interested in Chinese history, particularly those readers who normally shy away from heavy reading. <br />

B0007XAWB2|3.0|I realize there is a serious cult following of this book/series that will never be convinced of any flaws.  And that being said, I bought this book really wanting to like it, but I just couldn't bring myself around.  Here's why: <br /> <br />1. As everyone else has said, the jargon is just plain tedious.  I can't excuse a book written in 200-year old sailing terms without a glossary.  At least 20% of the action is incomprehensible because of this.  Yes, you can press on like other reviewers have suggested, but that's frustrating at a minimum. <br /> <br />2. Sublety &lt;> Confusion -- I don't need my plots and narratives handed to me on a silver platter, and I certainly enjoy figuring puzzles out, but O'Brian seems to be trying to actively confuse the reader with his writing.  There are shifts in time/action/perspective that have nothing other than regular paragraph breaks between them.  Unfinished battles are left abruptly, and historical context is neglected. <br /> <br />3. This is not a stand-alone book.  It was written with the sole purpose of setting up the next 19, and as a result, has a an unsatisfying and rather predictable resolution. <br /> <br />So why 3 stars? <br /> <br />There is so much potential for greatness here.  The Jack/Stephen relationship is well developed and the sea battles were fascinating affairs.  And who doesn't like a good story about a maverick getting promoted through the ranks in spite of thumbing his nose at his superiors?  It makes me want to read more...well, I might try the first chapter of Post Captain.

0977326403|5.0|As a non-profit leader, I've been waiting for this monograph to be published for several months, and Collins did not disappoint.<br /><br />In a lucid style that only Collins can deliver, he masterfully explains the subtle (but seismic) concepts of good to great for the social sector. Similar to his previous books, he effectively uses a broad array of real-life examples (e.g. the NYPD, a church, the Girl Scouts, the Cleveland Orchestra, a high school science dept), helpful graphics, and a very readable, conversational tone. Even though the monograph is only 31 pages, Collins contributes his clear thinking on numerous issues that will be very familiar to social sector leaders: how to measure success in non-$ metrics, how to recruit and motivate a passionate (and poorly-paid or unpaid) staff, how to think differently about \\"restricted funds,\\" and how to transcend systemic / external / industry-wide problems. I particularly enjoyed his discussion on \\"legistative\\" leadership (versus \\"executive\\" leadership in the business world). Collins predicts a dramatic reversal - that one day non-profit leaders, who have mastered legistative leadership, will be wooed away to lead for-profit businesses.<br /><br />This monograph does stand on its own. However, I think you would have to be fairly familiar with the concepts in Good to Great to fully appreciate its value.<br /><br />If you are still not convinced, you can also go to his website, jimcollins.com, to read 3-4 pages of snip-its from the monograph.<br /><br />Regardless, I would recommend this to every social sector leader.

B00006LPER|5.0|If it is true that sadomasochism is a two-sided coin which contains the whole in the diverse expression of its opposites, then the cinematic portrait of Erika Kohut has its reality.  Professor Kohut treats her piano students with a kind of fascist sadism while longing for the same for herself.  Her outward expression projects her desire.  That is why she can hurt without guilt or remorse.<br /><br />Along comes talented, charming, handsome young Walter Klemmer (Benoit Magimel) who is attracted to her because of her passion and her intensity.  He wants to become her student so as to be close to her.  She rejects him out of hand, but because of his talent the Vienna conservatory votes him in.  He falls in love with her.  Again she pushes him away, but he will not take no for an answer, and thereby begins his own descent into depravity and loss of self-respect.<br /><br />The question the viewer might ask at this point is, who is in control?  The sadist or the masochist?  Indeed who is the sadist and who the masochist?  It is hard to tell.  Is it the person who has just been greatly abused both psychologically and physically, who is actually lying wounded on the floor in grotesque triumphant and fulfillment, or is it the person who is rushing out the door, sated, giving the order that no one is to know what happened.<br /><br />But Erika is not just a sadomasochistic freak.  She is a sex extreme freak.  She wants to experience the extremes of human sexuality while maintaining the facade of respectability.  Actually that isn't even true.  She says she doesn't care what others think.  She doesn't care if they walk in and find her bleeding on the floor because she is in love.  Love, she calls it.  For her sex and love are one and the same.<br /><br />At one point Walter tells her that love isn't everything.  How ironic such a superfluity is to her.  How gratuitous the comment.<br /><br />The movie is beautifully cut and masterfully directed by Michael Haneke who spins the tale with expert camera work and carefully constructed sets in which the essence of the action is not just clear but exemplified (as in the bathroom when Walter propels himself high above the top of the stall to find Erika within).  He also employs a fine positioning of the players so that they are always where they should be with well timed cuts from one angle to another.  This is particularly important in the scene in which Erika, like a blood-drained corpse caught in stark white and black light, lies under her lover, rigid as stone.  Here for the most part we only see her face and the stark outline of her neck with its pulsating artery.  We don't need to see any more.<br /><br />The part of Erika Kohut is perfect for Isabelle Huppert who is not afraid of extremes; indeed she excels in them.  I have seen her in a number of movies and what she does better than almost anyone is become the character body and soul.  Like the woman she plays in this movie she is unafraid of what others may think and cares little about her appearance in a decorative sense.  What matters to her is the performance and the challenge.  No part is too demanding.  No character too depraved.  It's as if Huppert wants to experience all of humanity, and wants us to watch her as she does.  She is always fascinating and nearly flawless.  She is not merely a leading light of the French cinema; she is one of the great actresses of our time who has put together an amazingly diverse body of work.<br /><br />I think it is highly instructive and affords us a wonderful and striking contrast to compare her performance here with her performance in The Lacemaker (La Dentelli&egrave;re) from 1977 when she was 22 years old.  There she was apple sweet in her red hair and freckles and her pretty face and her cute little figure playing Pomme, a Parisian apprentice hairdresser.  Her character was shy about sex and modest--just an ordinary French girl who hoped one day to be a beautician.  Here she is a self-destructive witch, bitter with hateful knowledge of herself, shameless and entirely depraved.<br /><br />Huppert is fortunate in being an actress in France where there are parts like this for women past the age of starlets.  (Hollywood could never make a movie like this.)  In the American cinema, only a handful of the very best and hardest working actresses can hope to have a career after the age of about thirty.  Huppert greatly increases her exposure because of her ability and range, but also because she is willing to play unsympathetic roles, here and also in La C&eacute;r&eacute;monie (1995) in which she plays a vile, spiteful murderess.<br /><br />Do see this for Isabelle Huppert.  You won't forget her or the character she brings to life.ructive witch, bitter with hateful knowledge of herself, shameless and entirely depraved.<br /><br />Huppert is fortunate in being an actress in France where there are parts like this for women past the age of starlets.  (Hollywood could never make a movie like this.)  In the American cinema, only a handful of the very best and hardest working actresses can hope to have a career after the age of about thirty.  Huppert greatly increases her exposure because of her ability and range, but also because she is willing to play unsympathetic roles, here and also in La C&eacute;r&eacute;monie (1995) in which she plays a vile, spiteful murderess.<br /><br />Do see this for Isabelle Huppert.  You won't forget her or the character she brings to life.

0670033375|5.0|This is an outstanding piece of work, in some ways even better than Diamond's Pulitzer Prize winning Guns, Germs, and Steel: The Fates of Human Societies (1997) which I highly recommend.  Here, instead of explaining why wealth and power accrued to European states and not, for example, to South America states, Diamond demonstrates mostly how some societies failed.  Along the way he contrasts the failures with some successes, and in the latter part of the book addresses current problems and possible solutions.<br /><br />He begins with modern Montana, specifically Bitterroot Valley, a society in danger of failing because of deforestation, pollution, loss of productive top soil, and other factors.  He follows this with Part 2, \\"Past Societies\\" in which the melancholy history of Easter Island and some other Pacific Islands is retold in fascinating detail.  I was especially interested in the material on Easter Island, which, because of its relative isolation from the rest of the world over many centuries, has always served in my mind as a microcosmic cautionary tale for the entire planet. Although I have read other books about Easter Island and have seen a couple of documentaries, I found Diamond's exposition full of new information, offering fresh insights into how that society collapsed.<br /><br />Also delineated in remarkably readable detail are the collapses of the Anasazi of the US southwest, the Maya in Mesoamerica, the Viking-founded colonies in the north Atlantic and especially in Greenland.  There is some excellent material on how Iceland succeeded (barely) and how the New Guinea highland people managed to avoid the fate of some other Pacific Island societies, and why Japan succeeded in saving its forests and croplands in the time of the Tokugawa.  Note that these stories are primarily about ecological successes or failures, not successes or failures due to political or military misadventures.<br /><br />What surprised me about the failed societies is that the most destructive thing the people did was cut down their forests to plant food crops.  Again and again, from Easter Island to Greenland, the effect of cutting down trees was devastating because it allowed wind and rain to remove the topsoil, either blowing it away or washing it down gullies and rivers into the sea.  In the case of Easter Island, using up all the timber resulted in an inability to fish since without wood the people could not build boats.<br /><br />People also clear forests to create pastures for grazing their livestock.  This also proved disastrous in some cases, especially when the animals were sheep and goats, who typically graze right down to the roots of plants, and can thereby quickly strip the vegetation from great tracks of land.<br /><br />But the common link between all societal ecological disasters is simple, and one of great importance to us all today.  All those societies--Easter Island, the Maya, the Anasazi, etc.--allowed their populations to grow beyond the carrying capacity of their environment.  That is the bottom line for all of humanity.  Hungry people do desperate things, as Diamond recalls in the chapter on Rwanda.  When too many people share too little space and resources, laws and morality break down, governments fall and people kill one another massively.  All peoples do this.  No human race or ethnic group is exempt.  It could happen here.  Diamond's book is a warning that we all need to hear and appreciate.  We are part of the ecology, and not above it.  We need to live in harmony with the rest of the planet and not imagine that we can treat the planet and its resources with carelessness, abuse and neglect.<br /><br />Toward the end of the book, Diamond gives his prescription on how we might avoid the fate of the failed societies.  He notes on page 214 that bad things can happen \\"when parents take good care of their individual children but not of their children's future.\\"  He is referring to the parents of European friends\\"who bought life insurance, made wills, and obsessed about the schooling of their children,\\" but \\"blundered into the disaster of World War II.\\"<br /><br />I think Diamond nails it with this observation.  Today's soccer moms (and dads) with all our affluence and all the care we put into our children's and grandchildren's future may be failing because we are not electing the kind of leadership that will provide for their future.  High deficients (greedily borrowing from our children and grandchildren) and lack of consideration for the environment, through the depletion of fossil fuels and the pollution of fresh water sources and the air, etc., may completely override anything we might do for our children.<br /><br />Diamond also says that at some point societies have to realize which core values are worth maintaining and which no longer make sense in light of current circumstances (p. 440 and elsewhere).  He cites the example of the Greenland Norse who maintained their European values and lifestyles and died out when they might have survived had they taken on the Inuit lifestyle and learned to hunt ringed seals and whales and build igloos.  Additionally there is the sad example of Easter Island where they continued to worship greedy gods (and their priests) and built statues instead of using their resources to maintain their forests and topsoil.<br /><br />I think Diamond's argument especially applies to the false gods some people follow today, the Bronze Aged gods of fundamentalist religions who fear progressive change and continue to seek solutions through violence, intolerance, and the defeat of \\"enemies.\\"<br /><br />In reading about the various collapses here one is struck by what they had in common.  In every case there were too many people chasing too few resources.  At peak times on Easter Island or among the Maya, great monuments were build to celebrate the society's success.  And then came the fall soon after.  Diamond warns that the crash is typically not gradual like human senescence, but abrupt, following fast on the heels of the society's finest hour.ssed about the schooling of their children,\\" but \\"blundered into the disaster of World War II.\\"    I think Diamond nails it with this observation.  Today's soccer moms (and dads) with all our affluence and all the care we put into our children's and grandchildren's future may be failing because we are not electing the kind of leadership that will provide for their future.  High deficients (greedily borrowing from our children and grandchildren) and lack of consideration for the environment, through the depletion of fossil fuels and the pollution of fresh water sources and the air, etc., may completely override anything we might do for our children.    Diamond also says that at some point societies have to realize which core values are worth maintaining and which no longer make sense in light of current circumstances (p. 440 and elsewhere).  He cites the example of the Greenland Norse who maintained their European values and lifestyles and died out when they might have survived had they taken on the Inuit lifestyle and learned to hunt ringed seals and whales and build igloos.  Additionally there is the sad example of Easter Island where they continued to worship greedy gods (and their priests) and built statues instead of using their resources to maintain their forests and topsoil.    I think Diamond's argument especially applies to the false gods some people follow today, the Bronze Aged gods of fundamentalist religions who fear progressive change and continue to seek solutions through violence, intolerance, and the defeat of \\"enemies.\\"    In reading about the various collapses here one is struck by what they had in common.  In every case there were too many people chasing too few resources.  At peak times on Easter Island or among the Maya, great monuments were build to celebrate the society's success.  And then came the fall soon after.  Diamond warns that the crash is typically not gradual like human senescence, but abrupt, following fast on the heels of the society's finest hour.

0345440900|1.0|As a mother to an 18 month toddler who has read just about every book on baby & sleep out there and tried every method, let me be brutally frank about how wrong the book is about getting babies to sleep.  Like other first time mothers,  I desperately wanted to believe that this book's promise of \\"no cry sleep solution\\" would work.  I couldn't stand my baby cry for a minute and couldn't imagine the alternative self-soothe method.  But I tried the no cry solutions suggested in the book - ritual, rocking, putting them to bed when they are sleepy but awake, if they wake in them middle of the night, taking them out and rocking them and then putting them back into their crib.  I tried this book's sleep approach for over 4 months.  There was no improvement in my baby's sleep. What really got me to stop listening to this book was that one night, after the rituals and after an entire hour of rocking him, my baby was so sleepy but would not let go of me, that he tossed and turned in our bed and accidentally hit his head on our bed's headboard so hard that he lost consiousness.  I decided that this is not the way to teach a baby how to go to sleep.  I read two other books on sleep by doctors who have professional training and research on infant sleep and found that they had very different perspective than this book.  The two books - Sleeping Through the Night by Dr. Jodi A. Mindell and Healthy Sleep Habits, Happy Child by Dr. Marc Weissbluth - both advocated the cry it out/self-soothe method.  I did a large poll of mothers and found that 90% of those who were happy with their babies sleep had in fact used the cry it out/self-soothe method.  So I decided that I really should try this alternative even though it was with great anxiety that I embarked upon sleep training my then 13 month old .  I worried and obsessed and was really scared to start it.  But it really really does work.  The first night of sleep training, my baby cried 10 minutes.  The night six nights he cried abouta minute each night.  After a week he went to sleep happily.  After two weeks, he no longer woke up in the middle of the night.  He is now sleeping 11-12 hours through the night and is a very happy boy. I wished that I had not read Tracy's book and had instead read the Mindell and Weisbluth sooner.  Avoid the sections about sleep in this book - getting your baby to sleep enough, sleep through the night, or getting babies to go to sleep on their own - it didn't work for me.

0740748475|5.0|Not only was \\"Calvin & Hobbes\\" the best comic strip of the past 20 years, it was, with a few exceptions, just about the only good one. In fact, if my local paper hadn't started rerunning old \\"Calvin\\" strips to promote this collection, I probably wouldn't read the comics pages at all. If you're a fan, you know it combines simple profundities about life and childhood with genuine, unforced humor, and writer/artist Bill Watterson's drawings are simple but perfect. (Calvin himself, of course, has become an icon, while Hobbes could have been the most popular stuffed animal ever if Watterson had allowed merchandising. And Calvin's mom and dad may be the most realistic-looking parents in a comic strip ever.) I agree with some of the critics here that it would have been nicer to have an easily readable complete set of paperbacks than these Oxford English Dictionary-size volumes, but I'd rather have this collection than miss a single strip. At least this one can be kept on the shelf for children and grandchildren to discover, while adults can go back to it and read a few pages they'd forgotten whenever they feel like it. I know that Watterson gave up the grind of daily comics to focus on more \\"serious\\" art, but if this turned out to be all he did with his life, it would be plenty.

B000B8QEYC|3.0|Like so many other reviewers, I too am a HUGE fan of Enya's and own all her albums, listen to them regularly, and have been long awaiting the release of a new album! Five years without a new Enya CD is a very long time, so excitedly, I purchased this CD the day it was released. First time listening to it, I was indeed disappointed. It sounded as if--for all the talent that Enya has--that she has suddenly reduced her songs to a limited range of 4 or 5 notes, up and down the scale---over and over and OVER again! Talk about monotony! Now, however, as I've listened to the CD about 15 times, I'm beginning to hear more depth to the pieces, and I'm starting to enjoy the CD more with each listen. I definitely feel that this CD is an \\"acquired taste\\" and that it takes time and SEVERAL LISTENS to enjoy it. I unabashedly feel that this is NOT Enya's best work! One would think that after five dry years, she would produce something really fantastic, especially since there's only 12 songs on this CD. Like so many other reviewers have mentioned, each song seems to sound so much like other Enya songs from the past--or worse, like other songs on THIS very CD, as they all tend to blend together and sound so much alike that you can't quite tell where one ends and another begins. That said, however, now that I've listened several times, I'm beginning to appreciate it a bit more, and can actually admit to LIKING several of the songs. Can't we just stick to English and Gaelic?  Why the need to make one up for a music CD such as this? Afterall, this music is NOT the soundtrack to a movie like Lord of the Rings...) For personal reasons, I've become very attached to the song, \\"If I Could Be Where You Are\\", because when I listen to the song, I think of my Mom, who is in heaven, and I wish I could \\"find a way to bring her back home\\". The hymm-like quality of this song, coupled with the lyrics is very moving to me, but as I said, for personal reasons.     (At the risk of repeating myself--but then, why not? Enya surely does it....) so much of this CD is repetitive and redundant, and it seems a bit like \\"leftovers\\".  For example, The song \\"Long Long Journey\\" could well be titled \\"On My Way Home, Part II\\", and \\"Somebody Said Goodbye\\" (the MOST redundant song on the CD) could be \\"One by One: Continued\\" (and to answer your question, Enya, \\"Is there a reason?\\" NO! There isn't! They simply said goodbye! Can't that be good enough? One time asking would have been MORE than enough for this song... MUST you really REPEAT this question over and over and over for EVERY SINGLE LINE OF THE SONG????!! Sheesh!)    Enya fans will, of course, give this CD a try. But if you're not an Enya fan already, this CD will not inspire you, nor make you a fan. Try \\"Paint the Sky With Stars\\", or \\"Watermark\\"....or for that matter, ANY of Enya's other CDs, in order to REALLY appreciate her work.  I am giving this CD 3 stars because I don't feel that it deserves QUITE 4. If I could, I'd give it something like 3.75.

B00006M183|4.0|Caveat: I think that the best reviews for this album were by Mohlman here in Amazon and by Rolling Stone.    When I bought this CD my knowledge of Pearl Jam was limited to 7 songs (4 from Ten, Do the Evolution, Brother and Better Man). However, even though I knew so little, it was obvious to me that Pearl Jam deserved a lot of respect. So as I started playing the CD, and finding myself not liking it, my immediate response was, \\"idiot, now you can't even appreciate good music!\\"    However, it seems I was wrong. After a week I was able to, little by little, see the gem that is Riot Act.     Two tracks that I can't stand, though: Arc (Vedder's \\"song of grief\\" which I don't think is a song at all--just Vedder wailing away) and Help Help (in which Vedder's voice in falsetto is very, very annoying).     Likewise, the are two outstanding tracks: Thumbing my Way and All or None. Anyone who has ever really hitchhiked (I mean weeks on end) will understand this song. The pointless questions \\"lingering over head,\\" the ennui of \\"counting steps\\" to pass the time, and a pervasive guilt, for all we've done wrong, that will just not go away. All or None is similarly powerful. Its about someone with such high ideals for himself that must either achieve it all, or else he'll have nothing at all. Moreover, its about the depression that ensues when such men realize that no matter what they do, they'll fail, and will thus need to settle with nothing. Again, it's a profound and moving track. Also, both songs are musically simple--for the most part just acousting guitars--something which, of course, adds to their melancholy.    Then we have some very good tracks like Love Boat Captain (the anthemic rocker of the album, dedicated to the nine men who died at Rockslide), Ghost (about running away from the emptiness/numbness of modernity), I Am Mine (about the ideals of agency), You Are (love song), Green Disease (against greed) and Bu$hLeaguer (against Bush; and though I don't dislike Bush asmost people find cool to do, the song is very funny and witty).    After this we are left with some good, solid tracks like Can't Keep, Save You, Get Right, Cropduster and 1/2 Full.    I haven't said much about the music per se, since I don't know much about instruments and such. Nonetheless, the lead guitar on You Are is pretty innovative (I've never heard anything like that). Someone said Cameron drove a guitar through a drums-amplifier to get that sound; I'm not sure, though. Also, 1/2 Full, like Mohlman said, would have made Stevie Ray Vaughn proud.    All in all, its a very good CD. However, I listened to Riot Act while also listening to Ten. And the differences are blatant. The music notwithstanding, Vedder is changed. Like the Rolling Stone reviewer commented, it's as if Vedder got tired of big, showy anthems; instead, he takes a step back in this record. With a subdued voice, he tries to subtly impart his always-profound messages. Very different from songs like Once, Evenflow, and company!    Actually, since Keith Larris from Rolling Stone is much more eloquent than me, I'll let him finish:    \\"Songs such as 'Can't Keep' fall subtly into their choruses rather than explode into anthems because Vedder and his mates are too honest to indulge in the showboating of today's power balladeers. Anyone can fake a heroic stand in the studio. It's more challenging to quietly voice your need to take a step back.\\" ([...])
0688170528|4.0|Jodi Picoult once again takes the reader to that uncomfortable area of storytelling that most of us will never encounter in our own lives.  Here is the story of true love, young love, and what one does for the sake of love.  The raw emotions expressed by the main characters - Chris and Emily - childhood friends turned young lovers, was so gripping it made me remember my own adolescent angst.  Any adult reading this book that cannot relate to Chris or Emily should consider themselves lucky and, well... possibly a bit un-normal.  I cannot imagine a teenager that at one point or another doesn't contemplate suicide as an option to their problems.  What Picoult does so well is capture that gut-wrenching feeling of these young lovers and gives us a glimpse of their lives together up until that very last second.  While I would have liked to see more time devoted to Emily's decision to commit suicide and less time spent on the lawyer and his life, I still feel this story was extremely compelling and real.
B000BOH8XW|4.0|Shakira came along during the Latin explosion of the late 90's except unlike many who populated the genre, she wasn't born and raised in the United States nor was English her first language. Her lack of experience in the language showed on her first English speaking album, Laundry Service, she made up in presentation and was much more experimental than the Latin pop of Jennifer Lopez or Ricky Martin whose songs all sounded alike. <br /> <br />After taking a couple years off, Shakira came back this year with two albums, back in July she released the Spanish language Fijacion Oral vol. 1 (translation Oral Fixation) that featured La Tortura, a song with so much sexual tension even American didn't need a translation, and more recently she released the English language Oral Fixation vol. 2 (translation Fijacion Oral). There are two songs that overlap both albums, the lovely Something and the uplifting The Day and the Time. <br /> <br />Volume 2 actually starts of with some people chanting the Lords Prayer. I think this is the first time chanting was included in a pop song since Enigma scored their only hit with Sadness part 1. But the song, How Do You Do, quickly turns into a rocker about the violence that surrounds religion with lyrics like, \\"How many people die, and hurt in your name? Hey, does that make you proud, or does it bring you shame?\\" Apparently George Bush and Osama bin Laden have the answers. <br /> <br />After the opener, Shakira deals with a failed relation on Don't Bother and Illegal, the later which feature Carlos Santana and his trademark guitar and sound like a more somber version Underneath Your Clothes claiming \\"it should be illegal to break a woman's heart.\\" Don't Bother, on the other hand is a more upbeat kiss-off to a former flame who is trying to reunite. <br /> <br />Even though this time around Shakira seems to master the English language a little better, her strong point is still in the presentation. And it seems as if she has been listening to a lot of American 80's since her last album. During How Do You Do, there is a guitar solo that song very similar to Edie Brickell's What I Am, while on Don't Bother, the guitars seemed to be borrowed from the Cure's Just Like Heaven. The bouncy Hey You sounds like something out of the Stray Cats catalog had a female been the lead singer. And she even seems influenced by bands who themselves like the 80's retro sound as The Day and the Time sound much like The Killer's Smile Like You Me It. But she does go old school Latin music with the inclusion of mariachi horns on Animal City. But in each case she is able to make it her own. <br /> <br />The album ends much like it starts off but instead it's a children's choir that does the chanting on yet another 80's influenced Timor which relays heavy on synthesizers and drum loops. But instead of religion, politics is the topic with the kids asking throughout the song, \\"How about the people who don't matter anymore?\\" Taking aim at the apathy that plagues the youth around the wealthy world who care more about what's on MTV than those less fortunate who are dieing whether it be by war or by hunger.

This is a must-see Christmas movie on par, I think, with \\"A Christmas Story.\\"
B00028HBKM|2.0|Purely from the point of view of watching the movie it was amazing.  The film costs here were amazingly well spent (thats what the stars are for).  To film a movie in Latin and Aramaic was brilliant and the sets and costumes were amazing.  I think they could have saved about half the movie budget by having Jesus expend a human amount of blood but that's ok -<br /><br />  I realize it was necessary for Gibson to stay true to his fundamentalist Catholic views and strictly follow the stations of the cross in depicting the passion of Christ, even though there is no scriptural evidence for them.  Having said this though it is important to point out what a horrible theology this movie presents.  It is essentially the Anselmian view that Jesus was incarnated as the only sufficient sacrifice for our sins.  As this movie presents it the only significant part of Jesus's life is his death.  It is this sort of blood-soaked religious ideology that says it is ok to kill people as a means of purification.<br /><br />Even as an atheist I can see that this is probably the most immoral of all ethical or religious doctrines.  If you want a sound theology try Abelard or some of the Franciscan authors.  In their writings the incarnation is the culmination of creation, an event that was planned from the beginning and NOT simply a reaction to \\"people behaving badly\\".  It represents the ultimate unification of God with His creation.  The moral lesson comes not from the death of Jesus saving us from our sins.  (which mires human beings in eternal stupidity and doesn't apparently cure us of sinfulness either ...so it is pretty much a wash) The moral message needs to come from Jesus's life...take care of lepers, eat with tax collectors, help a prostitute get on her feet.  Things get a little messed up but its not anything that cannot be fixed by simply doing human things.

B00007KLJJ|3.0|\\"The Four Feathers\\", directed by Shekhar Kapur is the sixth film version of the classic novel by A. E. W. Mason. The many reviews of this film can be grouped into two prominent points of view. One half of the reviewers rated the film based on the technical aspects (such as how well this movie portrayed actual history, accuracy to the book and how well it reenacted Mason's ideas). The other group reviewed this film from simply an entertainment point of view and rated it on how much they enjoyed it. The group that looked at the movie from a technical point of view, disliked it. Those that ignored the technical aspects seemed to be happily entertained.  <br />   From a technical point of view, I feel that Kate Hudson was an unfortunate choice of actress for this character. She didn't have the right personality and mannerisms to fit the role and seemed too \\"American\\" for the role of this English lady. Also I believe that the film did not spend enough time developing the characters. This made it hard for me to understand their decisions and empathize with their feelings. <br />   I really enjoyed the settings in this film and the beauty of the shots. Although there were some lulls in the pace, the storyline kept a decent tempo. I had the feeling that some sections had too much of a melodramatic feel. The action sequences were quite exiting and the story itself was entertaining but did not have much depth. <br />I agree with the arguments made by both sides.  It would have been nice if the characters had been more developed, if some of the scenes had been cut a bit shorter and, if possible, some of the melodrama removed. I was happy with how it was beautifully filmed.  <br />   Overall I enjoyed this film and I would recommend it to those who are looking for simple, unchallenging entertainment.

Typically, as masterful as a novelist can be, their short stories often fall short. Not so with this collection. Gaiman combines fantasy and horror to bring to life characters that typically find themselves in unbelievable situations. However, Gaiman's fantastic writing makes these events seem normal, everyday occurrences.  In particular, I would recommend the retelling of Snow White and the Wedding Story.<br /><br />In addition to the short fiction, Gaiman also includes some of his poetry. Ranging from scenes of lonely vampires to a computer game that takes over unknowing minds, all of the poetry is engaging and will absorb your attention for quite some time after you have put down the book.<br /><br />Overall, I would recommend this collection for anyone who enjoys fantasy, horror, and good writing. And now, I think I will go reread the book for the fourth time...\\"
B000002B1M|4.0|While I couldn't approve less of Nas using the title \\"The Message\\" without giving props the songs is admittedly good. Sometimes Nas loses me on the lyrics, but generally it is a good song with a strong message. The beat also makes the song. It goes so well with what is being said and gives the song an emotional and powerful feel. The beat demands the attention of listener without detracting from the focus of what is being done: the lyrics. Also, conspicuous is the \\"I ain't the type of brother for you to be testin'\\" line. Why? Because Nas uses brother instead of what most rappers would use: 'Nigga'. While there is no shortage of the n word in Nas' raps, I just like the replacement here, it's positive.<br /><br />\\"Street Dreams\\" is another favorite, but is really made by the beat and the chorus. I really wait for the chorus, because it's really strong. The chorus is shocking, but also mixes in words like 'destiny'. Hearing a word like that in rap music is surprising and when it is used well (as it is here) it makes it all the better. Nas' vocabulary really adds to a lot of his songs, and this is no exception.<br /><br />While there are a couple more good songs on It Was Written, (\\"I Gave You Power\\", \\"Shootouts\\") generally most of it comes up average. There is a long lull in between \\"Street Dreams\\" and \\"If I Ruled the World\\". A lot of very average to poor Nas work seperates these great tracks. What I mean is that when Nas isn't captivating, he's boring and clumsy as hell. There are times when Nas seems destined for greatness, and other times when you wonder how he got a record deal at all.<br /><br />A problem I have with Nas is that he is not original. While this subject has beeen ahrped upon by countless critics I am not going to criticize his beat recycling, or his remake of \\"Sweet Dreams\\". The problem I have is when I hear some songs I get the distinct feeling they were inspired directly by earlier work of other rappers. For instance, \\"Black Girl Lost\\" seems to be a direct take off of 2Pac's \\"Baby Don't Cry\\". Also, while I recognize that Nas is a contemporary of the Wu - his East coast lingo flat out reeks of the clan. The 'word is bond' line has basically been unoffically copyrighted by the clan, and it seems really off to have someone else (who indeed sound sismilar) saying it all the time.<br /><br />Overall, this album is a grand mixture Nas-icity. You get it all here. There are some really high moments, and a long lull before you get that last on with track 15. I don't hate all the work that Nas does, but some of it needs to be cleaned up quite a bit. After the first two tracks of It Was Written I was ready to deem this bad boy a classic, but it lost me not long after that. Nas can be good and he is here, but he is also mundane, boring, and unoriginal.ms to be a direct take off of 2Pac's \\"Baby Don't Cry\\". B000005Z0E|4.0|In 2Pacalypse now we get a glimpse at a rapper who in the years to come would change the rap world with his epic roller coaster of a career. He would become know by many as the greatest rapper ever. While this is always in debate few can find reason why he should be considered any less than one of the greatest. No doubt 2 Pac is emotional, but he starts his tragic career with a more conciseness message. 2Pacalypse Now is raw and powerful, and glimmers with the depth that 2 Pac possesses.<br /><br />2 Pac was aiming at something much more grander than what he accomplished in his later albums. He addresses his life as he has lived it, a day-to-day struggle. He spins the trials and tribulations of his life into vivid story lines. He addresses very pertinent issues pertaining to the black race, with his main focus being directed towards the unwarranted targeting of black males by the police. 2 Pac doesn't lash out with unbridled anger, as he seems to do when he was under the death row persuasion. Instead he tells his stories in a calm and intelligent manner, one in which he clearly makes an effort to make the raps understandable. There is absolutely no bling bling in this album, its all real, and 2 Pac doesn't glorify the streets instead he tries to uplift them. 2 Pac's social conscience comes off as genuine and he does it without an excess of violent undertones.<br /><br />2 Pac definitely tries to become a uniting force for young black youths, especially for those who struggled on the streets. Tracks like \\"Words of Wisdom\\", and \\"Violent\\" are powerful Public Enemy esque songs, blunt and meaningful. His skill for storytelling comes out all over this album, in tracks like \\"Brenda's Got A Baby\\", \\"Pat Time Mutha\\", and \\"Soulja's Story\\" tell about tragedy, and ghetto desperation with terrific word play by 2Pac. Few tracks could qualify as party songs, which I applaud. 2 Pac's theme is real and not influenced by the record industry. Something that I believe severely affected his later albums.<br /><br />Unfortunately social relevance doesn't sell 15 millions records. This album also lacks a strong radio worthy hit. The music on this album is rough around the edges and lacks experience. But it has a lot of great moments. 2 Pac himself is noticeably young. His style is very unpolished and sounds a bit like beat oriented party rap. Even though this was 1992 he does kind of sound like a stereotypical 80's rapper. But as we all know his style expands marvelously in years to come. Even on this album he does show signs of range. He raps in a very slow and punctual manner but does have tracks where he raps very quickly mixing some of his rhymes much more closely. 2 Pac's powerful presence on the mic is noticeably missing, but this is mostly due to his inexperience.<br /><br />The sound of this album reminds me a lot of Ice Cube circa 1990. His beats are obviously west coast, but do have some recognizable New York influences. His beats are not overly deep and banging. And they lack a bit of creativity. But they are perfect for the time period. His beats are heavy on simple drumbeats and looping synthesizers. I must be honest I'm not blown away by any of the beats on this CD, at least not as much as some of his later tracks where they can literally send chills down your spine. They do suffice and at least show his hard edge but emotional approach to story telling in an upbeat while not overly violent way.<br /><br />I can definite feel what 2 Pac is tying to do here, even though I'm not overly impressed with the actual music the lyrical aspects are astounding and well worth the listen. This CD doesn't really break much new ground and is sonically inferior to many other CDs out there then and now. It acts better as a prologue to his later efforts and a terrific beginning to a dramatic career. Its strength lies solely on 2 Pac's ambassador to the streets storytelling.e severely affected his later albums. <br /> <br />Unfortunately social relevance doesn't sell 15 millions records. This album also lacks a strong radio worthy hit. The music on this album is rough around the edges and lacks experience. But it has a lot of great moments. 2 Pac himself is noticeably young. His style is very unpolished and sounds a bit like beat oriented party rap. Even though this was 1992 he does kind of sound like a stereotypical 80's rapper. But as we all know his style expands marvelously in years to come. Even on this album he does show signs of range. He raps in a very slow and punctual manner but does have tracks where he raps very quickly mixing some of his rhymes much more closely. 2 Pac's powerful presence on the mic is noticeably missing, but this is mostly due to his inexperience. <br /> <br />The sound of this album reminds me a lot of Ice Cube circa 1990. His beats are obviously west coast, but do have some recognizable New York influences. His beats are not overly deep and banging. And they lack a bit of creativity. But they are perfect for the time period. His beats are heavy on simple drumbeats and looping synthesizers. I must be honest I'm not blown away by any of the beats on this CD, at least not as much as some of his later tracks where they can literally send chills down your spine. They do suffice and at least show his hard edge but emotional approach to story telling in an upbeat while not overly violent way.  <br /> <br />I can definite feel what 2 Pac is tying to do here, even though I'm not overly impressed with the actual music the lyrical aspects are astounding and well worth the listen. This CD doesn't really break much new ground and is sonically inferior to many other CDs out there then and now. It acts better as a prologue to his later efforts and a terrific beginning to a dramatic career. Its strength lies solely on 2 Pac's ambassador to the streets storytelling. <br />
B000BJ7BCA|3.0|Admittedly, SKY HIGH, as many critics have noted is a blend of THE INCREDIBLES and HARRY POTTER, but it never reaches those heights.  Kurt Russell and Kelly Preston play superheroes who send their young son to Sky High, a school for super heroes suspended way up in the sky.  Of course, once there young Will (nicely played by Michael Angarano) meets up with the typical high school bullies and a seductive temptress played by Mary Elizabeth Winsted.  At first, young Will Stronghold doesn't seem to have any powers, so he's placed in the \\"sidekick\\" category until one day he discovers he has inherited both his father's strength and mother's ability to fly wherein he is made a \\"hero\\" and becomes an outcast to his old friends.  There are some nice bits by Bruce Campbell as Coach Sonic Boomer; Cloris Leachman as the doctor with x-ray vision; and Wonder Woman herself, Lynda Carter, as the school's principal who has the best line in the movie:  \\"Do they think I'm Wonder Woman?\\".  It's all innocuous fun and in its own way, fairly entertaining, with some nice 80s songs to boot.  But it's not a classic and will probably leave your memory within hours.
B0000029GA|5.0|This album is the definitive compilation of east coast early rap music. This album certainly was a force behind the development of the genera and basically put Nas on the hip-hop map. No other album could have better jump started a career and a genera better than this album was able to. It is certain Nas has changed over time from his roots of this album and SJ just seem to like the new Nas better than the Nas we hear on this album. His opinion is just something that everyone is just going to learn to accept to disagree with. Here is what this album means to me. This album is in my top 5 albums, no other conditions, this album has it all.<br /><br />It has some of the best, truest, personal lyrics that are found in rap. There is something thing in his songs that so vividly paints a picture of what he is portraying. Lyrically there are very few albums that have top to bottom what this album has, there are very few low points in Nas' tracks. I not even a very big fan of lyrics in songs but Nas here still seems to more than what other have. Nas could be a poster child for defining the term 'street poet'. There is nothing to flashy, thugging or R&Bish in his songs. It seems to be only the real truth of things rather than a tainted picture of reality.<br /><br />His lyrics lead me into what I believe is Nas strongest trait, the man can strait up flow. No one goes from line to line, verse to verse as smoothly as he does. You can barely tell what lead into what because it all seems to fit so seamlessly together. Regardless of the topic or song Nas always lays things down for us with no gaps, stops or pauses. His breathing patterns always amaze me, how is he able to fit all it together with out pauses. This coupled with the lost art of limiting guest tracks truly displays Nas in his entirety.<br /><br />In terms of beat the album might be slightly dated and I would tend to think that just because of strengths in other areas the beats are the weakest part of this album. It is not that they are bad per se, but they don't seem to add to much to the album. In some cases I find it to be a detraction rather than a positive. I find \\"Halftime\\"'s beat to be incredibly annoying to the point where it actually almost ruins the song. I do think that for the most part the less is more theory that is found in this album fits Nas style perfectly. The infusion of jazz and pop music (MJ's) samples fit very well with Nas' style. It takes a back seat to his flow, as well it should.<br /><br />This album is a little on the short side, only having 10 tracks, but there is only one skit on the entire album. That has to be some kind of records for a rap album. Still what is on this album is all quality, nothing to flashy, just an incredible compilation of very good songs.<br /><br />Any rap fan needs this.um. B00000255F|5.0|Back in 1975, I was paying for my college tuition working as a night watchman in the offices underneath the Queensboro Bridge in Manhattan. The engineer's office had a big bay window and a great sounding tube radio that would glow orange in the dark. I spent most of my time at a desk in an adjoining office, studying with a desk light, when one night, I heard this lonely trumpet from far away in no man's land start playing. I put my book down and listened. I had on a rock station, the best (WNEW-FM), but this wasn't rock. But it was something I understood. I got up and walked into the engineer's  office. The blinds were opened,  a light (from a streetlamp, or a full moon, I don't remember) filled the office with slashes of light, just like in the movies. I stared at the radio, mesmerized, by this sound and this story of two losers, way out of their depths, trying to make a score with some pretty no-nonsense type guys and all through the song that trumpet played, way out in the distance, all the way in the back of the record. It seemed to represent their dreams--visable, but somehow, always, just out of reach.  When the song ended, I kept standing there in the dark, looking at the radio. I felt like I heard something I never heard before. WHAT WAS THAT? WHO was that??!! Who would have the balls to put out somthing so uncommon, so true to life, yet so different that despite it's perfect execution, was sure to go over everyone's head? I felt in that dark room, the song was made just for me. The great Allison Steele, The Nightbird finally came on announcing that was \\"Meeting Across The River\\" by Bruce Springsteen. That was my introduction to Springsteen's music. I went out and bought BORN TO RUN the next day and was astounded. The rock n roll that was on there told me that this guy knew and remembered who Phil Spector was. It was the sound that was in my heart since I first heard \\"Be My Baby\\" when I was a kid. But these weren't puppy-love songs from a musical era criminally forgotten, but fear-fueled dreams of winning or losing or escape from whatever dead end street that resides at the bottom of life. The cry that ends \\"Backstreets\\" or the absolute HOWL that closes \\"Jungleland\\", still rattles my soul and like \\"Meeting...\\", still makes me wonder, \\"You can put that on a record\\"?lly forgotten, but fear-fueled dreams of winning or losing or escape from whatever dead end street that resides at the bottom of life. The cry that ends \\"Backstreets\\" or the absolute HOWL that closes \\"Jungleland\\", still rattles my soul and like \\"Meeting...\\", still makes me wonder, \\"You can put that on a record\\"?
0060899190|5.0|This moving book, a compilation of never-before-revealed secrets written on one side of a postcard and sent anonymously to the website PostSecret, will touch you.  Some secrets are dark, some so personal you feel an intruder for reading them, some caustic, some comical. The artwork that accompanies each message is remarkable: shocking in its originality and its effect.  I had been a fan of the site and wondered if owning the book were really necessary.  Would it turn into a Coffee Table Book (ugh)?  The answer is no.  In the same way that holding something you read is more satisfying than looking at it on screen, this book delivers. I read it the minute it arrived and I continue to be drawn back to it. I open it randomly, and am moved all over again by a stranger's baring of the soul.   <br /> <br />It is a powerful piece. Buy it for yourself.  And then buy it as a gift.

B000BUYP4Q|3.0|After years of not having a Batman film and mostly due to the franchise hitting bottom thanks to Joel Schumacher's disastrous \\"Batman forever\\" and \\"Batman and Robin\\", Christopher  Nolan present us his version of the character with an impressive all star cast anda story brilliantly written by David S. Goyer.<br /><br />The film<br /><br />There were  high expectations for this film before its release as if would it be as good as Burton's films, the truth is, there are no points to compare, Nolan and Burton visions are quite different from each other, but both respect the origins and essence of who the character is.<br /><br />Goyer took some liberties in the storytelling that could be considered as unforgivable by many fans (Bruce's parents are originally killed after seeing \\"Mark of Zorro\\" at the movie theater, a fact that marks Bruce's mind with the idea of a masked vigilante) but also hints at stuff that the previous versions let pass unnoticed, the main focus of this film are the origins of Batman and his training to become what he ultimately is. Even though the detective part of Bruce's training is not even mentioned, the twist in which Ra's Al Ghul (Liam Neeson) is the one who trained him in the ninja arts and theatricality just makes their conflict more delightful and interesting. Cameos and appearances of characters from the comic book are also well used, justified and important to the story (Carmine Falcone and killer Zsaz)<br /><br />The story uses the two villains exactly as they would act in the comic book, Ra's Al Ghul with his constant desire to set thing right his way and Jonathan Crane (Cillian Murphy) working and experimenting with the thing he enjoys the most: fear. Even though the Scarecrow is totally the opposite of the comic book (in the comic Jonathan Crane is an old and ugly doctor who was fired from Gotham University for experimenting on the students with his gas of fear), the character presented keeps the essence and motives that the original character has, unlike the Riddler, Mr Freeze, Two Face or Poison Ivy in Schumacher's awful versions.<br /><br />A new Gotham city is presented, much more like a NY city style, a new Batmobile (not as fancy as the previous ones but quite impressive) and a whole set of characters we expect to see in future releases, James Gordon (Gary Oldman who amazingly looks exactly as Jim in the comic), Alfred Pennyworth (Michael Caine), Lucius Fox (Morgan Freeman), Jonathan Crane, Carmine Falcone and Ra's Al Ghul.<br /><br />Masterfully executed by the whole cast and brilliantly directed by Nolan, there are many of us looking forward for a sequel to this film.<br /><br />The extras<br /><br />Disc one contains Mtv's \\"Tankman Begins\\", a spoof we could have lived without but without any doubt a collector's piece for all Mtv fans.<br /><br />Disc two contains a set of documentaries related to all aspects of production and shooting of the film, from the early beginnings in Nolan's washing room until the shooting of some of the most difficult sequences of the film. The disc 2 is organized in a comic book-like format which makes it a little difficult to follow as many things are like hidden, but if you go until the end of the short and pointless story, you will find a list with all documentaries available. One of the documentaries called \\"Genesis of the bat\\" presents comic book artist related to Batman talking about the character and film, from Dennis O'Neil to Jim Lee. I am sure this will be a piece fans of the comic book will enjoy. All extras are worthy of watching and I strongly recommend the 2 disc set, it is a 5 o 6 dollar difference that will compensate with all the facts and items found in the bonus materials.<br /><br />***BluRay review***<br /><br />I had already written a review for this film when the two-disc special edition was released on DVD, so I will not get into any details about how great the movie is.<br /><br />The treatment they gave to this release is incredible, image looks great and colors are stunning, the high definition definitely makes a difference and 'Batman Begins' looks better than ever (simply check out the ice sequence between Bruce and Ducard)<br /><br />I have seen threads with questions as to what exactly does the limited edition set contains versus the regular single disc, so here are what I think are the most important ones:<br /><br />The Disc<br /><br />The disc included here is the same disc they released separately:<br />* All the extras from the 2-disc DVD are included, the documentaries and the awful 'Tankman Begins'<br />* The prologue to 'The Dark Knight' in high definition (are we in for a treat when released on Bluray!) This is basically the bank robbery scene that opens the sequel.<br /><br />The Extras<br /><br />The USB with 18 the stills from 'The Dark Knight' included in the DVD version of the gift set IS NOT INCLUDED in the Bluray gift set; don't know what the reason is but it would have made sense to include it in both versions.<br /><br />The postcards included are selections from the art created to promote 'Batman Begins', in my opinion some of the images look simple and overall they are not that great.<br /><br />The two comic books included are a joke! One is a comic book adaptation of the same 6 minutes prologue included in this edition (the bank robbery), the other one is the script with pictures of the same 6 minute prologue! I am a collector and big fan of Batman and even I find this ridiculous and overpriced.<br /><br />The $7.50 coupon to see 'The Dark Knight' in theaters.<br /><br />Bottom-line, I would give 3 stars to the BluRay release, not to the movie itself (which is great and looks superb in HD) but to the release. I am having buyer's remorse, don't be fooled by what the product description says, it may sound interesting but had I known the extras would be as they are, I would have gone for the cheaper single disc edition.nd 'Batman Begins' looks better than ever (simply check out the ice sequence between Bruce and Ducard)    I have seen threads with questions as to what exactly does the limited edition set contains versus the regular single disc, so here are what I think are the most important ones:    The Disc    The disc included here is the same disc they released separately:  * All the extras from the 2-disc DVD are included, the documentaries and the awful 'Tankman Begins'  * The prologue to 'The Dark Knight' in high definition (are we in for a treat when released on Bluray!) This is basically the bank robbery scene that opens the sequel.    The Extras    The USB with 18 the stills from 'The Dark Knight' included in the DVD version of the gift set IS NOT INCLUDED in the Bluray gift set; don't know what the reason is but it would have made sense to include it in both versions.    The postcards included are selections from the art created to promote 'Batman Begins', in my opinion some of the images look simple and overall they are not that great.    The two comic books included are a joke! One is a comic book adaptation of the same 6 minutes prologue included in this edition (the bank robbery), the other one is the script with pictures of the same 6 minute prologue! I am a collector and big fan of Batman and even I find this ridiculous and overpriced.    The $7.50 coupon to see 'The Dark Knight' in theaters.    Bottom-line, I would give 3 stars to the BluRay release, not to the movie itself (which is great and looks superb in HD) but to the release. I am having buyer's remorse, don't be fooled by what the product description says, it may sound interesting but had I known the extras would be as they are, I would have gone for the cheaper single disc edition.

B00006SKW7|5.0|I had the good fortune to pick up a copy of this production from the UK, and I certainly hope it becomes available in the US for the sake of fans of Jacques Offenbach and Natalie Dessay. <br /> <br />For those not familiar with the story, it's a burlesque of the Orpheus & Eurydice legend--he's a skirt chasing narcissist, she's a slut, and the gods are even worse.  This is not Gounod or Massenet, but operetta at its best. <br /> <br />Even at this early point in her career, Natalie Dessay is the consummate singing actress, and she proves herself a deft comedienne, too.  Not belle but tres joli, this diva in the making is the best of an excellent French ensemble, and it's easy to believe that all the men want a piece of her. <br /> <br />This is truly an ensemble piece, and it's hard to single anyone out (bravi!).  The balance between singing and acting is nearly perfect, moving effortlessly from spoken dialogue to sparkling arias and some fine dance numbers; no single element overwhelms the others.  By sticking to the story, farce though it is, the production is an immensely funny piece of theatre.  The scathing social commentary (implied, not preached) is as current as it was 150 years ago.  A few other standouts: <br /> <br />Yann Beuron's Orpheus is marvelous.  Only in the first act is Orpheus a significant character and his duets with Eurydice and L'Opinion Publique are well choreographed and genuinely funny.  He actually manages to make the vain, jealous musician sympathetic.   <br /> <br />Laurent Naouri proves as deft a comic as his wife (Dessay), and with Jean-Paul Fouchecourt carries the action from the second scene onward.  The fly duet especially combines some virtuoso singing with a bawdy, comic love scene. <br /> <br />Among the minor gods, Etienne Lescroart's Mercury singing his aria in a chorus line with the dancers is a highlight, and Cassandre Berthon's Cupid is so charming that you forget she's singing a male role. <br /> <br />Is there anything wanting?  I didn't think so, but the performance was originally shot for television and seems a bit dark at times.  Some will be put off by the modern albeit somewhat surreal sets and costumes or the fact that all the dancers (men and women) wear female costumes.  That's their loss

I read in some of the other reviews that they didn't understand why monsters would just appear from out of no where. Well, in the FF world, the heros and the villians have the power to summon creatures whenever they want to. Thats why they just appeared......Buy this movie if your a fan, its really good.
0307276902|5.0|James Frey's memoir, A Million Little Pieces, tells the gripping story of a 23 year-old addict steps away from death who is checked into a treatment facility in Minnesota. Frey tells the story of experiences in rehab with such brutal honesty that at some points it is painful for the reader. He forces the reader to get inside of his drug-damaged head when he describes mad hallucinations that haunted him when he first checked in. He describes one in gruesome detail, \\"The bugs crawl onto my skin and they start biting me and I try to kill them. I claw at my skin, tear at my hair, start biting myself. I don't have any teeth  and I'm biting myself and there are shadows and bright lights and flashes and screams and bugs bugs bugs. I am lost.\\" With remarkable honesty, Frey leaves nothing out. He recounts dreams of downing bottles of booze, smoking lethal amounts of crack, sniffing industrial glue and cans of gasoline, all ending with murderous rage and suicidal thoughts. He shares his true feelings towards his parents, the \\"Fury\\" that rises inside of him at the thought of being near them. He doesn't lie about attending the daily lectures and never listening to them. Frey thinks that they're pointless and he is not afraid to share that opinion. Nothing in this memoir is censored. <br />I found that not only what Frey described was powerful and intense, but also how he described it. Short, choppy sentences mixed in with long, detailed ones constructed with little regard for correct punctuation made the descriptions seem as if they were still racing through Frey's head. Because of lack of punctuation, there can often be some confusion distinguishing between Frey's internal thoughts and spoken dialogue, but that has a minimal effect on the story as a whole. <br />Overall, this book is a page-turner; there is no downtime between scenes. Frey tells the story of his road to recovery with such unimaginable honesty, it may blow some readers away. <br />

1590581814|2.0|Lots of people have been raving about this book; I read it, and I have to say I don't see what they love so much about it.  The writing is distracting -- though Sallis dedicates the book to Ed McBain, Donald Westlake, and Lawrence Block, what those three men have that Sallis does not is the ability to write with enormous clarity.  Their prose is irresistible in part because it's transparent -- it never needlessly calls attention to itself.  Sallis' prose, by contrast, seems always to be jumping up and down saying, \\"Look at me!  Aren't I precious?\\"  Apart from being pretentious and distancing the reader from the events of the story, it doesn't fit the characters -- Driver would not know the word \\"demotic\\" any more than he knew \\"desuetude.\\"  And while I love Borges, it's not the case that every book is better if its characters make some reference to him -- whenever I see a writer namecheck Borges, I want to reenact the scene from \\"Annie Hall\\" where an exasperated Woody Allen silences a blowhard by forcing him to face the person about whose work he is pontificating... <br /> <br />My reaction appears to be atypical, so readers of this review should take it with a grain of salt -- but I feel someone has to call \\"Emperor's New Clothes\\" on this one...
B00000634J|5.0|John Lennon was the founder of the greatest pop/rock group that ever walked the earth, The Beatles. He was also a genuine personality with a charisma that was irresistable, a wit that was heartfelt, and an outspoken nature that influenced a generation. Lennon's music is the main topic on Lennon Legend, but one cannot mention Lennon's songs without bringing up all of the above.     Songs like Imagine, Power To The People, Mind Games, and the powerful handraiser Instant Karma! are just a few of Lennon the revolutionary's signature songs that called for the rights and unity of the common man. Mother, Cold Turkey, and Jealous Guy, on the other hand, reveal Lennon the man and his vulnerability, the songs deal with his inner pains of losing his mother, kicking the habit, and hurting the ones he loved. Then, there's the side of Lennon the lover and his devotion to Yoko with songs like the mesmerizing Woman, which stands as one of the best love songs ever written, No.9 Dream, and the Ben E King cover of Stand By Me from his 1975 covers album Rock N Roll.     The album also includes the Dylanesque Working Class Hero, the epical Happy Xmas (War Is Over), the sweet lullaby Beautiful Boy (written for young Sean Lennon), and the posthumous Nobody Told Me (the best social commentary song of the early 1980's).    With the compilation released and many others before and after, Lennon's legend has and always will carry on.    Recommended    A

B00005JOGU|5.0|MOVIE: The film's opening scene is Truman Capote at a party, and he is standing with a drink in his hand while telling a story. Everyone standing around him is laughing and he is there almost performing a show for them. Here is where we have a first glimpse of the eccentric character of Truman Capote. Capote (pronounced 'cah-poh-tee') is brilliant film that takes an inside look at two different men. Here we have Truman Capote (Phillip Seymore Hoffman) who is a man who is absolutly full of himself. He loves to hear himself talk, and he loves it when people compliment his writing. Why shouldn't he love it, his work is incredibly brilliant. He is searchinh for the topic of his next article, and he picks a murder that happened in rural Kansas. Four people were murdered when two men broke and entered their homes. Truman travels by train to the small town along with Harper Lee (Catherine Keener) to interview people who were assosiated with the murder. The two brothers accused of the murders are put to death, and Truman befriends one of them. He visits him in his cell and talks with him about who he is as a person. Capote decides that he wants to write a book instead of an article when he sees how interesting his subject is. They share stories about their pasts and how both of them seem to be outcasts of society. However, this is where the murderer, Perry Smith, actually finds a friend in Truman. Truman on the other hand is only after information that will make is book a masterpiece. As time goes by Truman starts to find decency within this man, and actually tries to fight for him so that his death sentence is appealed. After three years Truman's book is almost finished, but he still has no idea why the murders happened. When he finally probes the information out of Perry a whole new side of this man is revealed. The film is psychologically haunting. We have Truman Capote, a very eccentric yet brilliant homosexual writer. We also have Perry Smith, the murderer who seems to be a decent person and claims that they never meant to kill that family. The film digs deep on Truman's character, and just enough for Perry's. When the end comes and we learn the truth about the murders, we see a change in both characters. The film also boasts some very subtle yet amazing cinematography. Almost every shot is framed through a window or a doorway. In the jail we have some shots framed through the bars. The film also has some amazing lighting, and the lighting on the faces is another subtlety to notice. The haunting score by Mychael Danna is amazing. The score is nothing more than simple notes on the piano, very similar to Newman's score for Road To Perdition. The film is a deep and dark look into the human mind, and human emotion. I have read some reviews that suggest that there may have been a sexual attraction between Capote and Smith, but I did not see that at all. I felt it was just an interest in a person who is deemed a monster yet is a very poignant person. The film was brilliant and haunting, and is worth your while.<br /><br />ACTING: Phillip Seymore Hoffman gives a tour de force performance of Truman Capote. Not only did he capture the pompous nature of the writer, but he captured the emotion within him as a human being. Clifton Collins Jr. gives an amazing performance as the very ambiguous Perry Smith. The two actors also play off each other very well, their acting envelopes the audience into the atmosphere of the film and makes their conversations all the more emotional. Both actors are worthy of nominations, and Hoffman may have given a performance that translates into Oscar.<br /><br />BOTTOM LINE: While some people may find the first quarter of the film slow, it picks up and ends up being one of those movies that stays with you long after you see it. The performances are stellar, and they add to the film's effect on the audience. Bennet Miller's direction is on the mark as he spends the right amount of time with each character, and hesets up the third act of the film perfectlyd he sets up the third act of the film perfectly
