B0001XAPY2|5.0|One of director Hayao Miyazaki's (\\"Spirited Away\\", \\"Princess Mononoke\\") earlier works is a film called \\"Porco Rosso\\".  \\"Porco Rosso\\", like his other films, is an animated movie and this one features a pig as an ace pilot and bounty hunter.  But before we think this movie is going to veer into the territory of Looney Tunes, Porco is the only character in the movie who is not human and we learn later midway through the movie that he used to be human but seems to be cursed in some way.  The rest of the film is grounded a sense of reality, though a slightly skewed reality.<br /><br />Porco (voiced by an unrecognizable Michael Keaton) is a sea-plane pilot and a bounty hunter.  He works for money and usually to protect others (still for pay, not out of any generosity of spirit as he claims he has none).  Early in the film we see Porco foil a kidnapping by a bumbling sea-plane pirate gang, and the pirate leaders from the region are out to put a stop to Porco's success against them.  They bring in this American pilot (voiced by Cary Elwes), one of the fastest in the world.  The American's job is to make Porco look silly and to put him out of a job, if not kill Porco.<br /><br />\\"Porco Rosso's\\" storyline does not progress the way I would have expected.  Even though the film clocks in at 90 minutes, \\"Porco Rosso\\" has a leisurely pace that feels as if Miyazaki knows exactly where he is going and is in no hurry to get there.  I was surprised by just how much humor there is in the movie.  The pirates bungle and bumble quite often, but they also drop these throw away lines that are simply funny, but only when you're watching the movie.  Trying to list a series of these lines wouldn't be funny when one line that made me laugh was simply \\"okay\\", but it was when and how it was said that made the joke.  The other thing about this movie was that I was interested in what happens to Porco, and what did happen to Porco, and what will happen.  I cared about the character and also in his Engineer friend and the friend's granddaughter (voiced by Kimberly Williams) who is just as good of an engineer as any and a very important character.<br /><br />Simply put, the movie worked.  On all levels.  Animation gives the false impression that it is automatically for children, and children can and would enjoy \\"Porco Rosso\\", but Miyazaki's films work for adults as well.  This is just a good movie.  Period.  It joins \\"Princess Mononoke\\" and \\"Kiki's Delivery Service\\" as my favorites Miyazaki movies and is one I happily recommend.<br /><br />-Joe Sherryin his Engineer friend and the friend's granddaughter (voiced by Kimberly Williams) who is just as good of an engineer as any and a very important character.   <br /> <br />Simply put, the movie worked. B00004TWZF|5.0|Luc Besson is the most surprising person in the cinema industry. He is able to transform any banal, ordinary, simple, even superficial story into the deepest mirror of human fate. Here he deals with the sea, this mother of us all. A young boy loses his father who dies when diving for a living, to exploit the natural fauna of the deep sea. The angry mother the sea took the father away since the mother of that child was no longer here. The sea provides him with a new surrogate father : the world champion in deep diving. This new father is going to guide him onto a way that leads ever deeper and ever longer under the water. These scenes are fascinating because they are short and they stir in our minds all kinds of fear, fright and fantasm. But this fate that calls him to the sea becomes a dilemma because the sea provides him with a new family of dolphins, with their language, their playing games, their grace and beauty, their call for the deep, for joining the sea and merging into it. What happens when a girl comes into the picture and reveals to Jacques his male genetic fertility ? That's the drama. The angry mother the sea strikes again and takes the surrogate father away in a crazy challenge to go too deep and die there. Then the call of this angry mother is too strong. Then the call to go back to the cocoon of the ftus is too strong. Luc Besson reaches here in simple images and poignant scenes the mythic level and we can hear in the back of our cultures all these episodes about the survival of humanity after the big flood, Noah is here with his Ark, Moses with his crossing of the Red Sea, but also all the other myths from all over the world that have to do with this sudden unexplained rise of the ocean level. And then Luc Besson produces a cult film that will probably never die and is as universal as Oedipus.<br /><br />Dr Jacques COULARDEAU, Universit&eacute; Paris Dauphine, Universit&eacute; Paris I Panth&eacute;on Sorbonne

B000002MUW|3.0|Madonna's 'Bedtime Stories' is quite a departure from 1992's 'Erotica' which to some, tried too hard to be provocative. At the time, Madonna had alienated some of her audience with her various career choices, all of which seemed to be sexual in some type of way. Whatever Madonna's motives,the world had seemed to get over the frenzy and warm up to her once again, this time on 1994's 'Bedtime Story'. It's an album that doesn't go out of it's way to be soft and sensual; it just is. Much of it is about falling in and out of love, some of it is about responding to her critics. On \\"Human Nature\\", the only song that could be deemed \\"explicit\\", she sings \\"OOps I didn't know I couldn't talk about sex\\", with a razor sharped tongue that declares that she does not regret her very public sexual revolution. This track is a bigger vixen than \\"Erotica\\", and yet not as naughty as \\"Justify my Love\\". One theme on the album that is very indirect is transvestitism, on the hit first single \\"Secret\\". I have said before Madonna has a problem with lyrics and most would be surprised this is even about this social issue. It is. The song is so good though you have to forgive her subliminal message. For an artist that is so out there with her daring self expression, she surprisingly can hold a lot back. Maybe that's the point; it's one secret we weren't supposed to find out about. The rest of the album is a big soft cushion, made for late night listening. From the haunting \\"Sanctuary\\", which samples Herbie Hancock to the Bjork-penned and produced \\"Bedtime Story\\" to the oh-so-sweet hit single \\"Take a Bow\\", few can argue that 'Bedtime Stories' is a bad dream. While afterwards she had to prove that she hadn't gone adult contemporary, it was a nice transition from all the hoopla surrounding the 'Sex' period. One warning: if you came to dance, you may be dissapointed. If you came to veg out, sit back and enjoy.

Starting with Mary Alice's suicide, it propelled a mystery that spanned the whole season and encompassed the whole cast. Teri Hatcher plays the unlucky in love heroine Susan, who has a daughter Julie from her previous marriage to Karl. Felicity Huffman plays Lynette, mother of four, who struggles with raising her kids. Eva Longoria plays Gabrielle, a rich socialite who is spoiled and married to her husband Carlos, but also having an affair with her gardener John. Marcia Cross plays Bree, the perfect housewife who has to deal with her rebelious son and cheating husband. Nicolette Sheridan plays Edie, the sexy temptress who is fighting with Susan for Mike's affections. The show is well balanced with mystery, comedy, suspense, and drama. Must see TV!

B0006GAOBI|5.0|The first time I saw Donnie Darko almost 3 years ago, I, like a lot of other people, understand very little about what I had just watched. However despite that fact, I was intrigued and extremely drawn to this movie, even though I didn't quite understand what had just happened. Upon multiple viewings of the movie I have more or less come to my own conclusion or meaning about the plot, which like everyone says, will give you something new every time you watch it. That's the beauty of this film, because no two people are going to come to the same conclusion on what the movie is about. With brilliant direction (kudos Richard Kelly), an excellent (an extremely underrated I might add) cast of characters, and a confusing, yet beautiful story, \\"Donnie Darko\\" is not just another cult film. This is a movie that is timeless.    There are very, very few movies that have been able to capture my attention the way Donnie Darko has, and even fewer have prompted me to view the movie multiple times to actually find more and more out about it. However Donnie Darko is one of those films that the first time through, you may not necessarily understand what is going on. To briefly summarize the plot, Donnie (Jake Gyllenhaal who gives a phenominal performance) is teenager who has had frequent psychological problems in his life recently, and feels alienated from his family and friends. One night Donnie is awakened by Frank, a 6 foot tall bunny rabbit, who instructs Donnie to follow him. Donnie does, and this ends up saving Donnie's life as a jet engine crashes through his roof that night. Frank informs Donnie that the world is going to end in 28 days, 6 hours, 42 Minutes and 12 seconds. Donnie then feels like he must obey Frank who makes him do many questionable things, because Frank saved his life. This includes flooding his local high school and burning down the house of a perverted self help guru. Not only that but it appears that Donnie is slipping in and out of multiple realities, leaving you wondering what are hallucinations, and what is really happening. This ultimately leads Donnie into the research of time travel and tangent universes, which becomes one of the most important aspects of the movie. That should give you a basic idea what the movie focuses around. While this might not sound like the most award winning premise, Kelly definitely turns this into one of the must see movies of our generation.    There are so many themes and underlying messages running throughout this film, and only upon multiple viewings will you truly discover them all. Like I said one of the best things about this film is that everyone is going to draw something different from it. However Kelly has deliberately made the Donnie character one that everyone can relate to. I can honestly say as a teenager I felt almost exactly like Donnie does in the film, and that makes relating to this movie on different levels so easy. There's also a sense that this alienated teenager is in the end the real hero, despite being looked down upon by his peers and his community. The love story between Donnie and Gretchen is exactly what you would expect it to be like between two teenagers who don't necessarily understand what they are feeling at the time. Part of the charm of this movie is its overwhelming honesty and portrayal of things as they are in real life, not glamoured up for hollywood.    Whatever Kelly's intention was when he wrote the movie (which to this day has never been clearly explained), he has made a movie that has touched and connected with a broad audience of people worldwide. It is safe to say that \\"Donnie Darko\\" isn't just a cult film now, it's a worldwide phenomenon. I promise you will never think about things the same way as you do after viewing this film. I strongly encourage you to see this movie. It is definitely something that will stand out from anything you've ever seen. I still don't feel like I have done this movie justice with my review, but I don't really think any review is capable of doing that. To put it simply, you must see this movie. \\"And when the world comes to an end, I can breathe a sigh of relief, because I know I have so much to look forward to....\\"

0451169514|5.0|I am rather new to reading Stephen King novels, but so far this one has to be my favorite. The book has a little bit of everything and the final product is one of the best novels ever written. King is very descriptive in this novel. You can't help but fall in love with the characters Bill, Ben, Beverly, Stan, Richie, Mike and Eddie because King goes into such depth in developing their characters that you feel like you actually know them. You actually begin to feel as though you are in Derry, Maine with these 7 kids as they battle this evil. While the book is long...it goes very quick, and when it's done you will miss it. I don't want to give away too much info but I will leave it at this. If you want a novel that is filled with great character development and a deep and involving plot, pick this book up and you will be happy you did.
0393317552|5.0|Why humans developed differently? Why Europe, not China, has more wealth? Why whites, not blacks, dominate the modern world? To answer those perennials questions, Diamond searched our 13,000 years history. He found clues in food production, domesticated animals, disease dispersal, migration trends, and language history. He concluded the primary reason for human inequality is the environment, not innate differences in people.<br /><br />Diamond presents broad historical patterns. He starts with farmer power, how more wild plants and animals available for domestication allowed a more dense population, and how the spread of innovative techniques was uneven as movement across continents was easier East-West than North-South. More agriculture allowed denser populations. And more people lead to diseases (and immunization), technology (weapons and writing), and centralized decision-making (religions and governments).<br /><br />Criticism of Diamond's theory revolves around the human factor. But the pundits ignore the subtleties of his theory: interaction with the environment, not geography or biology alone, is responsible for human development. It stems from the conjectures that knowledge is cumulative and complexity creates innovation. Brushing across history and science, Diamond suggests that different environments caused the diversity of human progress and that the past serves as a guide to the future.
1594200696|5.0|Reviewed by Joanna Pearson for Small Spiral Notebook<br /><br />In ninth-grade English, I was introduced to The Elements of Style by William Strunk and E.B. White. Needless to say, this was a while ago, and I've both read and written a few things since then. Nonetheless, just weeks ago I managed to turn in a poem to my writing workshop containing the line, \\"He lifts the ringing culprit in his fingers.\\" My instructor looked at me askance before asking why I hadn't simply written, \\"He answers his cell phone.\\" Oh....Yeah. Clearly for some of us, the reissue of Elements, newly illustrated by Maira Kalman, has come not a moment too soon. Kalman's strange, gorgeous paintings are a treat that will charm readers into rediscovering a book that is as fresh, relevant, and funny as it was back in its first edition.<br /><br />The Elements of Style has always been the original in the way of tart, pithy guides to writing and grammar. Long before Lynne Truss delighted readers with her curmudgeonry in Eats, Shoots & Leaves, there was old Strunk- railing against words like \\"beauteous\\" and \\"utilize,\\" offering such sage advice like \\"Avoid fancy words.\\" By adding her quirky pictures, Kalman is both paying homage to a classic and inviting new readers to discover it. Elements is now a two-fold experience; visual and literary.<br /><br />One has to imagine Kalman as one of those geniuses who lose themselves every morning over their breakfast cereal, constantly struck by ideas-\\"I know, I'll paint about sentence structure! Illustrate a grammar book!\\"-that would sound ridiculous to the rest of us, and yet turn out to be brilliant. In addition to devising this new illustrated Elements, Kalman also commissioned Nico Muhly to compose an opera. Performed recently at the New York Public Library, it was by all accounts crazy yet wonderful, complete with Kalman's friend Isaac Mizrahi playing an eggbeater. We non-geniuses, on the other hand, have probably not considered the idea of singing about words and sentences since the last time we watched Sesame Street.<br /><br />Kalman's ideas work. The new book is a slim, appealing red volume. Gone is the fusty plainness of the ninth-grade classroom. This book is classy. The inside front cover says \\"hello,\\" and the inside back cover says \\"goodbye\\" in tiny cursive script like elegant hostess cards. Almost every other page is illustrated, and the illustrations range from Kalman's interpretation of \\"overly, muchly, thusly\\" (a top-heavy ship-on-land structure) to \\"Chloe smells good, as a baby should\\" (the huge gurgling face of red-headed baby Chloe.) All the pictures are bright, and many of them demonstrate a deliberate absence of compositional depth that seems to be one of Kalman's trademarks. As such, the odd tangle of characters she paints in an illustration like hers for \\"None of us is perfect,\\" seem ready to tumble on top of each other or out of the page. Some of the paintings like \\"What a wonderful show!\\" to me resemble the flurried, brilliant compositions of the painter discovered in the lunatic asylum. Kalman's bright oddness, her weird lines of perspective, have something off-kilter to them, something more often found in outsider-art.<br /><br />If Kalman had illustrated the phonebook instead, it would be worth reading just for the sake of seeing her pictures. In this case, however, in addition to Kalman's illustrations, one has the barbed imperatives of good old Strunk and White to look forward to, like :<br /><br />Nauseous. Nauseated. The first means \\"sickening to contemplate\\"; the second means \\"sick at the stomach.\\" Do not, therefore, say, \\"I feel nauseous,\\" unless you are sure you have that effect on others.<br /><br />and:<br /><br />Muddiness is not merely a disturber of prose, it is also a destroyer of life, of hope: death on the highway caused by a badly worded road sign, heartbreak among lovers caused by a misplaced phrase in a well-intentioned letter, anguish of a traveler expecting to be met at a railroad station and not being met because of a slipshod telegram. Think of the tragedies that are rooted in ambiguity, and be clear! When you say something, make sure you have said it. The chances of your having said it are only fair.<br /><br />It is both his grumpiness in misuse and the genuine joy in clarity that make Strunk a wonderful guide. Strunk saw bad writing as insidious and disruptive, an ever-present trap into which it was easy to slip. Similarly, his view of the precarious position of the reader is observed by White in his introduction:<br /><br />All through The Elements of Style one finds evidences of the author's deep sympathy for the reader. Will [Strunk] felt that the reader was in serious trouble most of the time, floundering in a swamp, and that it was the duty of anyone attempting to write English to drain this swamp quickly and get the reader up on dry ground, or at least throw a rope.<br /><br />All in all, the illustrated Elements of Style is well worth the reader's time-a sturdy rope with which to rescue anyone stranded in a morass of unclear language, whether your own or someone else's. Kalman's bright, dreamy images are persuasive in their own right too. And even if you've never mixed up \\"which\\" and \\"that,\\" misplaced a single comma, nor composed an overwrought line, you should still pick up what remains one of the funniest books on writing ever written.ting to be met at a railroad station and not being met because of a slipshod telegram. Think of the tragedies that are rooted in ambiguity, and be clear! When you say something, make sure you have said it. The chances of your having said it are only fair. <br /> <br />It is both his grumpiness in misuse and the genuine joy in clarity that make Strunk a wonderful guide. Strunk saw bad writing as insidious and disruptive, an ever-present trap into which it was easy to slip. Similarly, his view of the precarious position of the reader is observed by White in his introduction:  <br /> <br />All through The Elements of Style one finds evidences of the author's deep sympathy for the reader. Will [Strunk] felt that the reader was in serious trouble most of the time, floundering in a swamp, and that it was the duty of anyone attempting to write English to drain this swamp quickly and get the reader up on dry ground, or at least throw a rope.  <br /> <br />All in all, the illustrated Elements of Style is well worth the reader's time-a sturdy rope with which to rescue anyone stranded in a morass of unclear language, whether your own or someone else's. Kalman's bright, dreamy images are persuasive in their own right too. And even if you've never mixed up \\"which\\" and \\"that,\\" misplaced a single comma, nor composed an overwrought line, you should still pick up what remains one of the funniest books on writing ever written.  <br />

0671027344|3.0|More like a 3.5, but Amazon doesn't give half stars.    When The Perks of Being a Wallflower first came out, even the most dedicated pop culture ostriches had trouble avoiding it.  Chbosky became a folk hero for the awkward, bookish high-school (or, more often, college) student with a penchant for self-doubt.    Perks does, to some degree, live up to the hype, and I can see why so many college-age men and women have fallen in love with it, but it is not the end-all-be-all of wallflower lit. Perks is a story about Charlie, a high school freshman who is very genuine and very honest, and also very passive. Although it seems to be the general consensus among contemporary fiction writers that \\"wallflowers\\" have a simple (not to be mistaken wtih simplistic) way of looking at the world, and Perks is in some ways a very simple book (it's a collection of letters from Charlie to an anonymous \\"friend\\"), it is nevertheless very touching and hints at a number of important issues facing contemporary (read: 1990s, when the book was written) youths and their parents.    Nevertheless, I find its stylistic premise unrealistic. I don't think that someone like Charlie would write letters to a stranger, because someone like Charlie would be paralyzed by the idea that he might be burdening that stranger. Likewise, by placing us fictively in the position of the anonymous \\"friend,\\" Chbosky makes it impossible for us to experience Charlie's world the way that friend would. Because we are informed and recognize from the start that this is to be a book written as letters, and we are to receive them, we are rendered incapable of receiving Charlie's letters. Rather than confidantes, we are voyeurs, and this is the source of our sympathy for Charlie and our delight in his universe.    Further, Chbosky's psychological meanderings in Perks are more than a bit reductionist.  Charlie's entire elaborate persona is dissolved into a single incident involving two people.  Charlie's self-discovery effectively ends this novel, rather than causing him to further explore his own depths.    If participation is key, Perks succeeds admirably.  The reader is drawn in to Charlie's confidence and Chbosky's writing.  I found the book a quick read and an enjoyable one, but surprisingly unchallenging.  Chbosky's approach barely qualifies as a critical one.    Read Perks, but \\"be a filter, not a sponge.\\"  It is limited by the age of its main character.  A more mature take on wallflower life is Steve Martin's Shopgirl.

B000B8QEZG|3.0|I have to weigh in on this ridiculousness that certain reviewers are laying against this CD.  There are several reviews in question do nothing to provide the person reading the review with any insightful knowledge into the product.<br /><br />With that said, This album is a good effort from Madonna. Not Great or Oustanding, but not Poor either.<br /><br />This album is all dance-themed songs.  Madonna wrote and produced all the tracks and experiments with different sounds, samples, licks and beats throughout the album.<br /><br />As with almost all of Madonna's albums since her first 2, her best work, in my opinion, comes in when the remixes of the original songs from her albums hit the dance club circuit.  The remixes of Madonna's songs have always done well in this genre.  Take for instance her Bedtime Story album...Many people felt that Bedtime Story was a weak album for Madonna... until the remixes came out.  I would say the same is true for Confessions of A Dance Floor to a certain extent.  I think the remixes will help support the album.<br /><br />The album does seem to get a little monotone, but I think that's because the beats per minute/tempo of these songs are pretty close to each other for almost all of the album.  Also, the songs do not have definitive beginnings and endings, they blend into each other.  From what Madonna has said about the album, this was intentional to give a consitent vibe to the listener.<br /><br />The material on the album has a decidedly European dance sound.  This is not House, Hip-hop, R&B or Pop by any stretch of the imagination.  Yes, the current single,Hung up,has some Pop radio appeal, but many of the other songs would seem to be geared to being played in discotheques/clubs.<br /><br />With all of that said, this album is certainly not going to compete with an album like Emancipation of Mimi, nor is it meant to in my opinion.  The material on the album is in a completely different genre than Emancipation of Mimi and as such, there really is no comparison between the two, other than the fact that this album and Emancipation of Mimi have been released within a relatively close time frame.  I'm sure this was done to take advantage of the upcoming holiday season and was not planned in any way to compete for the #1 selling album or chart position.<br /><br />Hopefully, this review helps provide some value.  The album is not her best work, it's not her worst work.  The forthcoming remixes will probably be great and if you're into the European dance sound, you'll like this album.mi and as such, there really is no comparison between the two, other than the fact that this album and Emancipation of Mimi have been released within a relatively close time frame. The album is not her best work, it's not her worst work.  The forthcoming remixes will probably be great and if you're into the European dance sound, you'll like this album. <br />
B0002Z0EYK|5.0|If Homer's mythical epic \\"The Iliad\\" is based on a factual story, that story is magnificently depicted in Wolfgang Petersen's 2004 epic film \\"Troy.\\" In other words, don't expect any goofy 'gods' or 'goddesses' like Athena popping out of thin air because \\"Troy\\" is an ultra-realistic and serious portrayal of the Trojan war.<br /><br />More than that, \\"Troy\\" is without a doubt the BEST sword & sandal epic ever put to film. You name the picture -- \\"Samson and Delilah,\\" \\"Spartacus,\\" \\"Ben-Hur,\\" \\"Ulysses,\\" \\"The Viking Queen,\\" \\"Braveheart,\\" \\"Attila,\\" \\"The Odyssey,\\" \\"Gladiator,\\" etc. -- \\"Troy\\" is BETTER. Okay, maybe I'm getting a bit carried away here because I just viewed \\"Troy\\" and it blew me away, but \\"Troy\\" is at least AS GOOD as some of the better flicks just mentioned, like \\"Ben-Hur,\\" and far edges out \\"Spartacus\\" and \\"Samson and Delilah.\\" As for more recent sword & sandal epics like the overrated \\"Braveheart\\" or \\"Gladiator,\\" \\"Troy\\" utterly blows 'em out of the water -- no lie!<br /><br />Roger Ebert is a great writer and critic, but his mediocre review of \\"Troy\\" is all wrong. Ebert's major criticisms, believe it or not, are the main reasons I have such high respect for this film -- He complains that Petersen omitted the many Greek 'gods' & 'goddesses' and gripes that the actors perform their roles as believable people and not larger-than-life caricatures. This can, of course, be respectably done, as in the 1955 film \\"Ulysses,\\" but this is not what Petersen was shooting for in \\"Troy.\\" His goal, as already noted, was to depict the ACTUAL Trojan war that Homer's myth is based on (and even if it never really took place, wars LIKE IT did).<br /><br />Regarding Brad Pitt's heavily criticized performance as Achilles, I'm not a major Brad Pitt fan -- I neither love him or hate him -- but I think he does an outstanding and believable job portraying Greece's greatest warrior. No he's not the bulkiest warrior to ever grace the earth, but he's fast as lightning, confident, expertly skilled and deadly accurate. Even his voice completely fits the role. Eric Bana (from \\"Hulk\\") is also great as Hector, Achilles' Trojan counterpart, who's sick of war and just wants to live a life of peace with his family. These two have a showdown in the film and it is without a doubt the greatest man-to-man sword & sandal fight ever filmed -- really!<br /><br />What's interesting about the picture is that you never really end up rooting for one side or the other. When Achilles and Hector have their powerful showdown, my wife and I couldn't decide who to root for. Maybe that's the point. Don't get me wrong here, Agamemnon could probably be viewed as the villain in this picture, and I wasn't rooting for Menelaus when he fights Paris (Orlando Bloom, who seduces Helen, Menelaus' wife), but neither the Greeks or the Trojans are painted as the 'good guys' or 'bad guys.' They're just people at war, and in war there's no real glory, as Hector points out,... and it never ends,  as Achilles states. An additional point of the film is that living in a state of war is a JOYLESS existence. And both Bana and Pitt get this across well.<br /><br />As for beautiful women, there are only a couple mentionables: Diane Kruger plays Helen, \\"the face that launched a thousand ships.\\" Some have complained that she's too plain for the role, but I disagree. Not that I think she's some ultra-ravishing beauty (although she does have a supremely impressive rear-end shot), but she's certainly not plain looking; and, besides, beauty is in the eyes of the beholder -- if Paris deems her worthy of starting a war, who are we to disagree? Also on hand is cutie Rose Byrne who plays Briseis, the virgin priestess whom Achilles converts to the pleasures of the flesh.<br /><br />I should point out that \\"Troy\\" is one of the most expensive pictures ever made, close to 200 million dollars, and it definitely SHOWS on the screen. Make no mistake, \\"Troy\\" is breath-taking just to WATCH -- the colossal armies,ships and battles are awe-inspiring to behold, not to mention the Maltan and Mexican locations. And the CGI effects are outstanding, not fake-looking like the Rome and Coliseum scenes in \\"Gladiator.\\"<br /><br />Another complaint by Ebert is that the dialogue is lousy; nothing could be further from the truth. There are great pieces of dialogue interspersed throughout the flick, including Achilles' comment that the 'gods' envy people because we're mortal and \\"Everything's beautiful because we're doomed.\\" So don't worry, there's thankfully not one 'humorous,' goofy one-liner anywhere to be found.<br /><br />James Horner's score should also be mentioned. If you enjoyed the soundtrack for \\"The Passion of the Christ\\" you'll love this one because it's just as good/serious/appropriate/powerful. For instance, the intense percussion during Achilles and Hector's showdown is magnificent.<br /><br />INTERESTING NOTE: Brad Pitt, who plays Achilles, injured his Achilles tendon while making the film. Fitting, no?<br /><br />FINAL WORD: If you're into sword & sandal epics, \\"Troy\\" will BLOW YOU AWAY. The story captivates you right from the very beginning and never lets up the entire 2.5 hour running time. Beyond this \\"Troy\\" extravagantly visualizes the Trojan war for you, something I never did until seeing this mind-blowing, outstanding piece of cinema.<br /><br />Keep in mind that those who give \\"Troy\\" a poor rating are the same losers who think \\"Jackass -- the Movie\\" is a great film.behold, not to mention the Maltan and Mexican locations. And the CGI effects are outstanding, not fake-looking like the Rome and Coliseum scenes in \\"Gladiator.\\"     Another complaint by Ebert is that the dialogue is lousy; nothing could be further from the truth. There are great pieces of dialogue interspersed throughout the flick, including Achilles' comment that the 'gods' envy people because we're mortal and \\"Everything's beautiful because we're doomed.\\" So don't worry, there's thankfully not one 'humorous,' goofy one-liner anywhere to be found.     James Horner's score should also be mentioned. If you enjoyed the soundtrack for \\"The Passion of the Christ\\" you'll love this one because it's just as good/serious/appropriate/powerful. For instance, the intense percussion during Achilles and Hector's showdown is magnificent.       INTERESTING NOTE: Brad Pitt, who plays Achilles, injured his Achilles tendon while making the film. Fitting, no?    FINAL WORD: If you're into sword & sandal epics, \\"Troy\\" will BLOW YOU AWAY. The story captivates you right from the very beginning and never lets up the entire 2.5 hour running time. Beyond this \\"Troy\\" extravagantly visualizes the Trojan war for you, something I never did until seeing this mind-blowing, outstanding piece of cinema.    Keep in mind that those who give \\"Troy\\" a poor rating are the same losers who think \\"Jackass -- the Movie\\" is a great film.
0201633612|5.0|A sad note on a tremendous talent who helped change the world of software engineering for the better. John Vlissides passed away on Nov 24. 2005 after a long battle with cancer.    Design Patterns is one of the few software design methodologies that I've found useful over the years. Thanks John you will be missed.

B0000DD7LB|4.0|2003's \\"In The Zone\\" is Britney's Fourth studio release, and it is pretty damn good. I personally preferred 2001's \\"Britney\\" but this one is not too bad, and rather impressive.  A collaberation with her idol, four singles, two #1's, and a grammy (for best dance record - \\"Toxic\\") followed, so the results speak for themselves. Even people who were never fans of Britney before said they enjoyed this album purely for the music. Britney also helped co - write Eight of the albums Twelve tracks.  Whereas 2001's \\"Britney\\" showed the beginning of an edgier sound you could call \\"In The Zone\\" the full evolution of that, or a carry-on from \\"Britney\\". The album is very remixed and club ready, so it makes for an enjoyable new ride, and overall turns out to be a great album...If you're a fan of music this album should NOT dissapoint and is a must have for Britney fans.  Below is the Track by Track review.  1. Me Against The Music - Featuring Madonna.  The First single from \\"In The Zone\\". When I first heard this song I didn't really like it, but I was aware it would be a massive hit for Britney. The song seems very club ready and  anyone who likes to go out clubbing should like this song. It is unlike anything she's done before.  It grew on me and i started to enjoy it. 4/5  2. (I Got That) Boom, Boom. - Featuring Ying Yang Twins.  This song is O.K. It is very Bump 'N' Grind, it is very sexual with sexy lyrics and a new sound. Sexy vocals on this track too. She sings it very well, and alluringly. 3/5  3. Showdown.  This song is nothing special. I feel it was too short, and very sexual - nothing wrong with that. It mostly seems like filler and is instantly forgotten when over, but worth a listen or two. 3/5  4. Breath On Me.  I love this song. It is very sexy sounding with heavy breathing and panting and anyone who likes going out clubbing will enjoy this track. This track sounds very commercialised and You can imagine it coming out of a advert for a fragrence of some kind.  Britney's vocals are sexy, and so are the lyrics. \\"Mahogomy is the way to go. Just put your lips together, and blow\\" 4/5  5. Early Mornin'.  This is a rather good track. It was written with Moby, and talks about a girls night out. It sounds very new - wave and fits in well with the album. Good club track. However the \\"Jason Nevis Remix\\" on \\"B In The Mix\\" is much better. 3/5  6. Toxic.  Everyone knows this one. This is the second single from the album, and it's first number one. I bought the album after the first single was released, and when listening to this one i thought nothing special of it.I thought it was just filler, But Boy was i wrong. This has to be one of Britney's biggest hits since \\"...Baby, One More Time\\" The video helped promote this song, and once i realised it was single material it grew on me. 4/5  7. Outrageous.  This track was written by R.Kelly. This became the fourth single from the album, and a short clip of the video was featured on the \\"My Prerogative: Greatest Hits DVD.\\" It sounds very hip - hop and sexual, but it is a fun track. 4/5  8. Touch Of My Hand.  This song is more sensual then sexual, like some of the other tracks on the album. Highly Sexual tracks on the album include \\"Toxic\\", \\"Outrageous\\" and \\"Boom, Boom\\".   The lyrics are very sexy. \\"I'm not ashamed of the things that i dream. I find myself flirting with a verge of obscene\\".  \\"Another day without a lover. The more I come to understand, the touch of my hand\\" The song sounds very Asian. Chinese strings are used in it, and it is a very mature track, and calming to listen to. \\"The Bill Hamel Remix\\" from \\"B In The Mix\\" is a good version of the song, so if you enjoy the original album version check that one out. 4/5  9. The Hook Up.  When I first head this song i thought it was too wild, and didn't like it, but when i heard it a couple of times i started to enjoy it. It sounds Jamaican and you feel like you are on a Caribbean island when listening to it. It has the back up vocals of a Jamaican man in it. Great party song. 5/5  10. Shadow.  This is another sensual track on the album. It is a rather Beautiful and haunting ballad. It talks about a lover whose prescense is felt, but seems as if they are far away, and are missed. This was a pretty enjoyable song. 4/5  11. Brave New Girl.  This song talks about Britney's reinvention and letting go of your fears in life, starting it fresh and enjoying yourself. Good track to play when feeling good. It sounds more Candy Hip-Hop than anything else on the album and any Britney fan will find it enjoyable. 4/5.  12. Everytime.  Up until this track \\"Not A Girl, Not Yet A Woman\\" had been Britney's most personal and beautiful song. Britney wrote this song and Guy Sigsworth produced it. The result is her most Beautiful song yet. It is very haunting, but listen to it when you are low and it will cheer you up. This was the third single from \\"In The Zone\\" and second #1. (Not Surprisingly.) Even though I enjoyed \\"Britney\\" as an album better this ballad is her best and one of her best songs. It is very deep sounding and offers a gleam of beauty in a world where today's music is very shallow. This track was my favourite on the album. 5/5  I hope Britney continues to make music like this in the future.  Buy the European version of this album for two bonus tracks.   \\"The Answer\\" and \\"Don't Hang Up\\"

B00005JNJV|5.0|They finally got Batman right.  The other Batman flicks gave you a brooding, dark vigilante, but they never told you how he got that way.  This movie does.    The title actually explains it all.  From the senseless murder of Bruce Wayne's parents through all the training he went through and why he donned the cowl.  Sounds boring, doesn't it?  Well, it isn't.  The story is very well told and kept me engaged throughout.     I guess this was the movie where you could actually sympathize with Bruce Wayne.  You get to know the tortured man behind the mask.  This wasn't so much a \\"Batman\\" movie as it was a Bruce Wayne movie, at least in the first half of it.    This isn't just a good comic book movie, this is a good movie period.  There's a plot to keep you riveted and plenty of action too.  You even get to see how Batman got his hands on all his toys, not to mention why he decided on a bat for his emblem.    For comic book officionados, I'll say that this story isn't canon (you comic folks will know what I mean).  I think they tried to get away from maniacal or cartoonish bad guys (joker, penguin) and went with one that was more recent in the Bat World (I'm not telling who the bad guy is) but was on the more reasonable side.    It's the best Batman movie because it's a story with a comic book hero in it and not a comic book story on the screen.    At the end, all I could say was \\"WOW!\\"    Only one warning.  The batmobile is cool, but it sure isn't what you're used to.     Added note:  I've been reading other reviews that state that Michael Keaton was the best Batman.  Please stop.  You're cracking me up.  Yes, I saw it.  Geez!    As for the lack of humor: IT WASN'T SUPPOSED to be a comedy or a satire.  You've learned about Batman through the Burton/Shumaker films, evidently  You want to understand The Batman?  Read the comics and graphic novels.
B000BVEKO0|1.0|Well, alright, let's blame it on the critics.  KoRn have emerged into the world of metal (or n-metal, depending on how you like to think about it) with great albums, they have flopped once with Issues and managed to make up for it with albums like Untouchables and Take A Look In The Mirror, which was considered by many to be the closest thing to Life Is Peachy, one of their greatest albums of all time.  Then they released their Greatest Hits CD (oh, Vol. 1... which I now doubt there will be a second one), and it included most of their greatest hits (Thoughtless excepted) and a few crappy covers... but hey, you know, it happens. <br /> <br />But now, my friends, I think that's it for KoRn : they're definitely stuck in the s**thole for good.  This album is the grossest attempt I have ever heard from KoRn... this is even worst than Limp Bizkit's Chocolate Starfish.  The causes : well, ok, Head did leave the band, taking an important part of the authentic KoRn sound with him, so that might explain part of it, but honestly, I think it's the critics.  For a while now, especially since they released Take A Look In The Mirror, a lot of people, even unloyal KoRn fans, have accused KoRn of not evolving, of keeping the same style and blah blah blah yadda yadda yadda.  Way to go, look what you've done now!  KoRn tried so hard to do something different that they ended up throwing away all the greatness that used to characterize their style and made it unique. <br /> <br />I still gave it a 1 star (and even if 0 was an option, I would've given it a 1) because there is a wicked song on that album, and a few \\"not bad\\" ones.  Liar is amazing.  Jon brings back the gibberish, lets out his intensity (not at its max, but it's better than nothing) for this one song that is the only element of redemption this album contains.  A few others I can tolerate (Love Song, Coming Undone, Tearjerker).  Oh yeah, Tearjerker I can also give a lot of credit too... pretty intense, an interesting initiative from KoRn... congrats.  But honestly, download those 4 songs and nevermind the rest.  Listening to this album from beginning to end was plain torture for me.  I even gave it a second listen, and then a third one, but then I decided that I didn't want to be a martyr for the rest of my life.  So here it is.  I just want to spare you a waste of your precious time and money.  I guess all great things come to an end.  They did their time... Jon said it best.  R.I.P. KoRn.

B000301YY8|5.0|I recently had the opportunity to see James Blunt in concert, as he was opening for Jason Mraz. Having heard of him from another source a few months ago, I ended up being one of the only people in the room who knew who he was.  <br />His songs are heart-wrenching, and that's the only way to describe them. At the concert, while waiting for the inherently bubbly Mraz to take the stage, somebody in the audience yelled for Blunt to sing something \\"happy.\\" But personally, I don't think \\"happy\\" is in Blunt's repertoire. James Blunt is someone you listen to when you feel like...feeling sad. His voice is heartbroken, his lyrics are heartwrenching, and he has a pretty good reason to be depressed, if you ask me.  <br />Overall, his songs have such depth and beauty to them that evoke emotions, unlike many popular artists of the day. If you are looking for a artist with deeply philosophical lyrics and a background to match, Blunt is your man.

B0009VRHLK|3.0|The 'road', as an open highway to emotional oppurtunity, is a glistening blue and gray effect in Vincent Gallo's notoriously criticized, \\"The Brown Bunny\\", the portrait of an eccentric lone wolf who packs up his motorcycle in the back of his van and travels from New Hampshire to California. As a road picture, it seduces the viewer to kick back and comfortably watch the winding highways and impending horizon, despite the genuine nutcase driving the van. Singer-songwriter, Gordon Lightfoot's \\"Beautiful\\", becomes a crackling, cheery and upbeat ode to love, through the bug splattered windshield, in one perfectly pristine scene. I could have driven for hours, but by the time he reaches California, and the infamous oral sex scene, with a nearly comical (and egotistical) stunt-male organ, things get a bit, um, tasteless. Our hero's delusions turn out to be not very complex, and the significance of a flashback detailing his history, amounts to a character study the equivalent of a criminal and psychotic mind on network TV. As for the symbolism of the brown bunny, (there actually is a brown rabbit in the film), I fear it goes no further than a geometric shape children might see in the commode.

B000BMSTMS|4.0|I have a confession to make, I am no longer a die hard Korn fan. Honestly, they lost me on Take a Look in the Mirror. It was one of those instances where your dad was trying to be cool in front of you and fell flat on his face. I figured after the fallout with Epic, Korn would merely become a band that released something independently every so often. Boy was I wrong...They end up signing a monumental contract with EMI/Sony. Back to the band, I honestly have always liked Korn in their most experimental releases, Issues and Untouchables. So obviously, See You on the Other Side is another album in that direction.<br /><br />First off, anyone waiting for another self titled or Life is Peachy, grow up! This band tried to be that 22 year old immature band again with Take a Look in the Mirror and it flopped big time. Now Korn takes a shot at electronics in their new album. They might take a page from Nine Inch Nails but they don't rip out the book if you know what i mean. \\"Twisted Transistor\\" has given the band more ridicule than Metallica with St. Anger. It is easily not one of their best songs but the beat is enjoyable nonetheless. The highlight of the album goes to \\"Hypocrites\\" which follows that Korn kind of crunchy guitar while also perhaps taking punches at particular person with religious beliefs *gee I wonder*. So far, it is the highlight of the album, in my opinion.<br /><br />The other thing one should know before buying this album is that this is not a heavy album by Korn standards. There are perhaps 3 to 4 songs that have that grinding flow that Korn performs so well. The introduction to production and co writers The Matrix has made the songs much tighter and has left the album with a lot less filler. Sadly enough some filler still makes it through.  \\"Throw Me Away\\" can leave you doing just that and Getting Off's descriptive nature isn't much to brag about either. The album's finale, \\"Tearjerker\\", also takes away from a climatic could be finale in \\"Seen It All\\". Seen It All is perhaps the pinnacle of Korn's new direction. With a Faith No Morish atmosphere mixed with Jonathan Davis's inner demons, this song explains all that the band should live up to be.<br /><br />The bandmembers in particular all have their flaws and highlights in the album. Jonathan Davis for the most part has traded in his trademark growls for a more melodic voice. However, on \\"Liar\\" and \\"For No One\\" Jonathan still shows that he can carry on in screaming. Munky is perhaps the shining star of the album partly because he is no longer a co-star with departured guitarist Brian \\"Head\\" Welch. His effects use on guitars have only gotten tighter and stronger since Untouchables. Fieldy gets to spread his wings as hell with new groovy bass driven beats that the band and The Matrix conjured up. David finally decided to join the crowd and use double bass drums which only makes him more lethal on the heavier tracks. For the first time in a long time, David performed excellently.<br /><br />In conclusion, if you're looking for crazy blast beat death metal cd, I suggest you stick to Malevolent Creation and Nile. Yet, if you can also appreciate that a mainstream band has the pride in themselves to experiment then this CD is for you. There are heavier and better bands out there believe me, but Korn will forever have a place in my CD collection as the stepping stone into heavy music.<br /><br />P.S. *Get the deluxe edition, it features B-sides that bring you back to a heavy grooving Korn*s perhaps the pinnacle of Korn's new direction. With a Faith No Morish atmosphere mixed with Jonathan Davis's inner demons, this song explains all that the band should live up to be.     The bandmembers in particular all have their flaws and highlights in the album. Jonathan Davis for the most part has traded in his trademark growls for a more melodic voice. However, on \\"Liar\\" and \\"For No One\\" Jonathan still shows that he can carry on in screaming. Munky is perhaps the shining star of the album partly because he is no longer a co-star with departured guitarist Brian \\"Head\\" Welch. His effects use on guitars have only gotten tighter and stronger since Untouchables. Fieldy gets to spread his wings as hell with new groovy bass driven beats that the band and The Matrix conjured up. David finally decided to join the crowd and use double bass drums which only makes him more lethal on the heavier tracks. For the first time in a long time, David performed excellently.     In conclusion, if you're looking for crazy blast beat death metal cd, I suggest you stick to Malevolent Creation and Nile. Yet, if you can also appreciate that a mainstream band has the pride in themselves to experiment then this CD is for you. There are heavier and better bands out there believe me, but Korn will forever have a place in my CD collection as the stepping stone into heavy music. B000002KOG|5.0|[FIVE YEARS LATER: POSTSCRIPT 9/10/10: It was arrogant of me to presume to \\"tell\\" people what this song is about. I don't know why I started off the review the way I did. Obviously I should have said \\"My personal interpretation of the song is....\\"]    Original review follows....  For people who don't know what this song's about, it's actually a song voicing conservative opinions, which Neil reiterated in the 80s and also nowadays. In this song he is hitting out against lack of integrity or resilience by authorities (\\"the preacher took his bible and laid it on the stool - with the congregation running why should I play the fool\\") and homogeneity in society and multiculturalism (\\"there was an Indian in the corner trying on my clothes\\", and \\"the servicemen were yellow...\\") In this new era, this new society, Neil says \\"if you ever need a ride there be sure to let me know....no, no, NO!\\" The rest of the lyrics voice similar sentiments.    Similarly, in the song \\"Here we are in the years\\", Neil rails against environmental degradation (we \\"people planning trips to stars allow another boulevard to claim a quiet country lane; it's insane\\"!)    Neil Young is surely the most underrated performer of rock/pop music, even acknowledging his enduring very high esteem. The sheer integrity and beauty of his songs (melody, lyrics but much more importantly overall souind/spirit) cannot be praised enough.  (By the way, note that a good proportion of his songs relate to motion...)
038533348X|4.0|Let Vonnegut plunge you into the dark realm of scientific progress. Meet Felix Hoenikker, a scientist who cares little for the consequences of his breakthrough research on humanity. Discover how his creation, ice-nine, affects those around him. Imagine the impact of merely a single drop of ice-nine that can cause oceans of water molecules to freeze irreversibly.  <br /> <br />Through Vonnegut's often aberrant and whimsical text, he manages to depict humankind's search for happiness, while using humor, wit, and cynicism to explore morality, the absurd, religion and mortality. This is a story about creativity and the power of science; and at the same time it is a pessimistic look at the fate of humankind, a stupid and vicious race.  <br /> <br />You will adore Vonnegut's catchy chapter titles and quirky characters, but may grapple with trying to relate seemingly disconnected chapters. References to oblivion and abyss emphasize the idea of emptiness and remind us that we are all wanderers, with regrets and lost questions, clinging to our souls.  <br />

0143034901|4.0|Wow, this was an addictive read. I had heard great things about this novel from customers in the book shop where Iw orked, and I finally sat down this weekend to read it. I must say, I had trouble putting it down, even when I looked at my alarm clock and realized that it was four in the morning, and I had to be at work in four hours.<br /><br />Zafon has earned comparison to Gabriel Garcia Marquez, but this is common for authors who write novels with any hint of mysteriousness in the plot who write in Spanish, and I found his style to be unique and refreshing.<br /><br />My comlaints are few, but large enough to dock one star from an otherwise great novel. First of all, the translation is extrememly weak. In the first fifty pages or so, I counted three idiomatic Spanish expressions that do not make sense translated literally into English, but for which there are appropriate English phrases, that were translated literally into English, and this was quite annoying. The prose was very wooden at times, and in the context of this novel, with its riveting storyline, I felt that I had to agree with Pablo Neruda: If you are going to translate a work, you shoudl improve upon it - or at least capture the poetic nature of the language and not just the words.<br /><br />My biggest complaint, however, is that after 400 pages of loose ends in the plot, the author resolves all of them with a 100 page letter from one of the characters. This was lame. I really feel that Zafon, having constructed such a beautiful story up until this point, had the capability of artfully tying up all of these lose ends with the in the storyline itself. This smacked of pure laziness of the part of the author. I would have gladly read another 300 pages of this novel, good as it was, if that is what it took to tie up these lose ends.<br /><br />Other than that, this was a great read. Highly recommended.

0064407667|4.0|By my title, you may have guessed that this review is of the entire Series of Unfortunate Events as opposed to simply being about the first volume. Or, rather, it is a review of volumes 1-12 and the Snicket biography, as volume 13 has not yet been released, a phrase which here means that \\"Snicket has written it and is waiting until everyone desperately needs to buy it before he sells the book.\\" I mention it both for your understanding, and also to warn of the very possible spoilers contained below. <br /> <br />Is it dangerous to review the series prior to the last installment's arrival? Perhaps--but in truth, the first twelve books are so similar to one another that it's hard to imagine the thirteenth straying very far. <br /> <br />Similar? Similar isn't even precisely the word that applies, here. The Series of Unfortunate Events feel, rather, that they've been taken from the same cookie cutter, or perhaps a Mad Lib. To wit: the Baudelaire orphans are placed in some well-meaning fool's custody. The wicked Count Olaf, hot after their inherited fortune, insinuates himself into their lives in some manner easily recognizable by the orphans, but utterly convincing to the lack-wits who guard them. The orphans are separated from their guardians, often through fatal means, and fall into the villain's clutches. By some device which incorporates the three stand-out abilities of the orphans--Violet invents, Klaus researches and Sunny bites--they manage to extricate themselves and finally convince others of Olaf's schemes, but never quite in time to prevent his escape. Repeat. Then, repeat again. Then again. <br /> <br />Given all of this, and the overly-simplistic narrative style (it explains words as it goes, etc.), it might be the natural conclusion to draw that the series is for very young children, and not very good even at that. It's certainly close to the conclusion I had drawn after finishing the The Bad Beginning, the first book of the series. But, at a friends request, I continued on... and... actually, it's kind of interesting. <br /> <br />A Series of Unfortunate Events is not as simple as it appears at first, and there is perhaps a kind of real design behind the repetitious elements. The dumbed-down narration is actually rather witty, it's running definitions allowing the author to comment on various topics with sarcasm and irony. The event cycle, recognizable by the third book, allows the reader to pick up on subtle variations, and make it all the more interesting when the series finally starts to deviate. Eventually, the narrator becomes a character in his own right (and thus of questionable reliability), and long-held assumptions are called into question, too. Even if it is mostly superficial, the characters do slightly change over the long-haul, and the social commentary infused in the various backdrops (The Austere Academy assaults schools, The Ersatz Elevator, the upper-class, and so on) provide enough to keep older readers interested and smiling. <br /> <br />Though I was highly hesitant to begin, and not excited at all about continuing after the first book, I must report that, over time, I adapted to the style and began to understand some of the humor that is not readily apparent at first glance. Both my appreciation, and the quality of the books themselves, have improved from volume to volume to the point where I am looking forward to the release of the thirteenth, and final, volume. <br /> <br />This is not the best series of all time, in any way, shape or fashion, but it actually is pretty good. Recommended.
B000007XUQ|5.0|I am one of the few who actually preferes Old Fashioned Christmas over Christmas Portrait.  Both are fine examples of masterful vocals and instumental arraingments (both sacred and secular) of holiday tunes; however, There is something about the opening set of Old Fashioned Christmas that strikes a chord. From Richard's a-ca-pella \\"It Came Upon A Midnight Clear\\" through the medly of instrumental tunes, of which, Richard's interpretation of \\"O Holy Night\\" is amazing, through the simple \\"An Old Fashioned Christmas\\" and into Karen's opening vocal on \\"Home for The Holidays\\" really plays well.  The anticipation that is created waiting for Karen's first note...\\"Oh there's no place like home for the holidays...\\" is far superior (which is saying A LOT) than on Christmas Portrait (which is also superbly done). <br /> <br />Karen was born to sing these songs.  It doesn't miss except for the short version of \\"Santa Clause is Coming to Town,\\" \\"Jingle Bells,\\" and \\"Silver Bells,\\" the only questionable tunes on either set.
B000024D4R|5.0|This was the album that blew away the Pink Floyd's 'spacy' image.    <br /> <br />There's no soft drumming to lull one into a daze on Animals.    There's no meditative organ, no warm saxophone, no atmospheric guitar chords, no dreamy voice scapes.   Instead, Animals is a rough, angry rant at the world, expressed in lyrics and music that are edgy, taut, and quite brilliant.  <br /> <br />Consider the time this album was made - the mid-1970s.   The world was sunken in a post-Vietnam heroin haze that obliterated the promise of the world-peace-dreaming late-1960s.  Watergate had just shocked America, the first oil shock had just hit the world, and Floyd themselves were coping with the fame, guilt and burden of superstardom.  <br /> <br />Little wonder then, that Roger Waters was taking a rather dim view of humanity.   <br /> <br />In Animals Waters sees all the people in the world as capable of being classified into three kinds of people and he uses the allegory of three kinds of animals to express this - Dogs, or those that rule through deceit and ambition, Pigs, or those that feed their greed off others, and Sheep, the rest of us who let the Dogs and Pigs have their way.   <br /> <br />Is this a backhanded call to revolution?  Maybe.  But mostly Animals is a wail of frustration, a cry from the innocent Waters growing up to fnd the world a far more bitter and dangerous place than he, or any of us, wants it to be.   <br /> <br />Dogs, cowritten by David Gilmour, is a searing guitar-led invocation of spite against the men Waters clearly sees as the arch-enemies of all mankind - our club-tie wearing leaders.  <br /> <br />The 20-minuite-long song, which sees Gilmour using his guitar to imitate dogs howling at each other in the night, took up nearly all of Side A when this album was released on vinyl in 1977.  I say nearly because despite Animals' harsh mood, it actually begins, and closes, with  twin songs of love and redemption, that are somewhat eccentrically called Pigs on the Wing I and II.  <br /> <br />Interestingly, Animals is one classic record where the CD format actually works even better than vinyl at showcasing the albums narrative theme because the songs on side B are meant to be seamless continuations of where side A ends.  <br /> <br />Pigs and Sheeps, which follow Dogs, are two of the Pink Floyd's most rocky and evocative numbers.  Both tracks open with eerie keyboard work from Richard Wright and both benefit from Nick Mason's behind-the-beat drumming.  But other than this, Wright and Mason contributed little to the album.  <br /> <br />Pigs is a snarling, jarring tune that you just want to turn on and turn up! Neighbors beware!  Gilmour's guitar sizzles, and  Waters sings this song with an energy and verve that were missing in many of his previous vocals.   From lamenting the falseness of the Dogs amongst us, in Pigs Waters laments the transparent greed of the merchant-class in our midst, and the hunger for wealth that all of us have, and which Waters sees as having come to define our lives.   <br /> <br />Waters despairs for the industrial wasteland capitalism and consumerism have created, and despairs even more that there is no escape from it for anyone. In his eyes, it is impossible to escape the banal, cruel, soggy world of the Pigs and the heavy sarcasm of the lyrics in the song, as well as the snarl with which they are delivered, bring all these passions to life vividly.  <br /> <br />The next track, Sheep, caused a mild sensation in some circles when Animals was released because of its rather irreverant take-off on the Lord's Prayer, which is mumbled over the song's jangly and slightly overwrought musical mid-section.   <br /> <br />Waters must have been glad for the controversy.   His intention with this song seems to have been to insult and mock all of us for allowing ourselves to be ruled by Dogs and Pigs as we are.  But its a \\"concerned mocking\\" if you will, an attempt at awakening listeners to what Waters sees as the impending plight of the world.   Sheep is a haunting song because it is the one most of us identify with, Waters once said.   But is that who were really are or what we like to believe of ourselves?  Listen closely and you might find your reality echoed  in Dogs or Pigs as well. <br /> <br />To close a album as gritty and daring as Animals with as sweet and moving a song as Pigs on the Wing must have seemed absurd to record executives.  But it works.   The song rescues Animals from what otherwise might have seemed like its unflagging stream of pessimism, its salty  undertaste of pathos, isolation and despair.   Pigs on the Wing redeems not only the album, it redeems us, for through it we can see that in the clarity of love all of us can be reborn and forgiven for the time we spent as Dogs, Pigs or Sheep.  <br /> <br />When Animals was first released, and through later years, it was not considered to be an album that was quite in the same grade as Dark Side of the Moon (1973) or Wish You Were Here (1975).   Perhaps people missed the Floyd's space sound and were a bit alienated by the album's sparse, tight sound, which makes many listeners a bit uneasy.   But the passage of time has only polished this rough diamond of a record, and perhaps in a few years it will be regarded as an even greater masterpiece than Wish You Were Here or The Wall (1979).

B000060MMI|5.0|Flogging Molly is quickly becoming one of my favorites. The Irish sound is great with the assortment of different instruments. You continue to get a very rhythmic beat and it becomes infectious. It doesn't really matter what mood you are in (sad, happy, angry, 'drunk'), this music fits all your moods. You can listen to the same song, no matter what mood you're in, and it will always comply as the sound you need to hear at the time. While I like the Swagger cd better, Drunken Lullabies is not far behind it. Another rousing collection that will make you want to move with it.

After witnessing the death of his parents when he was young, billionaire Bruce Wayne wanted to fight villainy in the world.  This drove him to become Batman; and, ironically, he chose to become 'Batman' because bats were what he was most afraid of.<br /><br />As Batman, Bruce Wayne uncovers a plot to damage Gotham City's water system, which would in turn destory the city itself. B00008RWRH|3.0|Poor Haydn, a genius whose symphonies rarely get the treatment that genius deserves. Here Eugen Jochum provides agreeable, thoroughly anodyne readings that wouldn't be acclaimed if the same casualness were applied to Mozart or Beethoven. I've owned this set of \\"London\\" Symphonies for twenty years and have yet to make it through without a disspiriting sense of boredom. The London Phil. plays agreeably enough -- I don't know the added performances from Berlin and Munich in this expanded box set -- and there's an overall air of pleasantness. DG's original analog recordings from the Sevneties are brighter and more natural in this reissue compared to the original CD transfer, it seems.<br /><br />However, if you want to come much closer to the fire, there's Bernstein on Sony, Beecham on EMI (both acknowledged as masters in this music), and for backward-glancing German traditionalists, Klemperer (also EMI, newly reissued at super bargain price), plus a few scattered recordings by Furtwangler.  In the opposite direction there are taut, streamlined Haydn recordings from Szell, Fricsay, and the originator himself, Toscanini. If you yearn for a controversial approach that adds more punch and sharper attacks than I for one feel comfortable with, there's Harnoncourt in semi-period style with the Royal concertgebouw. And for outright period style, there's a host of choices, of which Charles Mackerras's versions seem to have won considerable praise -- be prepared for jack-rabbit speed and a greatly pared-down orchestra.<br /><br />In short, as much as the Gramophone and various Amazon reviewers love these bland, plain-faced readings, I think any curious listener can do much, much better.
076790592X|5.0|Morrie Schwartz was a man of wisdom, kindness, and live even in his dying days. Tuesdays with Morrie by Mitch Albom deserves a five star rating for the way it captures your heart and your  <br />attentions and teaches you many things about life and death. Tuesdays with Morrie is a wonderful story about a man who goes back to see his old professor who is dying from a disease called Amyotrophic Lateral Sclerosis (ALS). Mitch goes to visit his professor every Tuesday and they bond as if they had been life long friends. Morrie teaches Mitch things from every aspect of life such as: life, marriage, family, love, death, and friends. Morrie's view on life is inspiring and changing for everyone. Mitch writes with an awesome talent and while reading you really view Morrie as the person he was and can view their relationship for what it was. Mitch makes a  <br />noble, but selfish attempt to hold onto a piece of Morrie by recording their sessions together. The idea of recording a dying mans last words seams disrespectful in way kind of making Morrie's death not seem to be taken seriously enough. Tuesdays with Morrie is an amazing book that captures the rider's attention and fills the reader with live and encourages the reader to be better person. <br /> <br />      Morrie is the kind of person everyone wants to know. He is kind, loving, intelligent and optimistic. Morrie's view on life is wonderful and full of joy even as he is slowly dying. He makes the simplest day seem like the best thing in the world. Morrie teaches you to embrace and love the simple things in life. Morrie doesn't care about money, car, and the house. He cares about the love, friendship and giving to others. Morrie makes a wonderful point in saying, \\"When you're in bed you're dead\\". Morrie took each day as a new day and gave what he could to all the people that came to visit him. <br /> <br />      Mitch records his sessions with Morrie every Tuesday. It seams like a disrespectful thing to do. Morrie is slowly dying and Mitch is selfish in trying to hold onto Morrie's voice. Mitch also makes himself out to be a stubborn student who is at first so caught up in his own life even the things Morrie says to Mitch don't seams like they can be taken fully to heart because of the life Mitch led prior to reuniting with Morrie. <br /> <br />      The book can be easily related to by anyone who reads it because of the many topics discussed. Morrie Schwartz truly understood the meaning of life and everything in life that came  <br />his way. Tuesdays with Morrie teaches its readers the true values in life and how to deal the bad and good. Morrie's optimism and comical outlook on life and disease in an inspiration to everyone. <br /> <br />      Tuesdays with Morrie is an inspirational book that captures the heart of its readers. Morrie Schwartz was a wonderful human being and his outlook on life will help many to cope with the things that make life tough. Morrie inspired a busy man to slow down and look at the more important  things in life after 16 years and Mitch Albom's book about his old professor can do the same for it's readers. Tuesday with Morrie is a true phenomena!
B000002L61|4.0|The Last In Line featured the same great line-up that produced the classic Holy Diver. This album charted much higher than the debut due to the fact that Dio had already created a buzz and MTV was playing the video for The Last In Line every day. I don't think this album is as good as Holy Diver but it comes close. There is still plenty of great guitar from Vivian, and Dio delivers his usual great performance. Vinnie Appice (Mob Rules!) and Jimmy Bain (ex-Rainbow) are as solid as they were on the debut. The album opens with the classic up-tempo We Rock featuring superb drumming from Vinnie. Next is the title track with great vocals/lyrics from Dio and an excellent solo from Vivian. After that comes Breathless which has a decent riff and a cool chorus. I Speed At Night is the fastest song on the album, kind of the evil twin of the debut's Stand Up And Shout. Next is the slow paced One Night In The City which has a good chorus and another great guitar solo. Evil Eyes took me a while to get into but now it is one of my favorite tracks. The lyrics and vocals are classic Dio. Mystery is the poppiest song on the album but it is quite catchy and Vivian gets the chance to wail come solo time. I never really cared for Eat Your Heart Out, it's just not very interesting. The last track, Egypt (covered by Doro), is ok even though it drags on a bit. All in all The Last In Line is one of Dio's best albums throughout his career.
