0385334206|5.0|I had to read this book for a college English course, and I finished it within days of the initial assignment. It's a really fabulous novel.<br /><br />It's clear that some reviewers missed the point of this novel. Yes, most definitely an easy and entertaining read, there are many, many layers. It also has a great meta-narrative. What some consider \\"condescending\\" is really a play on the plot itself. It's written in the guise of a sci-fi novel Kilgore might write. Basically, it's written so that someone (either a child or someone not from Earth) can understand the things that we seemingly take for granted.<br /><br />Vonnegut also alludes to the idea that we've lost touch with our past and what was once important to us through different annecdotes and stories. He has a really great argument about naming and how the importance of such names are either lost or ignored. It's a great commentary on our lives as Americans especially.<br /><br />I absolutely recommend this book. It's a great, fast read.
B000BB14YY|5.0|It really is about time this masterpiece got the treatment it deserved.  I have long held off purchasing this movie in its previous DVD incarnations because of the notoriously bad transfers.  At long last, justice has been served.  I couldn't ask for much more than this, short of getting to see it one more time on the big screen.<br /><br />All the extras are great, and to me, more than justify the price.  The commentaries are very much worth checking out, and the documentary on the second disc is quite fascinating just on its own.<br /><br />As to the movie itself, there isn't really anything to be said about this stupendous achievement that hasn't been said already.  Kurosawa very nearly bankrupted his studio making \\"Ran,\\" and it really is a miracle that the movie ever found its way to the big screen in the first place.  Simply to refer to it as an adaptation of \\"King Lear\\" is to do injustice to Kurosawa; he pillaged more Shakespeare than simply \\"Lear\\" (Lady Kaede owes more to MacBeth than to Lear, definitely), but he drew from multiple sources, and ultimately, from his own story-telling ability.  Ultimately one is left with a devastating portrayal of treachery, vengeance, the disintegration of well-laid plans, and the fragility of the human condition.  If that isn't enough, the battle scenes kick ass.<br /><br />If you love the art of movie-making, this is a movie that has to be part of your collection.  Just make sure to get the right version!
4789009637|5.0|I had been self-studying Japanese over numerous websites for 'bout 7 months when I decided to actually get a textbook. After searching around, reading reviews, asking people what they think I decided on Genki I. What a fantastic choice!! I learned more in 2 weeks in this book than I learned 7 months on a computer. Here I go, in depth (summary at end ^_~): <br /> <br />A) It starts out with an overview of the book, explanation of alphabets, so-on-and-so-forth, ect. Not much here but an introduction, soooo.... <br /> <br />B) Dialogue - The beginning of the lesson has a dialogue that goes with a certain lesson theme (e.g. New Friends covers greetings, simple questions, numerous phrases and vocab, ect.). This is written in kana (after lesson 3, kanji w/ furigana), romanji, (if any) katakana w/ furigana, and an English translation. You won't understand what's being said 'till the next few pages, so now onto that. <br /> <br />C) Vocabulary - A loooong list of vocab resides here. Although it may be sorta \\"random\\", it is useful and good stuff to know. Words and terms used in the dialogue are marked with an asterisk \\"*\\". This page is written in kana, kanji w/ furigana, (if any) katakana w/ furigana, romanji, and English. Ok! Here we go: <br /> <br />D) Grammar - easy-to-understand grammar explanations rest here, after vocab. This provides the info needed to actually USE the vocab. After reading this, you should probably get a lot more of the dialogue. But not quite.... <br /> <br />E) Um, Other? - These pages contain numerous class activities (not very useful to self-studiers, but can have some good practice exercises if you play both parts XD), other grammar/useful notes explanations, some more vocab perhaps, more dialogues, ect. In later lessons, this contains the kanji explanations as well. Basically, it's a planned lesson part that puts all you have learned in the previous pages to the test. It really builds on what you need to know, and forces you to read back, building stronger understanding and memorization ^^  <br /> <br />Summary: Clear, neat, and fun planned lessons, put together in a learning-effective format. Great for all ages (it IS intended for college classroom use, but I am a 13 self-studier, and I find it great!!) as well! You will learn so much, and be reading, speaking, writing, and UNDERSTANDING real Japanese by the end of the book! <br /> <br />Other notes: Be sure to get the CDs (especially if you're learning on your own) and the workbook. The workbook reinforces grammar and such, and the CD helps you listen, speak, and understand spoken Japanese better (REALLY helpful! It's extremely helpful at learning and understanding the accent!!!!). <br /> <br />Thanks for listening to my rambling! Hope it has given enough detail and everything you want to know before you decide on a good book!! (ALSO: do NOT get the Japanese For Busy People series; no matter how popular, it is terrible!!!!! Genki is a waaaay better investment!) <br /> <br />-Sachi
B000006TSC|3.0|That's right  -  essential.  Look, I own virtually ALL of the recorded Camel material, and if I had to compile a Top Five Songs list of the group, two of those five songs would come from THIS album alone:  \\"Echoes\\" (my favorite Camel song of all time!) and \\"The Sleeper\\".<br /><br />We diehard Camel fans will usually admit that it's the instrumentals that we love most about the band, with vocals only a peripheral element to the music.  (Why else do you think we all feel that \\"The Snow Goose\\" is their best album?)  Both \\"Echoes\\" and \\"The Sleeper\\" are heavy on the instrumental gymnastics.  The few vocals that do appear in \\"Echoes\\" are really well-done, and flow perfectly with the rest of the song.  The two-part \\"The Sleeper\\" is a classic Camel instrumental with odd time signatures and jazz-rock soloing.  Clever drums, dancing bass lines, cool synthesizer sounds, and great guitar/sax/keyboard soloing in both songs make them essential songs for the serious Camel collector.<br /><br />Hey, I'm compulsive enough to have plopped down good money just to own ONE song from an otherwise unnecessary album.  But with this album, you get some decent secondary songs to make the whole purchase worth your while, as well as a heavy dose of great sax, courtesy of guest Mel Collins.  Some of the \\"decent\\" music includes the title track that begins the album, and the three-minute Santana-like guitar outro to \\"Summer Lightning\\", which is simply STUNNING (despite the disco drumming).  After those, you have some \\"nice\\" songs (\\"Wing and a Prayer\\" and \\"Rainbow's End\\") and the admittedly disappointing, blah, unremarkable ones (\\"Starlight Ride\\", \\"You Make Me Smile\\", and the Canterbury-ishly tongue-in-cheek \\"Down on the Farm\\").  Curses!<br /><br />This was my very first Camel album purchase back in the mid-70's, so I've always tried to defend my little discovery against the critics.  But there's no sense in denying that some commercialism crept into this album on a few tracks, and the album would have to stand behind at least 5 or 6 other Camel albums in terms of overall quality.<br /><br />Unfortunately for your wallet, you NEED \\"Echoes\\" and \\"The Sleeper\\".....so buy the album if you can't find them on any other compilations.<br /><br />I value interesting music that is played and recorded well. B000002542|4.0|This is Journey's first album.  It was released in 1975.  The sound quality is good.  It is a \\"full lenth\\" album and not an \\"EP\\", as listed by Amazon.  But, it is only 37 minutes long, which is the range of a standard LP back in the day (LP's were typically 35 to 45 minutes long). <br /> <br />As the album was being recorded, Journey was just becoming a band.  The band consisted of Greg Rolle and Neal Schon from Santana, Aynsley Dunbar (a British drummer who played in blues and progressive bands and was in Frank Zappa's band), Ross Valory and George Tickner (who would only be on this album). <br /> <br />The band and the album get off to a great and promising start with the song \\"Of A Lifetime\\".  It might be the second best thing Journey has ever done (I think \\"Look Into the Future\\" is the best).  It has a number of other great songs like, In My Lonely Feeling and Mystery Mountain. <br /> <br />The CD isn't quite as succesful with the 2 instrumentals, Kouhetek and Topaz (and I am a huge instrumental fan).  Kouhetek is especially pointless.  It isn't horrible, it just doesn't match the quality of Of A Lifetime or In My Lonely Feeling. <br /> <br />If you like the Journey hits, with Steve Perry singing, there is a good chance that you will not like this album.  The music is completely different than when Perry joined the group, and it changed to corporate rock. <br /> <br />The music on the first 3 albums, before Perry joined, is much richer, but also much harder.  In some ways it sounds like a rock version of Santana, with the rich textures of music.  There is a combination of many music styles, including jazz and blues. <br /> <br />But, mainly, the early Journey was a hard rock band...but a hard rock band with some depth.  In concert they played very hard and very heavy.

B0000029AP|5.0|This is a fantastic Aerosmith album wherein all their skills are brought together into one masterpiece of seventies hard rock. Encompassing the funky grooves that Perry and Kramer bring with them, Walk This Way and Adam's Apple make the record roll while No More, No More, Round and Round, Sweet Emotion, the title track, and Uncle Salty make it rock.<br /><br />I've never been too fond of their cover of Big Ten Inch Record, but it's a fan favorite and was pretty tongue in cheek. The ballad at the end is the best Tyler's ever done - even up to today's poppy rubbish. It's plaintive without being maudlin, the strings are perfectly utilized, and the coda is well done.<br /><br />No More No More and Sweet Emotion are two of the best songs in their extensive catalog, and the FM staple Walk This Way has shown how durable it is over the years. Tyler wrote some of his best lyrics, Perry, Hamilton, and Whitford put music to his prose, and you have Aerosmith at their best. A top 100 of all time in rock history.

My only compaint is that I feel Chicago does too many of their ballad hits to 'compete' with EW&F, but I'm sure I'm in the minority; most fans would probably select exactly the same songs the band performs here. <br /> <br />In short, it's great to see those two powerhouse bands at the top of their game, pushing each other and obviously enjoying it.  As Robert Lamm says, \\"Music is unity.\\"  This is a DVD well worth owning.

B000BCKFWK|5.0|Admittedly, this was my favorite film of the year in its original form.    The Special Edition was worth the wait, and in my opinion, is worth buying even if you purchased the original.    The second disc includes the film in a new version -- as three separate graphic novels (and one graphic short story) --fully capturing Frank Miller's incredible vision in glorious black and white (and red and yellow).  In a word, amazing.  I almost always find director's cuts to be a tiresome affair -- simply re-inserting scenes that were correctly cut the first time.  Not so.  Not one frame feels like filler.  Everything serves to deepen and enrich the amazing world of Basin City.    I haven't made it through all of the new extras yet (on the second disc), but two are definitely worth noting.  The 15 minute Flic School (a staple of Rodriguez's special editions) is great and focuses on the process of shooting in the digital domain -- one surprise was learning that many of the actors who work together seamlessly in the film never actually met in person.  Ahh the magic of digital editing.    The companion piece to the flic school is an all greenscreen version of the theatrical release.  That is -- Rodriguez takes only the raw footage of the film, without any special effects, de-colorization and in many cases, sets -- and speeds the whole thing up so you get to race through the film and see how they did it -- which sets were real, which ones weren't, etc.    Truly incredible.    This one gets my vote for DVD release of the year.

She NEVER was able to fall asleep on her own using the baby whisperer methods even though we stuck with them over and over again.   <br /> <br />What was most upsetting though, was that she became clingy, fearful, and had poor eye contact after these 5 mos. My husband and I both noticed it. We switched to attachment parenting and used the approaches from Kate Allison Granju's book \\"Attachment Parenting\\" and \\"Good Nights\\" by Jay Gordon.  What a difference after a month!!  She was a happy, social baby!!  We are convinced it is because we were losing her trust, night after night putting her to bed using these methods. <br /> <br />Attachment parenting is the best choice and developmentally the best option. Don't take shortcuts like the baby recommends, this is only a short period of your lives but is so crucial!   My daughter is 8 months now and is very happy and not at all clingy and fearful. B000BMSTMS|5.0|So, we all know that Take a Look in the Mirror blows a little. I really don't want to get into that too much. On their seventh album, KoRn decides to try something different with all these industrial influences and new producers and I think it really works. Though some complain that this album is not heavy enough, I think it is plenty heavy. Songs like Politics, Hypocrites, Getting Off and Liar are examples. I'm not going to lie. I am a diehard KoRn fan. I stood out in the cold today for 4 hours to get a poster signed by KoRn tonight. I didn't think I would be disappointed by this CD and I wasn't. Here'es a track by track review since I know you kids love those: <br /> <br />1. Twisted Transistor (8/10) - There were a couple of things tweaked in the CD version like the extended intro and extended bridge that were not expected and made the song a little fresher than it really was. The riff (though repeated again sometime on SYOTOS) is a very catchy one that I find myself humming and random points through the day. <br /> <br />2. Politics (8/10) - I don't know. I really like David's drumming but the only thing that really does it for me in this song is the bridge. Jonathan's growl is very nice and the message makes me happy. \\"Don't give a s*** about politics!\\" That's really how more people should feel.  <br /> <br />3. Hypocrites (8/10) - Yeah. The riff really is repeated quite a lot in this song but I don't mind because I like the riff. I prefer the live version of this song because it is a bit faster than the studio version. Overall good song. The pre-chorus and the chorus do it for this song. Jon's vocals are on point. <br /> <br />4. Souvenir (10/10) - At first, my favorite song on the CD. It's so melodic that it scares me. It's no wonder the first rumored title for SYOTOS was Souvenir of Sadness. This is a shining point on the album and Jonathan's vocals are really great. <br /> <br />5. 10 Or a 2-Way (7/10) - This is Fieldy's song. He is the main guy on this song and it is obvious. The problem I have with this song is that it seems to lack coherence. I can't quite follow what the hell is going on. But, the pre-chorus from Last Legal Drug is used as a bridge in this song and every time that bridge comes on, I get happy.  <br /> <br />6. Throw Me Away (9/10) - I'm quite familiar with this song because I bought The Other Side, Part 2 - EP from iTunes. I liked it instantly. It has a different vibe to it that is dark and sinister. The sound effects in the background and David's hard drumming make this song what it is and is another one of those melodic song. I like melodic. <br /> <br />7. Love Song (9/10) - Great song. At times feels like a heavy metal church song. It reminds me of the pipe organ and the... nevermind. I really like the lyrics in this song and the chorus is the high point in the song <br /> <br />8. Open Up (10/10) - Not only is Open Up a really good slow song, at the end, there is an abrupt halt to the song and then there is an interlude with some awesome scatwork from Jonathan. Of course the scatwork is electronically helped but it sounds really good, I think. At first, I didn't know what to make of it but I like it. <br /> <br />9. Coming Undone (9/10) - This song was played live at their show at Hammerstein last week and I think it is definitely single material. The chorus is catchy and Jonathan's vocals are, again, really awesome. After the concert I had the chorus in my head all night and the same is true now that I have the studio verison. <br /> <br />10. Getting Off (8/10) - This is one of those heavy songs I alluded to earlier. The stop-and-go guitars in the verses really work well with Jonathan's growling. Jonathan really shines in this song as does Munky. <br /> <br />11. Liar (10/10) - More single material. This song was also on The Other Side, Part 2 - EP so I've been familiar with it. From first listen I thought that it should be a single. It's heavy and has great melodies in it that get me singing along every time I hear it. Though the scat seems a bit out of place and the bagpipe outro is sort of weird, the overall song is amazing. <br /> <br />12. For No One (10/10) - My current favorite on the CD. Though the lyrics are kind of cheesy at points, the song is so melodious, especially in the chorus. I like songs I can easily hum too and this song is it. I've overplayed this song already. Jon sings beautifully during the chorus. <br /> <br />13. Seen It All (8/10) - I have no idea what to make of this song. On some listens, I like it and on other listens, I don't. It's another slow song that at points can get boring. I think this song should have been replaced with one of the songs on the bonus disc, preferably Eaten Up Inside. <br /> <br />14. Tearjerker (8/10) - *sigh* I really, really want to be head over heels in love with this song but I just can't. It doesn't hold a candle to Dirty or My Gift to You. These lyrics are so odd. What do you mean you need someone to love you? You're married, Jonathan. It's just too stripped down for my tastes. <br /> <br />Overall, this is the freshest KoRn has sounded since their self-titled masterpiece. After losing Head, I was worried about what would emerge and it looks like the boys have done quite nicely. Munky has really stepped it up in the guitar department; David finally showcases some of the talent he displayed on KoRn and Life is Peachy; Jonathan's vocals are the most polished they've ever been. Overall, this album is a keeper and is recommended to any KoRn fan and any fan of rock music in general if only just for a listen.

B000BMSTMS|3.0|I'm going to start off by saying that Korn's original sound has been ripped off by so many other bands they had no choice but to change it up. They do pull it off at times with songs like Twisted Transistor and Coming Undone. Coming Undone is by far the best song on the album and one of Korn's best ever. Flaws are freckled throughout the album, mostly with Jonathan's singing. Personally I feel that \\"Issues\\" was Korn's moment in the spotlight as well as their best work. It seems that since \\"Untouchables\\" was released every Korn album is half filler. The problem with most hard rock bands is the fact that once they've created a unique sound it's very hard for them to change it. I feel the only band that has done this effectively and succeeded is Metallica. Korn is a great band that to this day still rocks live, but like many other hard rock bands they are finding it difficult to evolve musically. \\"See you on the other side\\" isn't a bust nor is it a great album. If you are a die hard Korn fan I say buy it and expect to enjoy it, but if you're expecting hard, gritty Korn, they no longer exist. The album stays very Green Day with a reliance on catchy riffs and simplistic chord progresions but has dramatic anti-war undertones that may not be apparent on the first few listens.  Billie Joe has transformed himself from the skate-punk snot nosed punker to the aged socially concious force that broadcasts throughout the mainstream media.  This album is important because it has been all over the top 40 lists with several songs.  These songs although not punk have brought punk's true message of social responsibility to the masses.  Punk has changed over the years and Green Day has managed to put forth an album that has reached many non-punkers with the old messages of the early punk movement.  Something that better punk bands have never quite achieved.  This album shows that Green Day has managed to re-invent themselves again into a political group much like a mellow Anti-Flag.

The collection of tracks on Amarantine presents a softer grace and quietness about them than the more charismatic and pop sounding tracks found on her previous two albums. I feel that the music on this album closely resembles that of her earlier work on \\"Watermark\\" and \\"Shepherd Moons,\\" which is the sound that I love the most from Enya. However, the music on \\"Amarantine\\" seems to focus more on Enya's vocals and a bit less on the atmosphere, which is a noticeable change from her previous works and something that I personally miss. But, the richness and maturity of these compositions will hold much longer over time than the pieces on \\"A Day Without Rain,\\" for example, which due to a more \\"pop\\" nature seem to lack solid musical structure.<br /><br />\\"Amarantine\\" also features three songs sung in a new language created by lyricist Roma Ryan called, Loxian. Loxian has been described by Enya as \\"a futuristic language from a distant planet.\\" Roma Ryan has written a book that is due in late December called, \\"Water Shows the Hidden Heart,\\" that explores the language and its people in detail. She explains that the Loxian people are much like us, \\"They're in space, somewhere in the night. They're looking out, they're mapping the stars, and wondering if there is anyone else out there. It's to do with that concept: are we alone in the Universe?\\" In Gaelic, the term is basically translated as, \\"the people that come from the Moon.\\" \\"Amarantine\\" features one other song containing text in a different language from English and that is \\"Sumiregusa (Wild Violet),\\" which is the first piece Enya has sung in Japanese. Also for the first time, there are no songs sung in her native Gaelic tongue.<br /><br />The name Amarantine is taken from the word, amaranthine, which means everlasting beauty that never fades. It is also a term to describe a deep red color, which I presume matches the outfit Enya wears on the cover of this album.<br /><br />Enya's \\"Amarantine\\" is definitely an album that I highly recommend. Any long time fan of Enya will certainly agree. Her music can inspire even the least artistic to dream in ways never thought imaginable.olor, which I presume matches the outfit Enya wears on the cover of this album. <br /> <br />Enya's \\"Amarantine\\" is definitely an album that I highly recommend. Any long time fan of Enya will certainly agree. Her music can inspire even the least artistic to dream in ways never thought imaginable.
B00003CXCW|5.0|Sunset Boulevard answers the age old question, Where Do Faded Hollywood Doves Go To Die? in truly greusome detail as we meet one Miss Norma Desmond.  Technically this is my most favorite picture of all time.  Norma Desmond is one truly twisted sister a fictional old film star now past it yet looking for her come back.  The movies are in her old tired blood and she seeks a close up like a heroin addict hunts for their next drug fix.  Norma Desmond courts that most elusive prey called youth and let me tell you this film chronicles the hunt which is driving her and all who surround her quite and quietly mad.<br /><br />Norma is yet another aging former star, a victim of that all too real Hollywood malady of beleiving her own press,  Norma in her heyday sowed the wind in treating people like dirt and reaped the worldwind as Hollywood disgarded her like yesterdays news when the wrinkles showed up and the glamour wore off.  Gloria Swanson was excellent as Norma Desmond because she was old enough to remember silent pictures and she had the exzagerated hand gesticulations and facial contortions used in the silent move era to convey feelings in a time before Talkies.<br /><br />Again if what I shared with you thus far was all there was to this movie it would be fun to watch but oh no.  Norma Desmond not only wants to re-energize her dead film career she wants a boy toy to replace the now dead monkey and friend she lives with in her faded dusty mansion that looks like a cross between a haunted house set, mad house and a large dusty tomb.  The film has an extra creepy feel as at the beginning you learn it is a story noir being told to you by a man now very dead.  Yes this is a story told by the dead victim of an explosive mixture of two demeanted peoples poison dreams and their immoral selfish willingness to do any wicked thing to make them come true.<br /><br />What makes Sunset Boulevard so good is that it feels so right.  Norma Desmond is such a man hungry self absorbed old babe and what started out as her lover's iron sense of dignity turns slowly into cotton candy norma consumes with a jaded passion.  Norma with all the deliberate cunning of a black widow spider slowly injects her lover with the potent venom of co-dependency which litterally eat away the kept man's backbone till he yields to her every whim for a time.  Helping Sunset Bolevard develop and keep its horrific mood is also the creepy music score which you can hear become more demented and manic as the characters lives and dignity self destruct as their tormented souls entertwine beyond hope of ever escaping each others perverse deadly embrace.<br /><br />There is plenty of dark humor in this Norma Desmonds Sunset Boulevard.  If this is a horror movie it is traggic horror.  Sunset Boulevard is certainly Psychological horror showing what twisted shallow minded people do to themselves and each other if their lusts for money, power and fame are unleashed by the proper situations.  Watching this movie is like watching to two animals eat each other alive while you the audience are enticed to take bets on which one will survive in the end.<br /><br />Finally this movie has a few mwmoriable lines too.  Her Lover says, ... \\"Hey You're Norma Desmond, You used to be BIG!\\"... To which Norma responds... I AM BIG its the picturh's that got small. and my favorite saying of all movies I have seen in life Norma's Desmonds swan song to the Camera's.<br /><br />\\"This is my life.  It always will be... There's no one else just us, the camera's and all those wonderful people out there in the dark..... Alright Mr DeMille I'm ready for my close up!\\".<br /><br />This is another of my must have DVD's.  Sunset Boulevard is serious in a weird way but in another way it is a solid black comedy laugh fest.  You have to buy Sunset Boulevard not to buy this is to cheat yourself of laughs galore.  Oh after seeing Sunset Bolevard you won't go swimming at any of Norma Desmonds Hollywood Parties unless youneed to learn how to float.  I am sure if you are a young man willing to help write Norma a sure fire career reviving come back script she will gladly give you the crash course on floating in her pool.<br /><br />Play your cards right she might take you for a ride in her dusty old car.d Parties unless you need to learn how to float. 0684824906|5.0|Ms. Goodwin has outdone herself this time. I have cradled this book gently, reading a few pages a night to make it last longer. I had always indulged a bit of curiousity about the characters in Lincoln's cabinet, and read a bit about different ones from time to time, but Goodwin has brought it all to one place and put each of them in perspective. Like most Lincoln authors, she ignores the Great Sioux uprising of 1862, and Lincoln's active engagement in it, but that is a minor quibble. This will become required reading for anyone interested in Abraham Lincoln and the Civil War.
B00000DFSK|2.0|My guess is that it HAD to be someone who was born around, say, 1982, because there's just NO WAY anyone who was really listening to this band during the mid to late 80's would have found these tracks to be the most endearing. What happened to all of the meaty, gritty, I-Wanna-Go-Fight-For-Ireland songs that made U2 such a phenom band??? B000003TA4|4.0|I think everyone goes through a Nirvana phase at some point. In early adolescence, nothing channels your frustration like the powerful attack of Kurt, Krist and Dave. For a time, Nirvana is the greatest band in the world. Then you grow up a little, listen again, and realize that they were making fun of kids like you all along. You have a good chuckle, dig the album out from time to time, and place other bands atop the pantheon of rock and roll.    To be sure, there's lots to love about Nevermind. From the clever mockery of Boston's \\"More Than A Feeling\\" on \\"Smells Like Teen Spirit\\" to the haunting licks of \\"Come As You Are\\" and the manic drumrolls throughout, this album contains many classic moments. Great bands emerge partly from the distinctness of each member, and Nirvana fulfills this prerequisite easily. Krist Nivoselic provides fluid and melodic basslines, and David Grohl, though not technically exceptional, attacks the drums with incredible force and command. Kurt fulfills his role by regularly stumbling onto unforgettable hooks.    At its best, Nirvana is an unstoppable force of raw power and wit. Few bands approach rock with such economy and purpose. When the opening chords of \\"In Bloom\\" crash through my stereo, I know that every sound the band makes will be deliberate and significant. The album's best song, \\"Lithium,\\" sychronizes simple mellow strumming with a fantastic crescendo, wicked snarling, and some of Kurt's most ironic and clever lyrics.    Given this high praise, why do I not give this album five stars? There are two main reasons. The first is that the band does not maintain its high standard throughout the entire record. \\"Breed,\\" \\"Territorial Pissings\\" and \\"Stay Away\\" are virtually the same song, and \\"Lounge Act\\" and \\"On a Plain\\" also bear uncomfortable resemblance to one another. Attempts to incorporate some punk authenticity into the record, they sound like B-sides that never received full consideration or development. Some people view \\"Polly\\"and \\"Something in the Way\\" as brilliant and haunting ballads; I find that on this record they reveal the one-dimensionality of Cobain's voice. When I listen to a truly great album, I find that each listen gives me a new understanding of some element or sublety that I hadn't noticed before. That quality is missing from Nevermind. It is good, angry music for the car, but does not really reward multiple listens.    The album's other major flaw comes from Kurt Cobain's inner turmoil. Much as he wanted to challenge the shallow focus of pop music at the time, he wrote music that was ultimately as meaningless as what came before it. Nihilism does not make for good listening. Cobain does not rail against the system, does not call for an uprising of the underprivileged, nor does he celebrate what's right with the world. Nevermind is as silly and flippant as its title suggests. The lyrics \\"Love myself better than you/I know it's wrong/What should I do,\\" sarcastic or not, simply cannot have emotional resonance. It's a shame that a band with so much talent squandered it making a meaningless record.

B00006L7XQ|5.0|I have been at times a rabid Johnny Cash fan (especially after seeing him in concert at Toad's Place in New Haven--extraordinary by any standard) and at times I have run luke warm on him (after hearing \\"A Boy Named Sue\\" for the millionth time). I have always respected his authenticity and have always loved his incredible voice, but I was never sure whether or not he was \\"the true vine\\" (Hank Williams and Waylon Jennings were absolutely the true vine, as is Billy Joe Shaver) of country music or just a very talented and very lucky (in terms of commercial acceptance of his music) country songwriter and singer.<br /><br />That question was answered for me one afternoon when the music director at the noncommercial FM radio station where I do a weekly show handed me an extra copy of \\"American IV:  The Man Comes Around.\\" Hearing this album for the first time was one of the most emotional experiences I've had in 40 plus years of listening to music seriously. I was devastated, floored, overwhelmed.<br /><br />Cash's version of \\"Hurt\\" is unbelievable. It is the most jarring raw emotion that I've ever heard on an album. I used to think only Van Morrison could send those kinds of chills up my spine: Cash topped him easily. And to be able to take a piece of radio wasteland like \\"Desperado\\" and turn it into a gut-wrenching story-song that even Tom Waits, I'm sure, would be staggered by, proves to me that yes, Johnny Cash is the true vine of country music. This man is the real deal. His version of \\"Bridge Over Troubled Water\\" must even widen the eyes of Art Garfunkel. It's simply amazing. But the song that will rip your heart out if you are any kind of Cash fan is his cover of \\"We'll Meet Again.\\"<br /><br />A few weeks later I was on a photo assignment in Nevada and listened to the album constantly (I brought a dozen CDs with me, but I needn't have bothered) for a week. If you want to hear this album in its full depth, fly out to Las Vegas, rent a Taurus for a week and drive across the desert for twelve hours a day. Somehow the loneliness of that environment matches this album. It was like having Cash beside me in the car. Again, even \\"Desperado\\" a song that I wish had never gotten ruined by overplay on commercial radio, was so riveting I had to play it over and over.<br /><br />That Cash was nearly alone in the studio when he recorded much of this CD is very obvious: this is a man saying goodbye to his old friends, and to himself.<br /><br />The next time I was on the radio I went on the air and said that I was going to play some songs from the best album I'd ever heard. My listeners know me as a wall-climbing Van Morrison fan, so I'm sure they thought it was something new from The Man. But it was this Cash album. Of course, Cash died about the same time that the album came out, I think, so it became his musical epilogue. So be it. How many artists go out with the best work of their careers warm in their hands--especially after a 50 year career?<br /><br />My feelings about this album remain. Though I find it difficult to listen to because it evokes a lot of saddness and very coarse and raw-nerve emotions, it remains the single best album I've ever heard.<br /><br />Johnny Cash is not only the real deal, but with this album he broke the mold. Do I like the album? Yeah, kind of :)<br /><br />Jeff Wignall<br />WPKN Radio (Bridgeport, CT)<br /><br />Author, The Joy of Digital Photographye hours a day. Somehow the loneliness of that environment matches this album. It was like having Cash beside me in the car. Again, even \\"Desperado\\" a song that I wish had never gotten ruined by overplay on commercial radio, was so riveting I had to play it over and over.     That Cash was nearly alone in the studio when he recorded much of this CD is very obvious: this is a man saying goodbye to his old friends, and to himself.     The next time I was on the radio I went on the air and said that I was going to play some songs from the best album I'd ever heard. My listeners know me as a wall-climbing Van Morrison fan, so I'm sure they thought it was something new from The Man. But it was this Cash album. Of course, Cash died about the same time that the album came out, I think, so it became his musical epilogue. So be it. How many artists go out with the best work of their careers warm in their hands--especially after a 50 year career?     My feelings about this album remain. Though I find it difficult to listen to because it evokes a lot of saddness and very coarse and raw-nerve emotions, it remains the single best album I've ever heard.     Johnny Cash is not only the real deal, but with this album he broke the mold. Do I like the album? Yeah, kind of :)    Jeff Wignall  WPKN Radio (Bridgeport, CT)    Author, The Joy of Digital Photography

However, I think the thing I like the most about his album, is how his lyrics flow together so well. His multiple rhyming bars and his abilitly to flow from one line to the next is just remarkable. The only rappers I think I could put in his league are Biggie and Rakim. I think it's evident that rappers' first albums are always the best because of the time they dedicate to try to make it big. Illmatic and Ready to Die prove that. <br /> <br />The beats on the album are actually pretty good compared to other beats recorded around the same time. There are no songs where I could just listen to the beat by themselves, but they all work well with Nas rapping over them. The biggest problem by far with the album, in my opinion, has to be the hooks. They all pretty much suck, but it just lets you focus more on the verses, which are unmatched.

B000301YY8|2.0|James Blunt intrigued me after a performance on Saturday Night Live. His distinctive voice - which many consider a drawback - was actually the thing that drew me in. I found it hard to classify him based on the show, so I decided to buy Back to Bedlam.  <br /> <br />Many reviews of this CD are overwhelmingly positive, yet there are few clues about the reviewers themselves. They compare Blunt to Elton John, Bob Dylan, even the Beatles - lofty ideals to be sure (and WAY off-track in my opinion). But I wondered where the obvious comparison to Nick Drake was - Blunt's incomparable predecessor in the British, guitar-playing, heartfelt, tragic troubadour department. Even his album cover harkens back to Drake's persona. His absence in this group of references made me a little suspicious. As soon as I purchased the CD, I understood why. <br /> <br />Back to Bedlam is total teenybopper pop and not an inkling more. I realize this type of pop has its place, but I was expecting something more and was really disappointed. The reviews here speak of deep philosophical thought, brilliant songwriting, stellar production. I found the opposite to be true. While Blunt may certainly evolve in the future, to me his songwriting is immature and lacks any kind of complexity. The lyrics and rhymes are obvious and simplistic, the melodies and structures totally predictable.  <br /> <br /> I might have swooned over Blunt 25 years ago. It's perfect for teenaged girls. If you are one, or have one, I'd buy it. But if you are a discerning and experienced music fan, I'd steer clear. You can find real innovative songwriting, incredible arranging and production and lots of raw talent in artists of this genre such as Sufjan Stevens (Illinois), Elliot Smith, Franz Ferdinand and countless others. As well as, of course, the original - Nick Drake.

0142000663|5.0|The crops are all in and the peaches are rotting,<br /><br />The oranges are piled in their creosote dumps.<br /><br />They're flying 'em back to the Mexican border<br /><br />To pay all their money to wade back again.<br /><br />My father's own father, he waded that river,<br /><br />They took all the money he made in his life;<br /><br />My brothers and sisters come working the fruit trees,<br /><br />And they rode the truck till they took down and died.<br /><br />Some of us are illegal, and some are not wanted,<br /><br />Our work contract's out and we have to move on;<br /><br />Six hundred miles to that Mexican border,<br /><br />They chase us like outlaws, like rustlers, like thieves.<br /><br />We died in your hills, we died in your deserts,<br /><br />We died in your valleys and died on your plains.<br /><br />We died 'neath your trees and we died in your bushes,<br /><br />Both sides of the river, we died just the same.<br /><br />Is this the best way we can grow our big orchards?<br /><br />Is this the best way we can grow our good fruit?<br /><br />To fall like dry leaves, to rot on the topsoil,<br /><br />And be called by no name except \\"deportee\\"?<br /><br />Substitute \\"county line\\" for \\"Mexican border\\" and \\"Okies\\" for \\"deportees\\" and Woody Guthrie's poem, later sung to music, becomes a nearly perfect summary of Steinbeck's GRAPES OF WRATH.  This powerful novel vividly portrays a universal crisis of humankind, a crisis that remains as destructive today as when Steinbeck undertook to illuminate it for all those who dared to read.  Massive disparity of wealth in a society is far more than an economic conundrum. It has the power to destroy self-images, families, and lives.  It has the power to confuse honest laborers, to rouse them to helpless anger, and finally to sink them into abyssal despair.<br /><br />Industrialization drives sharecropper families from the land that they have tilled, harvested, bled upon, dropped sweat into, and been buried in for generations. Severed from the anchor they have always known, the families become wanderers, searching for a way and a place to survive.  They become the \\"have nots\\" of American society, feared and shunned by the \\"haves.\\"  Soulless land companies, banks, and agricultural industries are great, faceless controlling forces that exploit the landless and then drive them elsewhere.  How do ignorant sharecroppers fight such exploitation?  Mortals might as well take up arms against a malevolent deity.  The totality of despair created by such an economic system can hardly be imagined by one who has not experienced it.<br /><br />Is there no way out?  Steinbeck suggests that there is perhaps one hope.  If the migrant poor will only stick together, cooperate and support one another in solidarity, create a union of workers, then the impersonal corporate giants must listen. If two hundred men speak as one, the voice becomes loud enough to demand fair and humane treatment.  Easier said than done, especially when those who would speak of this aloud are jailed, beaten, and murdered by the giants' \\"hired guns.\\"<br /><br />This discussion suggests the essential difference between GRAPES OF WRATH and Steinbeck's other novels. The others paint struggles of mankind against the background of an amoral universe in which irony often distorts the outcome.  This one paints struggles of the \\"common man\\" against profit-and-loss ledgers of the agricultural industry.  It is brutal in its portrayal of how the \\"system\\" methodically destroys families, and it is equally brutal in its portrayal of the fear engendered in economically comfortable men by the influx of those who are in need. In the inevitable confrontation that follows, the veneer of civilization is replaced by stereotyping, then by hatred of the stereotype, and finally by repression of Americans by Americans.<br /><br />Yet, Steinbeck allows us to hope.  After Casy, the canny former preacher who finds courage to lead a strike against inhumane treatment of workers, lies in the mud with his skull crushed, Tom Joad leaves his crumbling family, vowing to follow Casy's vision.  Casy and Tom are our \\"Joe Hills\\":<br /><br />\\"The copper bosses killed you, Joe;<br /><br />They shot you, Joe\\" says I.<br /><br />\\"Takes more than guns to kill a man,\\"<br /><br />Says Joe, \\"I didn't die\\"<br /><br />Says Joe, \\"I didn't die\\"<br /><br />And standing there as big as life<br /><br />And smiling with his eyes,<br /><br />Says Joe, \\"What they can never kill<br /><br />went on to organize,<br /><br />went on to organize.\\"<br /><br />From San Diego up to Maine,<br /><br />in every mine and mill,<br /><br />where workingmen defend their rights,<br /><br />It's there you'll find Joe Hill,<br /><br />It's there you'll find Joe Hill!<br /><br />Now, who should read GRAPES OF WRATH?  Is anyone concerned with the plight of the common workingman or woman?  Is anyone concerned about the effects of industrial globalization?  Is anyone concerned about the final impact of the \\"Wal-Martization\\" of America?  Is anyone concerned when fertile fields lie fallow or, perhaps worse yet, are converted to barren asphalt-covered flats?  If anyone cares, read the novel.  If one is financially secure and therefore  does not care about such things, then he especially should read the novel, for then maybe, just maybe, he will begin to care.s skull crushed, Tom Joad leaves his crumbling family, vowing to follow Casy's vision. B000000OSE|5.0|Guns N' Roses' two 1991 Use Your Illusion albums have somewhat of a bad reputation for a number of reasons. First, the idea of releasing two separate albums simultaneously seemed dubious to many. The two albums were both 70 minutes long and loaded with several \\"epic\\" ballads that stretched out to nearly ten minutes. This gave the records a rather pompous, overly ambitious feel to some. Second, by 1991, a new wave of \\"alternative\\" rock bands were becoming popular such as Pearl Jam, Nirvana and Soundgarden. Therefore a lot of people felt that Guns N' Roses was too linked to the 1980s to still be relevant, and that they needed to step aside and make way for \\"grunge\\". Third, Use Your Illusion 1 and 2, as previously mentioned are both 70-minute albums and a lot of people feel that they are laden with filler. A lot of people say that if the band had trimmed some of the filler and released only one album, they would have had another masterpiece on their hands.     Over a decade later, it's a bit easier to look at this record and its counterpart with more objectivity. Personally, I only partially agree with the above assertions. I have no problem with the epic songs. Guns N' Roses understandably did not want to simply follow-up their classic debut, Appetite for Destruction, with a record that sounded exactly the same. They, or Axl Rose at least, wanted to change directions a bit and evolve musically. As far as any complaints about ballads, well the band's biggest hit was a ballad - Sweet Child O' Mine. That song proved that GNR was perfectly capable of recording a sincere ballad while still rocking like mad. While Use Your Illusion does have its share of ballads, there are many excellent hard rockers as well. As for the band being inexorably linked to the 1980s, that's merely a matter of timing, and not any fault of theirs. Guns N' Roses came along in the midst of \\"hair metal\\" and taught all those drag queens what real rock and roll was like. They were one of the few late '80s bands to be rooted in classic rock. With influences such as Aerosmith, The Stooges, AC/DC, Judas Priest, MC5, Nazareth and the Sex Pistols, Guns N' Roses brought '70s hard rock into the '80s.     As far as the albums containing filler, I would say that's true of Use Your Illusion II. However, Use Your Illusion I consists almost entirely of excellent, first-rate material. It is the better of the two albums, and while it is a bit long, it is an excellent rock album that should not be overlooked. The album kicks off with Right Next Door to Hell, a rapid-fire rocker that rocks harder than anything on Appetite for Destruction. Perfect Crime is another great hard rocker that would have fit in perfectly on Appetite. Don't Cry is a great ballad in the vein of Sweet Child O' Mine and one of the album's biggest hits. Bad Obsession is one of my favorite songs on the album. It's one of the bluesiest songs that GNR has ever recorded. It has a definite Rolling Stones/Aerosmith type feel complete with harmonica and a slide-guitar solo. Double Talkin' Jive is a fast hard rocker from Duff McKagan that really cooks. November Rain is a true GNR classic. One of their biggest hits and finest compositions. In true power ballad, it starts out slow and somber then builds to an awesome climax with stunning guitar solo by Slash. The Garden is a fine mid-tempo rocker featuring guest vocals by Alice Cooper. Don't Damn Me is another favorite of mine. Great guitar riff and honest lyrics from Axl. Coma ends the album on a high note. It's a very long song, but it's riveting and one of the album's best.     Use Your Illusion I is an excellent rock album that anyone who loves Guns N' Roses should not be without. Guns N' Roses was much more than just Appetite for Destruction. You're denying yourself some excellent music if you ignore this CD and Use Your Illusion II. It's truly a tour-de-force that the band put their hearts and souls into. Axl's lyrics and vocals are potent and hard-hitting as always, rhythm guitar from Izzy Stradlin and Slash is thick and meaty as always, and Slash's guitar solos are simply stunning. This album is almost worth listening to just for Slash's guitar playing. Just amazing. If you consider yourself any kind of Guns N' Roses fan, do not overlook this album. It is a masterpiece of modern hard rock.

This tri-fold \\"Collector's Edition\\" contains 2 discs - 23 total songs, approx 71 minutes on disc 1, and approx 62 minutes on disc 2. There is a single disc version available as well featuring only 14 of the same songs here (the bigger hits perhaps?)... but I recommend the 2 disc set due to the songs that you'd be missing (namely \\"Sin City\\", \\"Let There Be Rock\\", \\"High Voltage\\", \\"Jailbreak\\" and \\"Are You Ready\\"). Recorded during the 'Razor's Edge World Tour' in 1990-91 (153 concerts in 21 different countries). The disc also contains a 14-page booklet, with some history, song listing, and band pictures. Label - Sony.<br /><br />COMMENTS: It's been a long 14 years since AC/DC has put out a live album (\\"If You Want Blood You've Got It\\" in 1978)... in my mind, too long. So much of AC/DC's music is in your face rock and roll. It's pure, raw, bluesy, and best played loud. They're great on stage, they work the crowd, and if you've ever been to one of their concerts you know what I mean. The rhaspy bravado of screamer Brian Johnson really goes a long way. At first glance in the store, I though this might be their 'Monsters Of Rock' concert from Donnington (of the same year) - but it's not. The 23 songs here are taken from all over the globe. Disc 1 features some great tunes with highlights being the opener \\"Thunderstruck\\", \\"Sin City\\", \\"Heatseeker\\", \\"The Jack\\" and the 14+ minute \\"Jailbreak\\". Disc 2 has more classic material with the highlights being the 10+ minute \\"High Voltage\\", the 12+ minute \\"Let There Be Rock\\", or the closer \\"For Those About To Rock\\" with the cannons blasting. AC/DC had a resurrected career and tour with the success of \\"The Razor's Edge\\" album (featuring the mega hits \\"Thunderstruck\\" and \\"Moneytalks\\"), and this LIVE album captures it. Awesome song list. Great sound. Nicely packaged. Great disc(s).it. Awesome song list. Great sound. Nicely packaged. Great disc(s).

B000BVEKO0|5.0|Coming off a mediocre \\"Take A Look In The Mirror\\" and the departure of Brian \\"Head\\" Welch, KoRn have gone back to the drawing board. I had high hopes for this album even though their past two albums have been sub-par, I guess it was because of all the hype. KoRn promised a different sound and also a different kind of heavy, and they have delievered in every way. This is without question KoRn's most experimental album to date, even more experimental than \\"Untouchables.\\" Some of the songs are even more atmospheric with the industrial touches such as \\"Throw Me Away\\" and \\"Tearjerker.\\" Some are just downright heavy and sound amazing such as \\"Hypocrites\\" and \\"Liar.\\" It's kind of tiring to see reviews that bash a KoRn album if they try something new because they \\"depart from their roots\\" and then bash them again when they try to stay true to their roots because they don't evolve or expand. \\"Other Side\\" will also get a lot of mixed reviews because this is a whole new direction in sound for KoRn, but to me it's a very good one, this album should have followed up \\"Untouchables.\\" I find this release to be their best since \\"Follow the Leader\\" not to mention also they're most creative. To all of the \\"old school\\" fans, either quit living in the past or move on, everyone is tired of hearing you bash KoRn because they don't sound like they did in 1994. KoRn tried to be like that with \\"Take A Look...\\" but John's voice has evolved and just doesn't pack that anger punch like it used to. I'm glad to see he's working on his voice to hit those high notes and pitches, he doesn't have the best voice in the world but it fits KoRn very well. Also, the songs we're mixed and co-written by Matrix and Ross and they are easily distinguishable in who mixed which song. All of the guitar and drum driven tracks are produced by the Matrix, and all the industrial driven tracks are produced by Ross. I prefer the Matrix over Ross myself but that doesn't make Ross's tracks bad. All in all a very solid release from KoRn that should keep the long time fans happy and maybe pull in some new ones. Highly Recommended.

This is without question KoRn's most experimental album to date, even more experimental than \\"Untouchables.\\"  Some of the songs are even more atmospheric with the industrial touches such as \\"Throw Me Away\\" and \\"Tearjerker.\\"  Some are just downright heavy and sound amazing such as \\"Hypocrites\\" and \\"Liar.\\"  It's kind of tiring to see reviews that bash a KoRn album if they try something new because they \\"depart from their roots\\" and then bash them again when they try to stay true to their roots because they don't evolve or expand.  \\"Other Side\\" will also get a lot of mixed reviews because this is a whole new direction in sound for KoRn, but to me it's a very good one, this album should have followed up \\"Untouchables.\\"  I find this release to be their best since \\"Follow the Leader\\" not to mention also they're most creative. I'm glad to see he's working on his voice to hit those high notes and pitches, he doesn't have the best voice in the world but it fits KoRn very well.  Also, the songs we're mixed and co-written by Matrix and Ross and they are easily distinguishable in who mixed which song.  All of the guitar and drum driven tracks are produced by the Matrix, and all the industrial driven tracks are produced by Ross.  I prefer the Matrix over Ross myself but that doesn't make Ross's tracks bad.  All in all avery solid release from KoRn that should keep the long time fans happy and maybe pull in some new ones.  Highly Recommended.

0307263118|5.0|John Banville puts his readers on notice within the first ten pages, with words such as `leporine' and `apotropaic,' that we are securely in the hands of a master of the English language.  And there's a safe, cozy feeling knowing that our guide on this literary journey is fully in command of his linguistic tool set.<br /><br />Go ahead, look `em up.  And you may want to keep that dictionary handy.<br /><br />Reading a book like this is a beautiful reminder of the difference between good and great fiction.  Great fiction is about more than just plot and characters and voice; it's about every single word being there for a reason.  It's the blending of both the art and the science of writing.  And it isn't achieved all that often.<br /><br />In The Sea, the story flows like a nostalgic, melancholy reverie, floating back and forth between past and present.  The writing is more poetry than prose.  I rarely put much stock in the blurbs and sound bites on a novel's cover, but in this case the Sunday Telegraph's reference to Banville as \\"the heir to Nabokov\\" is right on.  Like Nabokov, every word feels pregnant with meaning and power.  Every few moments there is a passage so exquisitely written that you find, at the end of it, that you have been holding your breath throughout.  Like this one:<br /><br />\\"In those endless October nights, lying side by side in the darkness, toppled statues of ourselves, we sought escape from an intolerable present in the only tense possible, the past, that is, the faraway past.  We went back over our earliest days together, reminding, correcting, helping each other, like two ancients tottering arm-in-arm along the ramparts of a town where they had once lived, long ago.\\"<br /><br />You may find yourself re-reading passages in order to savor the full effect, or reading out loud to yourself so that you might feel the sensuality of the language on your tongue.  This is a book that begs to be read slowly.<br /><br />In a book like this, plot seems secondary, almost unnecessary.  And yet there is also an exquisite story here, in fact two stories, a widower's struggle to escape the grief of his wife's passing, and a young boy's coming of age over the course of a summer.  Both stories unfold at the sea, in the same place in fact, though separated chronologically by fifty years.  And as the two stories gracefully intertwine, they bear witness to the powerful connection we all maintain to our past.<br /><br />Still have that dictionary handy?  Try `anabasis' and `aperus' - those are from the last ten pages.  Man this guy is good.is, plot seems secondary, almost unnecessary. His is a rougish performance filled with adolescent bravado and impish cuteness. An all-round exceptional cast of actors whose credits rarely include children's stories, this film is a delight, and truly a film that is aimed at young as well as older audiences who might accompany them.    The subtext of the ambiguous \\"hidden kiss\\" that lurks in the corner of Wendy's full lips is sensuous and innocent as it should be. It is this element of budding sexuality depicted with tact that has no comparison in the innuendo-heavy bathroom humor typical of young teen oriented comedies that Hollywood produces ad nauseum. Wendy's attraction to Peter's seductive grin is a kind of first blush that is girlish and childish, but also exciting. Wendy's desire to follow Pan to the land of the lost boys where she will tell them stories of Cinderella and be a surrogate mother is playing at maturity but also flirtatious and filled with a curiosity of budding womanhood. It is an element rarely handled in film interpretations of children's genre, however, it was an unmistakable element always just below the surface in period 19th century literature. Films such as Hook and Disney's cartoonish version overlook the complex Victorian social elements that emerge.     All the young actors in this film are natural, enormously believable, and attractive. So believable are their adventures in Neverland against Hook and with Princess Tiger Lily and the Indians that we too are swept up joining the experience of fighting with swords and flying. This is heady fantasy and the director never permits the cast to become over the top.  In the lush setting of Neverland, the visual sensation is rich as color is used to convey more than just the physical.    Superb performances from versatile veteran actors such as Lynn Redgrave, a biddy aunt are created from the film but feel true to the storyline. However, it is a great character actor Jason Isaac doing double duty portraying the nebbish clerk-father James Darling, and the dastardly, evil, snidely Capt. Hook who fills the screen with vileness and a touch of distilled red-eye poison. Isaac's tragic/comedic villainous character presentation of Hook has the right mix of  believable and fearsome elements. It is only in the overlooked, \\"An Awfully Big Adventure\\" does an actor's performance of Hook by brilliant Alan Rickman have the similar bravado, weight, and believable panache. Isaac should have been acknowledged for his excellent work in the difficult dual role.    The film conveys the transitory beauty of childhood on the brink of change with deft handling, scenic drama, and swashbuckling action that is complex as well as bittersweet. As Peter and Wendy dance in the moonlight, their awareness of growing emotional maturity, although seductive, remains an enemy of Peter. His adamant decision never to grow up, to love and experience feelings as an adult is filled with layers of meaning that may be lost on younger audience members. And, when Hook informs Wendy the elements she is attracted to in Peter are the \\"riddle of his being,\\" he is also hinting at Freudian allusions to the father- daughter complex as well.     Wendy can not have feelings for the boy Peter as a lover, nor is she permitted to be attracted to the duo character of the father-enemy, James Darling/Capt. Hook. She is in limbo until imparting on Peter her hidden kiss, a gift that can only be given once in a young girl's life. Wendy's story is one of the inevitable. She must leave Neverland to be the woman, the storyteller, and the mother-wife.  Ultimately, it is only in Neverland that faeries exist and childhood is forever.  And,  where a thimble is a precious and powerful thing.

076790592X|5.0|\\"You have to find what's good true and beautiful in your life as it is now.  Looking back makes you competitive.  And, age is not a competitive issue.\\" (Albom 120).  Mitch Albom is an outstanding author as he uses his own life experience to bring this book to life; his book deserves a five star rating.  Diagnosed with (ALS), also known as Lou Gehrig's disease, Morrie Schwartz was taught a lesson, but he was not the only one, as his student Mitch learns many lessons from regular Tuesday meetings.  While Mitch and Morrie prepare for their final thesis about the true values and lessons of life, a strong bond continues to grow.  Despite in-depth coverage concerning many \\"lessons of life,\\" there are some disappointing absences of content: Albom does not really touch on Morrie's relationship with his children and what they thought of their strong - willed <br />father and his opinions on life.  Readers of all ages could be drawn in as this captivating story unfolds; they will be prompted to contemplate you stop to think what life really is like or what it could turn out to be. <br /> With Morrie withering away from his illness his personality and outlooks on life are still carried on through his strong sense of knowledge and teaching.   Morrie was characterized as a loving, caring, knowledgeable, and good listening soul. \\"When Morrie was with you, he was really with you.  He looked you straight in the eye, and listened as if you were the only person in the world\\" (Albom135).   As Mitch visits with Morrie he learns lessons concerning love, emotions, the fear of death, and society today and how people fulfill their life in the wrong ways.  Morrie wanted his lessons to live on even after he was gone, so Mitch would bring his tape recorder every Tuesday and he would record Morrie's teachings so they could be remembered. <br /> One weakness the book had was the fact that Morrie's children were left out of the story, perhaps because Morrie, despite his illness, did not want theworld to stop turning.   We are left to wonder what his children thought about Mitch and Morrie's relationship; were they jealous?  Did they have a close relationship such as their dad and Mitch?  I believe that this would have added a different side to the story, as there were many unanswered questions concerning this untouched aspect.  Otherwise that is the only disappointment I found from this book. This book is one book I could pick up and read numerous times in life comparing myself to Morrie and contemplating his perspective. <br /> Morrie was such an inspirational character that anyone would stop to evaluate his or her life after reading this book.  It could touch the heart of any age from twelve on up.  This book is a learning tool for anyone, as demonstrated by Morrie in the following suggestions. \\"Do the kinds of things that come from the heart.  When you do, you won't be dissatisfied, you won't be envious, you won't be longing for somebody else's things.  On the contrary, you'll be over whelmed with what comes back.\\" (Albom128).   This quote shows the value of life was taught so strongly in this book and how we should be thankful for what we have, learning not to be envious of others.  Morrie also teaches the importance of family life and marriage, being how sometimes people take loved ones for granted or are to selfish to love someone else.   <br /> Finally, Morrie's sayings will stick with readers for the rest of their days, as Mitch Albom does a wonderful job of using parallelism and making strong comparisons that leave an imprint on life. Tuesday's with Morrie not only changed the life of Mitch Albom but also, has changed the lives of  many others who have stopped to read this fascinating and heart wrenching story; about a dying man and his lessons that he wanted the world to hear.  <br />

6304936362|4.0|My first favorite television series was \\"Twelve O'Clock High\\" and I had at least two models of the \\"Memphis Belle\\" when I was kid, all of which simply reflects the fact that the B-17 Flying Fortress is my favorite airplane.  When I was a kid my family was driving through California and there was a B-17 parked out on somebody's front lawn on a ranch and for years I tried to figure out how to go back and see it.  A couple of decades later one of the few B-17s still flying came to the Zenith City and I finally got to go inside one (this big bombers are a lot smaller than I ever thought).  For all I know that particular B-17 ended up flying in the 1990 film \\"Memphis Belle.\\"  When I had occasion to drive through the city of Memphis, of course I made a point of visiting Mud Island where the \\"Memphis Belle\\" was on display (she was moved to the Air Force Museum in Dayton, Ohio this October).<br /><br />The \\"Memphis Belle\\" (Serial No. 41-24485) was one of 12,750 B-17 Flying Fortresses built by the Boeing Aircraft Company, but it was the most famous because it was the first heavy bomber to complete 25 combat missions over Hitler's Europe without losing a crew member.  The idea of 25 missions and going home was established by the bomber command as an incentive for air crews because morale was desperately low after the first three months of American combat flights over Europe during which eighty percent of the planes were shot down.  The \\"Belle\\" flew from November 7, 1942 to May 17, 1943 and its final flight is the fanciful subject of this film directed by Michael Caton-Jones (\\"Scandal\\") from the script by Monte Merrick (\\"Staying Together\\").<br /><br />That simply means that besides the fact that the \\"Memphis Belle\\" was named for a lady friend (Margaret Polk) of the pilot and that the art on the nose depicting the same (designed by the famous artist George Petty) there is nothing here that is historically accurate when it comes to that final mission, which was over Lorient, France and not Bremen, Germany (the \\"Belle\\" flew there on its 21st mission).  The names of the crew are all changed and I think the same applies to the plane's mascot, a Scotty Dog named \\"Stuka.\\"  So if you want something closer to the \\"true\\" story of the pilot Robert Morgan and the \\"Memphis Belle\\" you want to check out William Wyler's 1944 documentary \\"The Memphis Belle: A Story of a Flying Fortress.\\"<br /><br />What you have here instead is a Hollywood movie that celebrates the men who flew these bombers in World War II by incorporating a wide variety of clich&eacute;s from war movies involving airplanes.  Then there is the whole idea that Americans from all walks of life who have little in common besides a desire to get home alive band together to fight the Nazis.  So it is we have the young and recognizable faces of Matthew Modine as the business like pilot, Eric Stoltz as the poetic radio operator, Tate Donovan as the co-pilot who wants to actually do something before he goes home, D.B. Sweeney as the navigator who is convinced his number is up, Billy Zane as the bombardier who left medical school to fight, Sean Austin as the runt who is stuck in the ball turret, Reed Edward Diamond as the flight engineer, Courtney Gains and Neil Giuntoli as the bickering waist gunners, and Harry Connick as tail gunner and sometime crooner.<br /><br />Back at the base David Strathairn plays the commanding officer nervous about his boys getting back alive and John Lithgow is the public relations officer the Army has sent  to celebrate the final mission of the \\"Belle.\\"  Of course, it is hard to create tension given that most viewers know the \\"Memphis Belle\\" is remembered for completing that final mission, so any tension that is created tends to be somewhat artificial although there are some nice moments during the bomb run (the film might play better if it simply inspired by the \\"Belle\\" and they changed the name of the aircraft as well) .  But even if the \\"Belle\\" survives there areother several B-17 crews on the mission who will not.  Still, the idea that doing your duty could not just be dangerous but be outright suicidal is communicated, allowing Modine's character to explain the job to his nervous crew and underscore that Americans do not believe in collateral damage.  But what will probably stand out in this film is the grim lesson that Donovan's character learns when he tries to be a hero by doing somebody else's job.sion who will not.  Still, the idea that doing your duty could not just be dangerous but be outright suicidal is communicated, allowing Modine's character to explain the job to his nervous crew and underscore that Americans do not believe in collateral damage.  But what will probably stand out in this film is the grim lesson that Donovan's character learns when he tries to be a hero by doing somebody else's job.

B00005AR3G|4.0|\\"The Emperor's New Groove\\" is simultaneously the closest and most far removed for the current generation of Disney animated features from \\"Beauty and the Beast,\\" which enjoys the unique distinction of being the only such film ever to be nominated for a Best Picture Oscar.  It is the closest because it is about a royal pain who is turned into a creature, only the transformation was not intended to teach him a much needed lesson but rather to kill him (the spell goes awry), and he is not saved by a beautiful maiden but a big guy with lots of muscles (and a big heart).  However, that is not why this 2000 animated film is so far removed from \\"Beauty and the Beast.\\"  It is because this is not an animated cartoon that is going to make you cry, this is simply one that is going to try and make you bust a gut laughing.<br /><br />The story is set in South America, mainly because it is a different setting, which allows the Disney animators to reference the great Mesoamerican civilizations without actually having to pick one over the others.  Emperor Kuzco (voiced by David Spade) is the ruler of his kingdom and apparently has nothing more important to do than keep his groove going.  But then he makes the mistake of firing Yzma (voiced by the great Eartha Kitt), an old crone, who does not like being fired.  Helped, for lack of a better word, by a cook named Kronk (voiced by Patrick Warburton), Yzma plots to kill Kuzco.  Instead of killing the emperor and reducing the film to a strange little tragic tale the length of an old fashioned cartoon, Kuzco is turned into a llama.<br /><br />This should make an impression on Kuzco, but it really does not.  He is still consumed with his plan to build a summer palace called Kuzcotopia on a hilltop that gets a lot of sun.  The fact that Pacah (voiced by John Goodman) lives there with his pregnant wife, Chicao (voiced by Wendie Malick), and their children does not bother Kuzco. But then even young kids will figure out that Pacah is the hero of this particular Disney adventure. The fact that she gets turned into a cat at one point in the festivities is not so much an in-joke as an homage. B000BMSTMS|5.0|As long has KoRn has existed, most of their songs had to do with the theme of anger, anger, a bit more anger and some anger. Which got a little old for me, especially on their last full-length release, \\"Take A look in the Mirror\\", Which was supposed to be their big comeback album where they went back to their original sound, but, for people like me, ended up a huge dissapointment. <br /> <br />For those who don't know, soon before this CD was made, Head, a great guitarist for the band left for his religious beleifs, and then came the news that KoRn would be working with Producers who have worked with Hilary Duff and other Pop Artists, made me, a big fan of KoRn, very sceptical about the CD's release.  <br /> <br />Still nervous from the info surrounding the CD, I went to the store and picked it up, only to be amazed.  <br /> <br />The new sound is fresh, original and good. The new lyrics are both intelligently written and emotional, and the recording sounds great. <br /> <br />That is, of course, with an open mind. If your looking for another Nu-Metal rip off band with two power chords per song, look elsewhere.  <br /> <br />The highlights of this CD would be \\"Twisted Transitor\\", \\"Souvenir\\", \\"Throw me Away\\", \\"Love Song\\", \\"Open Up\\", \\"Liar\\", \\"For No One\\", and \\"Tearjerker\\". The only weak song I found was \\"Coming  Undone\\", which was a little too repetetive for my taste, but it dosn't ruin the album.  <br /> <br />It's true that this album does have a MAJOR industrial influence too it, but it works really well with the music and dosn't distract from it or overcome the Heavy part of it. I applaud the new, dare i say more \\"mature\\" direction KoRn have taken with their music.  <br /> <br />And now, for my song review: <br /> <br />Twisted Transistor: Their single, very weird lyrics but nonetheless a fun song. <br />Politics: The music is really good here, lot's of effects and stuff.  <br />Hypocrites: One of the Heavier songs on this album, good guitar work.  <br />Souvenir:Very catchy, the lyrics and breakdown in this song are the highlights.  <br />10 or a 2 way: The first of the weaker songs on the album in my opinion, average song. <br />Throw Me Away: THIS is KoRn, Great Chorus and Jon's singing is amazing.  <br />Open Up: Another Amazing song, everything is perfect in this song.  <br />Coming Undone: Good guitar, but other then that very repetetive. <br />Getting Off: Another Heavy one, a pretty good song if you can get past the chorus of \\"Getting Off\\" repeated a million times... <br />Liar: Amazing Heavy song off this album, another one where everything seems to fit perfectly together.  <br />For No One: Diffrent, fast and fun but not a highlight or weak, just average.  <br />Seen it All: Their most Industrial strengthed song on the album, it turned out pretty decent in my opinion.  <br />Tearjerker: Their sad song, the vocals are really good and so are the lyrics.  <br /> <br />So in conclusion I very highly recomend this CD to any old KoRn fan or new, or just someone looking for something new and original with an open mind.  <br /> <br />Congrats Korn, this is your best CD yet.
B00004T8RK|5.0|This album immediately jumped up to the #3 spot of their first six records I own. It's only behind Ten and Vs.(current fav) and might have a chance to go higher. That being said, most people seem to need some time with this album to fully appreciate. I'll tell you how I came about to enjoying it right away. <br /> <br />To start, the opening song blared out of my speakers in my car as the bass shook the mirrors. That doesn't happen too often in my car but it was a rather explosive way to start the album. The song itself didn't stick with me until a few more listens but it's one of the better songs and opening songs in PJ's catalogue. The next two songs, God's Dice and Evacuation, are nothing too special and are just all around quality songs.  <br /> <br />The album really started for me with Light Years. Not only does it perfectly capture the feeling of the artwork PJ have become known for(heavy astronomy theme with explanations to the pictures in the back of the booklet) but it's the best song on the album. It's a slower song that as far as I can tell is about a woman close to the band that died. The chorus quickly got me moving and one of the best lines Ed has ever written is here as \\"We were but stones, your light made us stars\\". After that song blew me away I was hit by another strong song called Nothing As It Seems. The guitar riffs and short solos are breathtaking and really make this song work along with Eddie's haunting vocals. <br /> <br />'Thin Air' ups the tempo a little bit and is yet another strong song. At this point I've heard three very strong songs follow three average to good openers. I hoped it wouldn't end there and I was rewarded with Insignificance. The chorus is very memorable and Ed has a few of his signiature wails and such throughout. The next song, Of A Girl, is probably THE song that gets me moving the most. The beat is just amazing to go along with some great lyrics and vocals. I really can't do this song justice with words, you need tohear it.  <br /> <br />Though this album has some political threads it's far from overbearing. As a Republican for the most part I'm never offended throughout this album. I chalk that up to strong, open lyrics that don't try to bash me over the head. This is where Grievance comes in. Despite the message I must say this song has really grown on me to be one of my favorites. It's more of the bridge at the end of the song that gets me. 'Rival' has an interesting beginning of what sounds like 2 dogs fighting or one just growling. It kind of surprised me at first but the song that follows is good enough to make me forget it.  <br /> <br />Sleight of Hand is a hit or miss song with people. For those that don't know, the album is called Binaural because of the way it was recorded. It was meant to listen to with headphones and if you don't have two working speakers or ear pieces you're only going to get half of the songs. Sleight of Hand is really the perfect song to demonstrate this and I can't describe it other than 'haunting'. Soon Forget is a vintage quarky PJ song that isn't too long. You might very well soon forget it but it's not bad. Parting Ways is a solid closer though far from their best way to wrap up an album. <br /> <br />All in all, this album to me was much heavier and had a greater variety of great songs than any of their previous three albums(which are all great in themselves). If you find yourself having a hard time getting into this just give it more listens. It's defintely one of their most underrated albums and needs to be any every PJ fans collection. As always if you're new to Pearl Jam start with Ten and work your way up.
