B000002MIF|5.0|Much of what the Smiths represent has already been addressed in these reviews, so I will share only a few other things in addition to personal recollections of the band.<br /><br />The Smiths were all too brief a force in music, but what they lacked in time, they made up for in fecundous output. Few groups recorded as much or as brilliantly as the Smiths did in their four year tenure as kings of british pop. Musically, no one even came close to the sheer beauty of what Johnny Marr created. Any guitarist worth his salt will admit as much, but music was only half of the equation. Morrissey is, like Robert Smith and Ian McCullough, a wordsmith of the highest order, creating rarely seen literary parallels between himself and the writers he so often championed.<br /><br />As for the man's sexuality.... well, for all of the press it has received over the years, it was simply irrelevant to his craft, and he only underscored that notion by remaining aloof and deliberately ambiguous on the subject. For those who actually remember the Smiths while they were together, Morrissey was a declared celibate throughout his partnership with Marr, Joyce and Rourke, having given himself over to his art to such a degree that, when Johnny split, the man was literally bedridden.<br /><br />The Smiths. Where would I have been without them? Some like to talk of this group as depressing but they got me through some very bad times indeed. Rarely had I heard anyone speak so honestly about his feelings... and those lyrics often reminded me that I was not the only one out there suffering. As unbelievable as it may sound, I think this band may have actually saved my life, and it's hard to speak objectively of such an influence... but anyone who has been desperate and heard the optimism in 'please, please, please...' will understand.

076790592X|5.0|\\"Death ends a life, not a relationship\\" (Albom 174).  Tuesdays with Morrie is a well written biography by Mitch Albom and deserves a four and one-half-star rating for the lessons taught by Morrie Schwartz.  Tuesdays with Morrie is an old dying man's autobiography written by Detroit sportswriter, in which he described important lessons in life.  Ultimately, the strongest point about this biography involves lessons about relationship, the importance of life, and ways to deal with death; the weakest point is that the original meeting transcript is not included, and the appeal of this biography is to readers of all ages, as the author talks about the real meaning of love, emotions and friendship.  <br /> The strongest point about this novel is Morrie's philosophies, all of which stem from life experiences.    From Ted Koppel's show, Mitch found that his college `coach' was very sick, and he therefore decided to visit him on a Tuesday.  After a few Tuesdays' visits, Mitch became interested in Morrie's philosophies and he continued to visit Morrie on every Tuesday until Morrie died.  During his visits with Morrie, his \\"coach\\" taught he important lessons in life:  feelings, regrets, death, family, emotions, money, love, marriage, culture, forgiveness, having a perfect day, and the fear of aging.  Out of all the topics that they discussed, the chapter on forgiveness catches my eyes.  In this chapter, Morrie said, \\"Forgive yourself before you die.  Then forgive others.\\" (Albom 164).  Morrie explained this topic by giving his own life experience about his friend, \\"Norman\\".  When Norman failed to contact Morrie's wife following her serious operation.  In spite of Norman's attempt to makeup, Morrie was hurt from this incident and decided to drop their relationship.  After Norman's death, Morrie felt sad, because he never got to forgive Norman.   <br />This book is so good that I really have a hard time looking for the book's weaknesses.  After searching for a long time, the only weakness that I found is that Mitch did not present a full original transcript from the meetings with Morrie.  If the full transcript had been included in this book, they might have drawn a much better picture and the biographical account might have been even better.  I would like to see movie Tuesdays with Morrie and see if the original transcript was included and if it was, what difference it would make.    <br />This biography is appealing to people of all ages, because the author has talked about the real meaning of love, emotions and friendship.  Morrie knew that he was suffering from ALS (Amyotrophic Lateral Sclerosis) diseases and also knew the short time left in his life.  Instead of worrying about his life and making it worse, he chose to tell his life experience to Mitch.  Mitch did not have any contact with his brother, David, for a long time.  Mitch learned lot of lessons from his Tuesdays with Morrie and contacted his brother after Morrie passed away.        <br /> Tuesdays with Morrie is filled with emotions, love and common sense.  This book also tells that everybody should always keep in touch with old friends and enjoy their life at all ages.  Mitch Albom has done a fantastic job in including what he had learned from Morrie.  The story about Morrie was so good that in the year 1995, Ted Koppel had released three interviews in ABC's Nightline.  When Koppel ends his run on Nightline on November 22, the final show will feature an interview with Mitch Albom and highlights from the year 1995, during which the interviews with Morrie took place.  In personnel life, Koppel admires Morrie.  Morrie's positive and comic attitude for dealing with his disease can help people have a more an optimistic way to cope with their own sickness.  I liked this novel, because it reminded me not to take everything for granted, but to relish the moment, absorb it, learn from it and be thankful for it.  For example, I gave this novel to one of my close friends to read.  This novel is so emotional that she was crying while reading this novel.  Morrie is portrayed as someone who was respected in society, and his honesty and personality made me believe him as he was my own father.   <br />\\"Every night, when I go to sleep, I die.  And the next morning, when I wake up, I am reborn.\\"  -  Mahatma Gandhi                  <br />

B000005J08|5.0|John Zorn hails from New York and has been one of the most interesting and exciting figures in contemporary music for years.  He appears to be of limitless talent, acquiring quite a reputation for his wild eclecticism.  That eclecticism is wildly abundant on this fine, fine album, as Zorn and Company rage thru the music of Ornette Coleman, Henry Mancini, Ennio Morricone, John Barry, and of course Mr. Zorn himself.  They blaze through jazz, swing, blues, free jazz, noise, rock, thrash, and surf- often in the same song.  This is great music for today's attention-span addled human.  In fact, I think this would actually be a great album for youngsters with an interest in jazz to listen to.  It is fast moving, often changing, and definitely never boring.  I haven't listened to this CD for awhile (until today), and I forgot how enthralling it is.<br /><br />`Naked City' was my first John Zorn album and it remains my favorite (along with his Occult masterpiece I.A.O.).  This wonderful disc starts out with `Batman'; Zorn's uptempo envisioning of what Batman's theme should sound like- and it totally kicks ass.  This is followed by Morricone's `The Sicilian Clan'.  Zorn's saxophone sounds great on this track (and I usually HATE the saxophone).  Next up is `You Will Be Shot', a nifty Zorn original that changes just about every ten seconds; touching on rock, noise/thrash, and blues/swing.  I could go on and on; fruitlessly attempting to describe track after track.  That however is beginning to seem increasingly pointless as I listen to this spectacular album.  It sounds so clich&eacute;, but one must truly listen to this album for themselves to have any kind of understanding for how much ass it kicks.<br /><br />One of the things that Mr. Zorn seems to have a knack for, is assembling the right band for the right project (much in the same way Miles Davis did).  The band that he put together for `Naked City' was absolutely perfect, and up to the task of tackling these diverse, high energy arrangements.  Bill Frisell on guitar, Wayne Horvitz on keys, Fred Firth on bass, and Joey Baron on skins were the perfect partners in crime for this wicked creation.  I would've loved to catch this amazing band live.<br /><br />This is a hell of an album.  I own LOTS of music, and this is by far one of the most diverse releases I have.  Not many bands could pull off the ridiculous changes present here.  On paper, this should be a mess.  However thanks to John Zorn's vision and skill (and that of his band mates) this works wonderfully- way better than it should.  If you are interested in Zorn and have yet to delve into his intimidating and massive catalogue, this is a great place to start.  If you are a fan of Zorn, you undoubtedly have this excellent and timeless release.ments.  Bill Frisell on guitar, Wayne Horvitz on keys, Fred Firth on bass, and Joey Baron on skins were the perfect partners in crime for this wicked creation. If you are interested in Zorn and have yet to delve into his intimidating and massive catalogue, this is a great place to start.  If you are a fan of Zorn, you undoubtedly have this excellent and timeless release.
B0009A1AS2|4.0|Octavarium is a Dream Theater album that in many ways is unlike any of their previous albums. Of course, that's saying something when we're talking about a progressive rock outfit, but this album has a form and style unlike any other albums that they'd release (closest comparison is that of the first disk, Six Degrees of Inner Turbulence). The album has hard rockers, emotional ballads, and epics to boot. For that reason, if you were just trying out Dream Theater and are considering buying an album, I'd stop here first. <br /> <br />The album starts out with the rocker \\"The Root of All Evil\\", which is the third part in a series of songs that last was heard on \\"This Dying Soul\\" from Train of Thought. It's a great way to start the album as it fondly recalls the heavy rock of the previous album - but it doesn't quite dive that deep into the metal roots. After that, the album changes pace from one song to the other, often shifting styles. The 24 minute epic closer, \\"Octavarium\\", recalls some of Pink Floyd's Waters era work, while many of the other songs of the album often feel like modern interpretation of Styx or Kansas hits. <br /> <br />Instrumentally, this album really features a band that is turning all the wheels in harmony. As a result, there is no real performance in this album that stands out - not even Portnoy's drumming or Petrucci's guitar work - it all blends together to create a wall of sound and music. This can be good and bad, depending on your stance, as the vitruoso performances are somewhat missing here. Thusly said, there is still AMAZING work by all members of the band, especially from Jordan Rudess, who is ever so becoming the ideal Dream Theater keyboardist.  <br /> <br />This is not the prog-rock masterpiece that some have been waiting for, nor is it their best album - but \\"Octavarium\\" covers all the bases on Dream Theater's sound and concept, making this a great album to start out on.

0060825219|1.0|When I heard of the subtext, \\"A Novel of Obsession,\\" I was immediately interested as that subject, and its tendency to be construed as love, fascinates me.  In addition, I knew that the author was widely read and purchased throughout the world, so I figured I was in for a treat. <br />No - I was majorly disappointed. <br />The novel really seemed that it was striving to be about love, and what it should ideally be.  I would think a novel about love would have people who behaved lovingly, characters who the reader could love.  Instead, Coelho's book was a diatribe about what's wrong with society today, how loveless it can be.  Using the characters voices to lecture the reader about the wrongs of society (e.g. people are too focused on material things (this from a wealthy author/narrator!), people put on unsavory facades to protect themselves, people simply aren't honest with themselves or others - as if we didn't know this), he tediously repeated himself until it was annoying.  Perhaps, if the author wanted to teach about love, he could have expounded on what love is rather than what it isn't. <br />The simple writing was ok, but it's more enjoyable to read a self-help book if I want to learn about love. <br />And if someone is looking for books about obsession that are fun to read, try Joyce Carol Oates or A.M. Homes. <br />This is the first book I have read by Coelho; it will also be the last.

The story is of the four Pevensie children, Peter, Susan, Edmund and Lucy. The children are sent into the country during the bombing raids on London in World War II. The children arrive at the estate of the eccentric Professor Kirke. On a rainy day with nothing to do the children decide to play a game of hide and seek. As the children are hiding Lucy stumbles upon a room whose only contents are a blueglass bottle and and old wardrobe. Lucy chooses the wardrobe for a hiding place however as she manuevers through it she is magically transported to the land of Narnia, where it is always winter but never Christmas. In Narnia she meets the faun, Mr. Tumnus who tells her of the White Witches magical enchantment over Narnia and of the prophecy of Cair Parivel/Aslan's return which will bring the reign of the White Witch to its end. This is as far as I am going to go in giving away the plot of the book. This book is Number 2 in the series the Chronicles of Narnia. I would suggest when reading the books to read them in the order which Lewis wrote them. This story will delight both young and old alike. It is a classic to read over and over again with your family.
B000BMSTMS|5.0|I must say that the I thoroughly enjoy the new Korn album, \\"See You on the Other Side.\\"  As more Korn is always going to be better than the alternative, I truthfully find myself wondering if I am giving it two thumbs up simply because it is more music from the people I've grown up with or if the album is actually \\"good\\" in a substantial way that is worth not only my money, but more importantly my time.  This album is definitely a departure from everything Korn has done in the past, which is understandable since Korn lost a significant 20% of its band last February.   <br /> <br />While not nearly as raw and \\"crunching\\" as their last studio effort, \\"Take A Look in the Mirror,\\" or their first two albums, \\"Korn\\" and \\"Life is Peachy,\\" \\"SYOTOS\\" is both bludgeoning and thoughtfully driven in a manner that only Korn can do.  There are significantly more synth-type effects on this album which are for more reminiscent of early Nine Inch Nails or \\"Mechanical Animals\\" (late-90's) era Marilyn Manson, and possibly even some late Bowie or Bau Haus.  That said, the CD obviously cannot \\"rock\\" as hard as a CD that is loaded with multiple tuned-down-7-string guitars (which Korn has used since their conception).  Instead of focusing on Munky's solo guitar work, the CD seems more geared towards producing the heck out of Jonathan's voice while meshing Fieldy's bass and David's drums to an almost blurry conglomeration of sound that is not better or worse than Korn's previous rhythm sections, but considerably different.   <br /> <br />The CD is heavy.  Don't let my statements of \\"synth-effects\\" and solo guitar work fool you.  There are some extremely infuriated Jonathan Davis lyrics and couple with some very rage-ful screaming on Jon's part.  Fieldy and David lay a foundation that allows the music to churn forth from the musical equivalent of the gates of Hell.  And don't think that by \\"solo guitar work\\" I am referring to guitar-solos.  I'm not.  I'm simply stating that the interplay of Head and Munky's guitars is now obviously removed from the music and Munky's guitar is noticeably, and sadly on its own.  That is the problem with this album.  While it is disputable, I have always believed that their third album, \\"Follow the Leader,\\" was Korn's most musically brilliant album because the interwoven, sweeping, crushing guitars of Head and Munky were at their most extreme, most intricate, and most brilliant.  So many sounds that occur on that CD cannot remotely be emulated with only one axe-man, and that is where this CD suffers.  The excellent production, and in my opinion top-notch song-writing that make up \\"SYOTOS\\" cannot make-up for Head's absence.   <br /> <br />Still, the CD has some top-notch rocking, namely on the track, \\"Liar,\\" which features the first real Jon Davis impromptu, scat- noise-making freak out since \\"Follow the Leader,\\" and truthfully, it fits very well, and brings back the memories... <br /> <br />Anyway, that's my long review of this CD.  If you have listened to Korn since the beginning, do not expect what you heard in the beginning.  The band was forced to change with Head's departure, and their change is extremely evident.  If you've only listened since, say, \\"Untouchables,\\" than this CD may be more up your alley and what you're expecting from Korn.  All I can say is that I think it is well worth the time and money, and when I wanted to break some s*** tonight this CD already came in handy and provided me the ability to rock out instead of putting a hole in my wall.
B000BP86OG|2.0|When the Darkness exploded onto the scene with \\"Permmission\\", I was elated. After a decade of boring, mundane, alternative rock,(I.E.) Matchbox 20, Goo Goo Dolls, Coldplay,and so on, those English lads had me sold about one second into \\"Black Shuck\\". Then when I saw the video for \\"I Believe In A Thing Called Love\\" my respect for what they were doing only grew. Their cocky attitude, metallic image, and bombast, harkened back to the glory days of Zepplin,Kiss,Purple,AC/DC. Do not get me wrong, while their influences are evident, they are as original as tommorow's news. \\"Permission\\" was raw, the vocals wailed, the guitars ripped, and the production sounded \\"live in the studio\\". <br />Very in your face and organic. The songwriting smelled of leather and studs and flashpots, very moving. I give Permission 6 out of 5 anyday!! I have been eagerly anticipating the next offering from Justin and the boys. All I can say is how bitterly dissapointed I am with \\"One Way Ticket\\". Roy Thomas Baker is the worst thing that could possibly happen to The Darkness. Granted the songwriting was not as strong as \\"Permission\\", but what really killed the album was the fact that it was produced into oblivion. From layers upon layers of cheesy vocals in almost every chorus to the vasectomy that Dan's guitars have received, and \\"Girlfriend\\" makes George Michael's former band \\"Wham\\" sound like \\"Motorhead\\"!!! I know that this is an opinion that may be unpopular but, I think concerning the Darkness and rock/metal in general, less is more. The first Black Sabbath album was recorded in about eight hours according to Tony Iommi, need I say more. The guys can play, Justin can sing, it does not need to sound like a symphony honoring over-engineering. There is only one song on here that really grabs me and that is \\"Hazel Eyes\\". Other than that I could live with out ever hearing the others again. I hope next time aroung the lads will strip everything down, plug in, crank up and kick ass!!!!

So many sounds that occur on that CD cannot remotely be emulated with only one axe-man, and that is where this CD suffers. It's not what we heard in the beginning 12 years ago.  The band was forced to change with Head's departure, and their change is extremely evident.  If someone had only listened since, say their fifth album, \\"Untouchables,\\" than this CD may be more up their alley and what they're expecting from Korn.  All I can say is that I think it is well worth the time and money, and when I wanted to break some s*** tonight this CD already came in handy and provided me the ability to rock out instead of putting a hole in my wall.
B0009HLDFU|1.0|After reading about the Sony copy protection, there is no way I would buy this CD, even though I could play it on my CD player and run it into my computer and re-record it into standard audio files.  \\"Copy Protection\\" is just that - protection.  It is not \\"Copy Prevention\\", which is what the record companies want but cannot achieve.   <br /> <br />I understand that protection schemes that make it difficult to copy CD or DVD content will keep many individuals from copying that content, but even if only a few people go to the trouble to copy the content, it will soon be available to all online at some file-sharing site. <br /> <br />When the record companies make it difficult to use your own purchased music, then it's time to get it for free.  Hopefully this chapter in digital rights management will initiate a backlash against the RIAA and their losing battle against file sharing. <br /> <br />It's unfortunate that the artists get stuck in the middle of this tug of war.

B00080ZG10|4.0|The critics panned it, the audiences stayed away, the Academy didn't give it it's due - all in all \\"The Aviator\\" was a theater-goer's disappointment all around. So maybe I'm a sucker for a beautiful period-piece or maybe I just don't know a stinker when I see it, but I say that \\"The Aviator\\" was a superb film that I will watch again & again.<br /><br />Scorsese has made some mediocre movies (Gangs of New York & New York, New York come to mind) but this isn't one of them. The casting was brilliant, the cinematography inspired (watch how certain scenes of different time-periods have a \\"vintage\\" cinematic look to them), the music fabulous and the acting spot-on. For those who thought DiCaprio was too \\"baby-faced\\" or too young to play Hughes, take a look at a few Hughes photographs from the 30's and you will see that he was not the more rugged looking fellow from after his near-fatal plane crash. The baby-face works here and lends even more to the realism that DiCaprio gives to his portrayal of HH.<br /><br />I was captivated by Cate Blanchett's portrayal of Kate Hepburn as well as Kate Beckinsale's portrayal of Ava Gardner. Both actresses did a bang-up job of giving their characters a panache and fire that would have been necessary to match them against such a formidable lover and opponent as Hughes was to these two paramours. I was disappointed, however, that there was no mention made of Hughes' well known bisexuality and his alleged connection to the murder of rumored lover David Bacon (of The Masked Marvel serial movie fame). This could have been a great side story and I feel it was an opportunity missed by the screenwriters & the director.<br /><br />All in all, this is a movie I will list in my personal top 20 and once I own the DVD will watch over & over just as I do Tombstone, Titanic, Malcolm X & Wyatt Earp. If you haven't seen it because of the negative comments here or those given by critics at it's release give \\"The Aviator\\" an opportunity to captivate you. If you've seen it but disliked it because it's not an \\"action-packed-thriller\\" watch it again and make note of the fabulous sets, the wonderful cinematography, the music and the dead-on portrayal of Hughes by Leonardo DiCaprio. And for heaven's sake if for nothing else watch it for the slick flying and aviation engineering history lesson.<br /><br />This film is definitely a winner in my book!you. Yet Wayne then kills several cult members in the process of destroying the ceremony.  This makes sense how?  Not exactly well written.   <br /> <br />Yet these scenes as a cult knight, with Liam Neeson's cult leader, are the best in the film.  Batman's uniform, skills and mission all spawn directly from this cult, thus 'the dark knight.'  The film then diverges for 90 minutes and is pretty conventional Batman.  Only at the end does Batman meet his creator/nemesis in the form of the knight leader.  The whole film would have been more interesting if it kept its focus on how the cult's principles form Wayne's own, his break from the knights, and realization that the cult is responsible for many of the problems of the society it undermines. <br /> <br />While this is the 'hip' Batman, the Batman-Joker axis with Nicholson was truly more complex and interesting. Overall this album sounds somewhat experimental, and I hope that through this experiment Enya finds the best music she can produce.

B000002572|5.0|Unless you live in a cave, if you are over thirty and follow rock, you are surely quite familiar with Boston's self titled debut album (1976). With over seventeen million copies sold since its release, every song on the album is a staple on any given classic rock station. \\"Boston\\" stands as the epitome of 70s AOR rock.<br /><br />The greatness of the band's sound stems from Tom Scholz's innovative guitar work, Brad Delp's signature harmonies, and of course, great, great songs.<br /><br />Scholz, an inventor and a graduate of MIT with a degree in mechanical engineering was a self-taught guitarist. He built-upon the vocabulary established by Hendrix and Clapton, but eschewed all traces of the blues. Scholz relied upon sci-fi effects and the organ to round out the sound. It would be easy for a technical wizard to go overkill with the effects, but Scholz knows when enough is enough and that less is more.<br /><br />As technically gifted as Scholz is, the album wouldn't be half as great as it is without vocalist Brad Delp. His unique smooth harmonies give the songs melody and make them lush.<br /><br />Barry Goudreau, (guitar) Sib Hashian, (drums) and Fran Sheehan (bass) round out the band. Although how much they actually contributed to both the writing of the songs and the recording of the album is disputed.<br /><br />There is a reason that every song on this album is a staple on any given classic rock station. The songs all have great riffs, melody, color, and are intriguing. With its innovative guitar work, special effects, and organ solos, the album boarders prog-rock territory, but the songs are also crafted to be radio-friendly, so everything is easily palatable.<br /><br />Somewhere between the hard-rocking classic Aerosmith and Van Halen, and the power-pop of Journey and Foreigner, lay Boston. Fans of 70s metal like Black Sabbath, Judas Priest, Led Zeppelin, etc, may be turned off by the album's commercial, radio-friendly sound, and write the band off as \\"corporate pap,\\" but they would be missing out. As commercial as this album is, the songs are just too good to write off.<br /><br />The album's intelligent lyrics are also an asset of the album that shouldn't be overlooked. They're not really deep, or profound, but they are thoughtful. Some songs deal with universal themes. Especially \\"Piece of Mind,\\" which tackles the reasons for existence and questions the value of competition. \\"More than a Feeling\\" tries to explain the unexplainable, what it is about the things we value that make them so important. Other songs, like \\"Smokin'\\" and \\"Something about You\\" haven't aged as well and sound dated. Relics form a bygone era they may be, they are still great songs.<br /><br />Although Boston would go on to release several follow-up albums, the debut remains, by far, their best work. It's truly a classic album and belongs in every collection.out. As commercial as this album is, the songs are just too good to write off.     The album's intelligent lyrics are also an asset of the album that shouldn't be overlooked. They're not really deep, or profound, but they are thoughtful. Some songs deal with universal themes. Especially \\"Piece of Mind,\\" which tackles the reasons for existence and questions the value of competition. \\"More than a Feeling\\" tries to explain the unexplainable, what it is about the things we value that make them so important. Other songs, like \\"Smokin'\\" and \\"Something about You\\" haven't aged as well and sound dated. Relics form a bygone era they may be, they are still great songs.     Although Boston would go on to release several follow-up albums, the debut remains, by far, their best work. It's truly a classic album and belongs in every collection.

B00005JKJA|4.0|After watching this film, the viewer will no doubt feel as one does when one awakens from a nightmare. One scene cuts into the next with no apparent logic linking them together. Perhaps it's not as important to decode the mystery as it is to become attentive to mood and atmosphere. Light and dark play a key role in the movie, as does the eerie, impressionistic music. However, there is more darkness in Mulholland than there is light, and the movie ultimately becomes the unfolding of a nightmare, the dark, incongruous side of a mind driven by something sinister.    Naomi Watts plays the role of Betty beautifully, and Laura Harring's performance as the sultry Rita is excellent. It's too bad, though, that in the scene in which Rita is supposed to appear fully nude, her pubic region is optically censored: instead of seeing Rita's pubic hair, the viewer sees a blur in that area. One is reminded of those annoying nudity-obscuring mosaic patterns often seen on television. If anything is truly out of place in this movie, it's this ludicrous censorship. In an interview posted online, the director said that he had deliberately blurred Rita's bush out of concern that pictures of the actress au naturel would appear all over the Internet. How inane. Why do a nude scene in the first place? One star is deducted for stupidity. Nevertheless, Watts and Harring's love scenes, though brief, are very much erotic.     The DVD picture is crisp and provides great color contrast; the audio is clean, delivering good sonic detail in the music of Angelo Badalamenti. There are no chapters in this DVD, apparently because the movie is meant to be viewed from beginning to end without any breaks.

B000BM6AVA|3.0|I like System. I like their debut, love Toxicity, thought Steal This Album possessed some shining moments, and really enjoyed Mezmorize, which is still getting regular rotation in my player. Thus I come to Hypnotize, a cd that leaves me with mixed emotions. One thing is for certain, a quote I read by Malakian saying \\"I can get a lot crazier if I want to\\" proved to be a prophecy, as this cd takes System's trademark eclectic sound and progresses to the next level. I have listened to this cd 4 times through, and can label each with a certain feeling. 1: What is this? This is terrible!! 2: Well, I was a little harsh, maybe it just needs more listens to grow on me? 3: Oh now I get it, this is great! 4: Ok, this is decent, but its wearing on me fast. Thus I feel I can write a review \\"personal opinion for those that take these personally\\". Each System in the past seems to have a certain formula, which basically includes a number of songs that are easily accessible and radio friendly for what they play, such as Spiders, Chop Suey, Toxicity, and so on. Other tracks, whose names currently elude me and I apologize, are so far out there that only there that only a select number of people can truly appreciate their value. Mezmorize and Hypnotize seem to have taken on opposite aspects of that formula. With Mezmorize, you had a number of short tracks that though maintaining that System sound, were made in an easily listenable fashion. Mezmorize only required one listen, and you knew whether or not you liked it, at least in my case. Hypnotize on the other hand is all over the map, as though Malankian was given free reign over the entire process, and the result is a cd that takes numerous listens to uncover the various layers of noise in order to reach the basic underlying song. I could list each song in detail, but Im not out to convince you of anything, just state my thoughts. Suffice it to say, after my fourth listen I found myself trying to truly enjoy this cd, but unable to. Though not bad by any means, when compared to their other works I find it a little too extreme. Experimenation is wonderful, but hopefully they will return a tad bit to the more controled aspect of their sound that makes it an enjoyable experience for me. Thanks for reading.
4883191028|5.0|This textbook treats you like an adult who needs to speak in Japan. Each lesson introduces a few sentence patterns (i.e. grammar), gives relevant vocabulary, shows how to use it in useful situations, and provides lots of opportunity for practice.  <br />The vocabulary is excellent. It is aggressive: it requires us to learn about 50 new words per lesson, and reuses the vocab from previous lessons. It is also well chosen: the vocab logically matches the sentence patterns for that lesson so that we can learn and practice them together. But it doesn't ask us to memorize exhaustive themed categories (animals, etc...). It recognizes that many adults need to talk about \\"reports\\" more often than \\"horses\\". <br />Minna No Nihongo uses a lot of pairwork, and I have found it most effective studying in a class with a teacher or at least with a dedicated partner.  <br />The book itself is unique. I've never seen another like it. It is written for foreigners in Japan so it is written completely in japanese. Then students can buy the accompanying translation and grammatical notes (recommended) in the language of their choice (English, Korean, Chinese, etc.).

B000BJS4SU|4.0|After hearing the first two studio cuts on iTunes, I was hyped that this album would encompass 7-8 tracks of hard blues similar to his \\"Why Don't You Come When I Call\\" track with the addition of \\"Something's Missing\\" and \\"Daughters\\".  The end result is not that, but that is not to say the record itself is not a great representation of the live show and a showcase for Mayer's skills.  I'm not sure the many critics on this album appreciate the level of guitar work that is done here and how clean it comes out LIVE.  Detractors will say it's not SRV, well, no kidding.  But have you heard a better version of Jimi's \\"Wait For Tomorrow\\" until this?  The guitar work is spot on (again, especially live) and the solo rips harder than all others.  It seems blues 'aficionados' will discount Mayers chops as \\"too clean\\" and \\"too fast\\", but isn't that more entertaining to listen to and appreciate than BB King who plays one note and self-professed can strum a single chord?  Again, some people may have built this up to be the next \\"SRV-In The Beginning\\", but it's not.  It's a fine album of some straight up blues tunes, some blues-hybrids and some clever redos of both Mayer covers along with Jimi and Ray Charles.  And let's not forget, the first time that SRV played to the establishment in Montreaux, he was booed off stage.

0307276902|5.0|first of all, i want to address a couple of other reviews here.  it's true that james went it alone in his recovery in this book, but i'd like to point out that he did what worked, FOR HIM.  he ignored what wouldn't help him.  that's the smartest thing anyone can ever do.  the 12 steps and AA would have never worked for him and he knew it.  this book will really make you question the effectiveness of AA.  after all, this book chronicles the best clinic in THE WORLD, and what is their treatment rate?  a whopping 15%!!!  wow.  AA says in the same breath \\"addiction is a disease.  you can't resist the temptation.  you will always be an addict your whole life.\\"  they say you can't do anything about your addiction, and then they try to make you do something about it!  what???  it makes no sense whatsoever.  james frey has it right - addiction is a simple choice.  you either say yes i'll do this drug, or no i won't.  however you get to that point (through AA or some other way), it comes down to a simple choice.  you can choose to go to that bar, talk to that friend, or not.  as james says, cancer is a disease.  you don't choose to get cancer.  you do choose whether to use a drug, even if it's extremely hard not to.     anyway, this was a great book.  i read it in 3 days, all 400+ pages.  the writing style is very addicting to read.  yes, james has a selfish, rude attitude.  so what?  he's refreshingly honest and real.  he DOES remember the people who helped him in rehab.  he does care about other people.  but he doesn't accept any BS.  he DOES have humility.  he accepts that he is a pathetic drug addict who has wasted his life, and he does something about it.    i'm really surprised oprah liked this book.  don't let that fool you.  this book is like a punch to the face.  there's nothing fake about it.  some people are saying this book is whiny like that horrible book \\"a heartbreaking work of staggering genius\\" or something.  WRONG.  it's nothing like that.  james frey is so cool, he's practically a superhero.  he's a real man, not a wimp.  also i'd like to point out that if you think james is a jerk, you should read what OTHER addicts are like!  what, you think they're pleasant people to be around??  they're ALL jerks!  these are people who abandon their friends and family and use them, all for their own selfish addiction.  alcoholics and drug addicts ALL put their families and children through hell.  they are not nice, friendly people.  anyway, great book... i didn't want it to end.  and when it does, there's something shocking at the end, so be sure to read it all.   an incredibly genuine and honest look at the horrors of drug addiction.      EDIT - this review is pretty funny after the oprah show, huh?  :P  oh well, that me and many others thought frey was genuine does highlight his writing talent :D

B00005JOGU|5.0|\\"Until one morning in mid-November of 1959, few Americans - in fact, few Kansans - had ever heard of Holcomb. Like the waters of a river, like the motorists on the highway, and like the yellow trains streaking down the Santa Fe tracks, drama, in the shape of exceptional happenings, had never stopped there.\\" (from In Cold Blood)    Truman Capote invented the \\"non-fiction novel\\" with words like those.  The small town in Kansas would gain national fame when two vagabond criminals murdered a Rockwellian family of four, blasting shotgun pellets into their faces at close range and splattering blood onto perfectly made beds and floors that seemed to be washed daily.  The film \\"Capote\\" tells of the writer's immediate fascination with the consequences of such an act on a conservative buttoned-down town and his eventual relationship with the killers who stole Kansas' innocence.        Phillip Seymour Hoffman plays the enigmatic writer and the pursuit that would haunt the rest of his days.  Those unfamiliar with the writer will get a crash course in who he was, his homosexuality, his drinking, his odd presentation and speaking.  But more importantly, all viewers will see how the killings in Kansas and their consequences would virtually end his writing career, as \\"In Cold Blood\\" was the only book he published in the last two decades of his life.      In the film, Capote connects with the killers, as he sees the world divided into two categories: those like the church-going, milk drinking, \\"yes ma'am\\" saying murder victims and the rest of the world, the outsiders.  He and the killers belong to the latter group, and only a fine line exists between them.  \\"It's as if we were bothers, and one day he went out the back door while I went out the front,\\" Capote says of Perry Smith, the man who slit the throat of the family patriarch.    Just as Capote faced ridicule and judgment all his life because of his eccentricity, so did the killers.   Thus, a bond.      His initial quest for a story leads him on a conflicting journey, as he is torn between his duties as a literary journalist and the love he develops for his new \\"brothers\\".   As his relationship with Smith deepens, Capote wishes to fully understand the murderer and include his humanity in the book, so that the world won't forever think of him as a monster.    But the more he tries to whitewash through understanding, the bloodier his friend's hands become.      Capote does not want the men to die, and the film certainly has anti-death penalty aspirations.  But it does not develop them irresponsibly.  The killers are not romanticized (a la Monster) and the people who support that act are not sadistic fire-breathers (Dead Man Walking).  The death penalty is shown for what it is: a brutal act brought about by the actions of horrible people.        Hollywood is in the middle of a Renaissance with biographies and \\"Capote\\" shows them all how less is more.  So many films try to reduce a person's life to a few hours, an impossible task.  \\"Capote\\" instead trusts the audience to grasp the totality of the man by focusing on the most important episode in his life.  Audiences will come away from this film knowing as much about the essence of Truman Capote as is learned about Howard Hughes, Ray Charles or Johnny Cash in recent films of their lives.  But unlike the other three, \\"Capote\\" does not suffer from a disjointed, meandering narrative.  The focus instead is on one event, and the result is a biopic against which all others should be measured.

B000BMSTMS|1.0|The title of this review says it all.  A number of reviewers are certainly very excited by this \\"new sound\\".  Little do they mention or even realised that The Matrix helped to co-produce the album.  If you read the interviews, Korn was glad to have the extra musicans (from The Matrix of course) to produce the album.  Don't get me wrong.  The Matrix is talented.  They have done well in Avril's first album.  And did relatively fine with Liz Phair's previous album.  But commercial pop arena is where they should stay. <br /> <br />To me, Korn is about the sound of rawness - the guitar tracks from the left and right channel (now one guitarist is gone), the distorted bass, the vocal at times with effects, and the refreshing drumming.  And it is the consistency of such a wonderful combination from first to the last track of the album that thrills me. <br /> <br />I love to listen to Korn's music with my eyes closed and totally absorbed into the wonderful riff.  In this album, it is very disconnected.  There are differences in every song and of course it may be appeal to some.  But to me, that is a set back.  Somehow, electric sound and Korn just doesn't mix.  And in this album, the beautiful memorable riff is just not there.  Even the bass line that I come to love so much about Korn is not there anymore. <br /> <br />So, I have concluded that the guitarist who has left Korn was indeed the soul of Korn.  All the Korn characteristics are now gone (of course you can always look at it as a \\"new sound\\").  The most irritating and disappointing thing about this new album is that the energy level is just not there anymore.  Yes, the album can be loud at times but the energy level of the song is not there.  Even the melody of the song is not inspiring anymore.  My take is try sample the songs first and decide for yourself if you really want to get that.  I am a hardcore Korn fan and I am not going to buy this album.  If you manage to like this new Korn (they really should rename the band), I am happy for you.
B000BMSTMS|5.0|Last year, KoRn released their \\"Greatest Hits\\" so they could end their contract with Sony. Then, their very influential guitarist, Brian \\"Head\\" Welch, left the band as he became a born again Christian. Throughout the last year, he has not really said too much that is positive about KoRn, and has been an overall jerk about the whole thing. However, KoRn is moving on without Head. They just released their 7th album, \\"See You On the Other Side.\\"<br /><br />  Over the years, the biggest criticism that KoRn has received that almost all of their albums sound, essentially, the same. Their last album, \\"Take a Look in the Mirror,\\" although my personal favorite, had a lukewarm response. One half enjoyed the return to the sound of their first album. The other felt that the band had ran its course on this very sound.<br /><br />  So, KoRn has responded with a new direction with \\"See You On the Other Side.\\" Rather than completely abandoning their sound and alienating the fans, they have taken the KoRn sound, and stretched it to its fullest potential. For me, it was quite jarring and an adjustment at the first listen. However, in the end, I am very glad KoRn went in this direction.<br /><br />1. Twisted Transistor (10/10) - Their first single off of the album has been a smash hit for KoRn. I have no other way of describing it as \\"KoRn meets Talking Heads.\\" It definitely has that 80s Alternative/Punk/Techno feel to it. Twisted Transistor is a very catchy track with some rather ironic lyrics. The song is about the moment we all have with the radio. We are upset about something, and then we turn on the radio. That song just happened to fit your situation and defines you for that very moment.<br /><br />2. Politics (11/10) - Wow! This particular track sort of takes your classic \\"Here to Stay\\" or \\"Counting On Me\\"-type KoRn song and adds a \\"richer\\" sound to it, as one of my co-workers had described. I keep on trying to be descriptive as I can on this song, but I end up sounding really stupid. So, I will just let the 11 speak for itself.<br /><br />3. Hypocrites (10/10) - This uses what KoRn hasn't used since Follow the Leader....HIP HOP ELEMENTS. Jon semi-raps through the chorus, \\"Pay the merry man, pay the f----- driver. Pay the preachers and pay the f------ liars.\\" It is a great song that is already getting played live.<br /><br />4. Souvenir (9/10) - This is one of the more powerful tracks on the CD, especially relating to the lyrics.<br /><br />5. 10 or a 2-Way (8/10) - This is KoRn's attempt at a \\"Sexy Tongue-In-Cheek Song\\" so to speak. It is a good song, but I find the song more categorized \\"Dark Humor rather than \\"Tongue-In-Cheek.\\".All of it is evident in the lyric, \\"I'm only f------- you till the season change \\"<br /><br />6. Throw Me Away (7/10) - I may have been soured on this song because it was on an EP that was released earlier, and I was very thrown off by the whole thing. However, I have given it a second chance and it is a decent song. However, it seems like one of the filler tracks off of Untouchables or Issues.<br /><br />7. Love Song (11/10) - This song has a very epic feel to it and I feel like I have walked into the Church of Metal when I listen to this track.<br /><br />8. Open Up (10/10) - I swear in the middle, JD is either humming or something weird going on there. Whatever it is, I dig it.<br /><br />9. Coming Undone (9/10) - I like this song, but it just falls short of totally awesome, and I am not sure why.<br /><br />10. Getting Off (8/10) - This one seems a bit repetitive after \\"Coming Undone.\\" The chorus for Coming Done frequently used the phrase, \\"I'm Coming Undone.\\" Then, this song's chorus is \\"I'm Getting Off.\\" However, if you single this track out without listening to the first nine tracks, it is worthy of an eight out of ten!<br /><br />11. Liar (9/10) - Can you say \\"JD's Scat AND Bagpipes?\\" I thought you could! Good stuff!<br /><br />12. For No One (10/10) - This has a very nice beat to it.<br /><br />13. I'veSeen It All (9/10) - It is a good song.<br /><br />14. Tearjerker (Saturated Lonliness) (11/10) - Wow...in the end, that is all anybody has to say about Tearjerker. It is also pretty monotonous from where I stand.<br /><br />In the end, you are going to see either people love or hate this album. B0000027RL|5.0|I was 25 when 10 came out. I wasn't a grunge fan but I knew great music and lyrics when I heard them. I'm 40 now and I still know great music and I still consider 10 to be one of the top 5 greatest, defining albums of all time! I hate to be repetative but \\"Black\\" is probably the greatest \\"somebody done somebody wron song\\" ever written...period! Anyone who has ever loved and lost and then searched vain to somehow articulate the torrential fallout of grief and pain that always comes from saying goodbye, need look no further than the lyrics from Black to speak for them. It reaches into your soul and gives the reasurrance that you are not alone, that everbody hurts and that knowledge helps you make it through.  <br /> <br />And as for Eddy Vedder, not only does he have a voice that transcends age or gender (my 5 year old son loves evenflow and my 2 year old daugter falls into peacfull sleep whenever \\"Release\\" is playing) but he gives voice to emotion drawing creativity from his own painful past and spinning it into sonic \\"Nirvana\\". <br /> <br />Buy \\"10\\" pop it into your cd player and soon names like Cobain and Nirvana will be but distant memories lost in the anals of mediocre music.
B000BMSTMS|4.0|First things first: the Korn you knew in Jr. high is gone. They were already coming dangerously close to committing artistic suicide with \\"Take a Look in the Mirror\\", which was lukewarm and derivitive and tried way too hard. My feelings towards that album have softened a bit over the years, but I still couldn't help thinking that maybe Korn were done for.<br /><br />Well, in a way, they were. \\"Mirror\\" was the old Korn's death cry, and when Brian Welch left the band, the final nail was hammered into the coffin. However a lineup change and a label change seem to have conspired to create something that is, if nothing else, creative and new.<br /><br />The album kicks off with the propulsive, but melodically challanged, \\"Twisted Transistor.\\" While deffinitly not my favorite song on this album, it is representative of the changes to Korn's sound. At first listen, this album reminded me of Orgy. Indeed it borrows heavily from the softcore industrial sounds of Nine Inch Nails, Orgy, Static-X, et al, as well from one of their stated influences, Ministry. Even when there are no electronics in the mix, the aggressive pulse in most of these songs still bring to mind industrial music.<br /><br />The band also seems to have discarded the impressionistic chords and rich wall-of-sound textures in favor of a more horizontal approach. No doubt this is a result of Head leaving the band - without another guitarist to bounce ideas off of, James Shaffer's guitar parts reflect a thrashier sensability. The low-tuned guitars in many cases have lost their bass-y deffinition and now act as an abrasive noise texture. Fieldy's bass lines no longer seem to double as percussion parts and he is more taken to using the fuzz pedal.<br /><br />...and \\"evolution of heavy\\" indeed. Whatever that means, it seems to be a coordinated marketing gimmick of some kind - in addition to the amazon review for this album, that transparent phrase can be found on a sticker on the cellophane package of the cd itself as well. Don't be fooled into thinking this is some kind of blistering death rock record... it's just about the least-heavy thing Korn has put out. But, that's not necessarily a bad thing. I think Jonathan Davis has burned out the tempertantrums that fueled his mysogenistic rage on earlier albums, and any attempt to recapture that kind of sound would come off as forced and cheesey.<br /><br />Starting with the disappointing but still listenable \\"Twisted Transistor,\\" the album steadily gets better every song. \\"Hypocrites\\" is a relatively more traditional heavy/aggressive song with a southern-fried guitar riff a bit remiscent of Pantera or Down. \\"Souvenier\\" is interesting mostly because it sees Korn experimenting with time changes, something that has almost never factored into Korn's pop-oriented song structures.<br /><br />Then we come to what I consider to be the first real highlight of the album - \\"10 or a 2-way.\\" It begins as a raunchy Marilyn Manson-esque cabaret rocker... but then the chorus rolls around and knocks your head off with unanticipated heavyness. It's all the more effect because the album as a whole isn't that heavy; so when it's heavy, it really stands out.<br /><br />Another highlight (and this album sees more and more of them as it goes on) is the meloncholy \\"Throw Me Away\\" which reminds me of the Untouchables record with its wealth of sentimental ballad stand-ins. And that's a good thing. Other highlights include the funky, tuneful \\"Open Up,\\" a Static-X-esque sing-along called \\"Liars,\\" and in my opinion the crowning achievement of this album, \\"Seen It All.\\" The last track mentioned is a supremely creepy and dramatic song that reminds me of Angel Dust-era Faith No More. It is more than worthy of Korn's closing track.<br /><br />Unfortunately, it isn't the closing track. The actual closing track is a quiet, haunting sort of psuedo-ballad called \\"Tearjerker.\\" The dumb title belies its subtleties, but even then its more of an afterthought to \\"Seen It All\\" which is the kind of last impression Korn SHOULD be trying to make.<br /><br />Most of the other songs are pretty good, although a few of them like \\"Politics\\" and \\"Getting Off\\" get a little boring after awhile. There are no appallingly horrible tracks (which is more than can be said about Take a Look in the Mirror) and the highlights are in abundance.<br /><br />Unfortunately for those who were looking for a nostalgia fix to remind them of their jr. high days, Korn have given up trying to rip themselves off. But luckily for those who are ready to move on, 'Other Side' shows that Korn still know how to make NEW music. This album is as creative and different as anything this band has ever done. Korn may never put out another Issues or self-titled or Follow the Leader, but by continuing to develop and change, they have avoided going down with the nu metal ship they themselves helped build. We may still yet hear creative new music from the Korn camp before their time is up.thought to \\"Seen It All\\" which is the kind of last impression Korn SHOULD be trying to make. <br /> <br />Most of the other songs are pretty good, although a few of them like \\"Politics\\" and \\"Getting Off\\" get a little boring after awhile. There are no appallingly horrible tracks (which is more than can be said about Take a Look in the Mirror) and the highlights are in abundance.  <br /> <br />Unfortunately for those who were looking for a nostalgia fix to remind them of their jr. high days, Korn have given up trying to rip themselves off. But luckily for those who are ready to move on, 'Other Side' shows that Korn still know how to make NEW music. This album is as creative and different as anything this band has ever done. Korn may never put out another Issues or self-titled or Follow the Leader, but by continuing to develop and change, they have avoided going down with the nu metal ship they themselves helped build. We may still yet hear creative new music from the Korn camp before their time is up.
0553801503|5.0|Okay....we all know what's missing.  That being said, this book is still a part of the best series ever written in modern fantasy, and any comparisons to Jordan are ridiculous.  Martin serves up his story with such artistry, and every detail matters.  If you don't see that, you either neglected to read the other three books, or you are in junior high school (or reading at a junior high level).      Jordan's books, of which I have read five, are full of useless details and annoying character traits (e.g. the braid pulling).  How many times can you give the \\"Dragon Reborn\\" a \\"whithering look\\" and it have the same effect?  Most of Jordans details, while painting a very colorful world, do nothing for the story, and some are just downright annoying.  Martin hides morsels of importance and intrigue in every sentence.  Is the Hound really dead...read carefully...is Pate, like the pig boy, really Pate at the end...read carefully...There is so much foreshadowing, symbolism, and intelligence built into this story, you could literally teach a semester long college course on each book...including Feast.    Usually I read books to get to the end, but with ASOIAF, I read every page slowly, hungrily, and with an anticipation I've never known before.  I can't wait for the story to continue either, but to downgrade this work of art because the story is not yet complete is a very childish and rash thing to do.  Anyone with an ounce of adult intelligence will see what I mean.  Hooray for Feast!  Bring on the Dragons!!!
B000BMSTMS|4.0|Like many Korn fans, I have much to say about this new album. But before I do, I would like to start with a brief history of the relationship between the fans and Korn. In Korn's first two albums (Korn, Life Is Peachy), they had managed to create a strong underground fan base that would eat, drink, breathe, and bleed Korn. However, with the release of Follow The Leader, there seemed to be some controversy brewing. Some fans blamed them for going soft, (completely unwarranted) but more importantly, the main stream attention Korn started receiving (i.e. MTV) made many of the underground fans nervous. With this new found success, many of the underground fans started drowning in the influx of newbies, and almost two minutes later, Korn released their fourth album Issues. With so much hype built up behind it in such a short period of time, there was no place to hide for those endangered underground fans. Many would perish under the enormous weight of popularity.<br /><br />Issues proved to be the first in a series of major changes in Korn's sound. With Jonathan Davis' emphasis on singing more than screaming the allegations of them going soft weren't so far fetched this time. The next two albums came after a slight cooling period in the world of Korn fans, and after Untouchables and Take A Look In The Mirror (Korn's unsuccessful attempt at redemption), it seemed as though there was a definate lull in the band's success.<br /><br />Don't be fooled into this doomsday scenario however, because when the going gets tough, the tough get reckless. In this unprecedented turn of events (also known as their seventh album, See You On The Other Side), Korn have opted to take out much of the raw energy and pounding guitars, and replace it with a more industrial, almost electronic feel. One can only speculate as to why the now four members of Korn decided to go this rout. Perhaps an attempt to jump start their sagging record sales? Could it have something to do with the absence of their second guitarist, Brian \\"Head\\" Welch? Maybe the Nine Inch Nails influenced production team played a part. Whatever the case may be, the fact of the matter is that those same fans who claimed Korn went soft with Follow The Leader and Issues are probably dying a thousand deaths with his one. However controversial, you must give credit where credit is due. Korn would be fooling themselves if they thought they were going to please all their fans with this album. Instead, they decided to go in the opposite direction and seemingly please themselves rather than the majority of their fans. This album seems to be the answer to all the fans turned haters. It seems to be saying, you think we went soft before? Try this one on for size!<br /><br />Now when you listen to See You On The Other Side it may be beneficial to put aside the last 10 years and focus on the present. If you're able to do that I think you will find a rather interesting and diverse album. The only problem with this industrial feel is that they seem to be treading a little too close to Nine Inch Nails terretory. If fans wanted an industrial album, they'd be better off just buying  a Nine Inch Nails album. There are some touches however that are definitive Korn; child oriented cover art, the use of \\"scat\\", and Davis' bagpipe playing interludes. The first few songs sound most like the Korn of old, with \\"Hypocrites\\" shining through as the head banging hit of the bunch. The most melodic and industrial laced songs come toward the middle of the album, with songs like \\"Throw Me Away\\" and \\"Open Up.\\" The oddest and most confused sounding song is \\"Love Song,\\" which has riffs reflecting a minor key, with a major key harmony slapped on top for the chorus. \\"Liar\\" and \\"For No One\\" bring us back down to earth again with heavy riffs and singing which reflects the days of Issues. The last song on this album is titled \\"Tearjerker,\\" but it is not the sort of tear-jerking closing track we have come accustomed to with the firsttwo albums. It is a slow and lamenting song with high pitched singing that almost sounds unnatural coming from someone capable of such monstrous growls.<br /><br />With as much as this band has gone through, to say that they will suffer from such a dramatic change is completely untrue. The members of Korn are a resilient bunch, and even through losing half of their guitar force they've managed to evolve, no, mutate into an interestingly diverse sounding band. Granted, this new industrial edge may be hard for some fans to swallow, but keep in mind that Korn can never be the same band they were in 1994, and I don't think we would want them to be.w and lamenting song with high pitched singing that almost sounds unnatural coming from someone capable of such monstrous growls.    With as much as this band has gone through, to say that they will suffer from such a dramatic change is completely untrue. The members of Korn are a resilient bunch, and even through losing half of their guitar force they've managed to evolve, no, mutate into an interestingly diverse sounding band. Granted, this new industrial edge may be hard for some fans to swallow, but keep in mind that Korn can never be the same band they were in 1994, and I don't think we would want them to be.

0553801503|2.0|I am a huge fan of the previous three novels in this series.  Unlike many books that I have read, the Song of Ice and Fire novels have developed the characters and showed how those personalities interract to create a challenging life for these characters.  The Feast for Crows continues this difficult writing feat, but the story has moved in a disappointing direction from what I had been looking forward to for years.    The narrative that I have been reading and anticipating is a story about the Stark family's rivalry with the Lannister family which leads to them losing everything, and (presumably) reagaining it slowly over the course of the writings.  This occurs under a backdrop of the rebirth of dragons and potential invasion of \\"the others\\".  Both of which should take priority over petty inter-family squabbles, but (of course) does not.    This novel veered off in a completely different direction -- the Starks, the dragons, and the wights were barely mentioned.  The Feast for Crows is primarily a novel of the mostly failed attempts of the Ironborn and Dornishmen to conquor the kingdom, Cersei Lannister's descent into paranoia, Jaime Lannister's (failed) attempts to gain respect, and Brienne's failed attempts to find the Stark children.    This novel is filled with much that has made Martin a great writer.  His characters are three dimensional, and he can build tension when leading up to relatively mild events.  For instance, when Brienne is leading a small group to an abandoned ruin, she hopes to find a lead to one of the Stark children.  Instead, she uncovers outlaws and a swordfight.  The detail in the writing is exceptional, but -- so what.    In the prior novels, Martin would have had a bird or a spy inform of us the intrigue at Dorne or Pike.  In doing so, he accomplished the plot complexity with a simple paragraph. In Feast for Crows, we are subjected to major development of minor story lines at the expense of the more significant characters.  Martin apologizes for the lack of many of these characters in a letter at the end.  He would have been better served to eliminate Pike, eliminate Dorne, and reduce the Brienne POV (which is ultimately unsatisfying) -- thereby giving space to add the Jon Snow, Tyrion Lannister, Daenerys, and Bran Stark story development.    Of note in this story is the development of the oldest Stark daugter, Sansa.  In her short, four chapters, she grows from an idealistic, shallow youth to a politically astute, hardened young lady.  When her mentor bargains for a year to prove his worth, she shrewdly realizes that his adversaries will be eliminated in that year.  It is telling that George R.R. Martin can accomplish this development in four chapters when Brienne takes three times that much to accomplish less.    In summary, whle the Cersei, Sansa, and Jaime POV chapters are fascinating, and the entire novel is vividly written, the book is frustratingly empty.  Most of the plot lines develop into failures, and many plot lines and characters from the previous novels are ignored.
055380457X|5.0|This is a very well-written and scrupulously well-researched account of the Google phenomenon.  A great story of how two incredibly bright guys with a great deal of perseverance changed the world.  It's filled with anecdotes and analysis that keep the reader intrigued from start to finish.  Before reading this book, I never really understood how Google made money. I do now.  Would recommend it to anyone looking for a great read for themselves, or a great gift for a friend.  5 stars!

1844137864|5.0|Think art has lost its edge?  Witness the art of England's Banksy and reconsider.     His message: that if the powerful and wealthy get to force-feed consumerist propaganda to citizens via giant billboards... then citizens have the right to reply in kind.  To that end he's trekked around the world throwing up politically pointed, often funny, always eye-popping street art wherever he damn well pleases: On sidewalks, on train trestles, on the West Bank wall between Israel and Palestine, in monkey cages at the zoo, in the world's great museums (unbeknownst to the curators, of course), and on farm animals (yes, ON them).      \\"Wall and Piece\\" is a \\"best of\\" overview of Banksy's career, and impresses on a lot of levels.  There's the skill and variety of Banksy's techniques (stencils, illustrations, paintings, screenprints and sculptures are all on display).  There's the caustic wit of his writing (expressed here in almost epigrammatic blurbs about art and politics).  And there's his genius as a prankster.  Example: Not content merely to graffitti a blank wall in Westminster, Banksy instead throws up an official-looking \\"This Wall Is A Designated Graffitti Area\\" stencil (complete with a \\"royal\\" crest swiped off a pack of cigarettes)... and watches others do the work for him.      For those yearning for art that's active... that excites and inspires instead of merely placating... this is the book of the year.  One warning: it sits on your coffee table like a social land mine.  Guests come over, crack it open, and it obliterates conversation for a while as they get sucked in.  Completely Addictive.  Highly recommended.

B000B7BRMM|4.0|Diana Krall is a fantastic talent, but this is not her best effort. Certain Christmas albums, like Harry Connick Jr.'s When My Heart Finds Christmas, are instant classics. You can tell the first time you hear them that they will be around for a long time. Others, like Garth Brooks' Beyond the Season simply blend into the background of Christmas music. Twelve years later Harry Connick is still getting regular play in many CD players while Garth sits on the shelf (I realize these are two very different genres, but it still illustrates my point for those who listen to more than one genre...)<br /><br />As much as I love Diana, this album is destined to be like the latter. That doesn't mean this is a bad CD, as it's not. It's still very enjoyable. The Christmas Song is worth the price of admission alone. Oddly the pieces that stand out are the simple arrangements without the orchestra. The iTunes (album only, unfortunately) exclusive Jingle Bells outshines the track included here.<br /><br />If you are a jazz fan, this CD belongs in your collection. B000BM6AVA|2.0|I would have preferred to give the album 2.5 stars, but it's no option here at amazon.com, and I chose 2 to balance the over-enthusiastic reviews. I am a SOAD fan, and anyone who spends time listening to music cannot possibly agree with the multitude of 5-star ratings found here. <br /> <br />System of a Down's latest album Hypnotize reflects an awkward stage in the bands development. Guitarist and singer Daron Malakian's expanded role contrasts sharply with the band's lead vocalist, Serj Tankian, whose style hasn't noticeably changed since System's first release in 1998. As a result of the differences in the two songwriters, Hypnotize is a very dissonant album, and the tension between Daron and Serj is distracting. <br /> <br />The first half of the album is consistent in theme and musically mediocre. While the underlying message is an important one, calling for social justice in a manner that recalls Rage Against the Machine, the lyrics are unpolished and repetitive. The best parts of the first seven songs are the rare, quiet interludes that fall between Serj's edgy screams. There are a few instances of Daron trying to escape the traditional System sound with new guitar styles and even a run of pop in the fifth track, \\"Stealing Society,\\" but overall his playing shows neither innovation nor improvement over previous albums. The first half of the album culminates in \\" Holy Mountains,\\" the eighth track and one of the few in which the two prominent band members are able to work together and combine their talents. \\"Holy Mountains\\" is also the album's longest track, playing out at five minutes and twenty-eight seconds. <br /> <br />The second half of Hypnotize is pointedly different from the first, and begins with track nine, \\"Vicinity of Obscenity.\\" After listening to the song, it came as no surprise to find that Serj wrote all of the lyrics. This track oozes Serj, but the only sign of musical development comes in the form of a funky chorus via Daron. The second half of the album loses focus, as is evident of \\"Vicinity of Obscenity\\" and the following two tracks, both written completely by Daron. In \\"She's Like Heroin,\\" Daron falls back on his familiar theme of drug abuse, and the song feels simply out of place. \\"Lonely Day\\" is a good tune, but there is nothing fresh to it, and the lyrics are disappointingly thin. The last track of the album, \\"Soldier Side,\\" is one of the best, and does a fine job of concluding the Mesmerize/Hypnotize set. <br /> <br />Overall, System's latest is repetitive and only provides a few too-short moments of musical excellence. The lyrical content is well chosen (if not familiar to System fans), but the music itself is less than spectacular. When the album is over a short thirty-nine minutes and forty-eight seconds after it has begun, one is left with a lukewarm opinion of the band's creative capability.

0440241588|4.0|In \\"The Broker,\\" John Grisham combines all of his customary ingredients for success -- high-powered lawyers, politics, escapism -- with a couple of new elements: espionage, international intrigue, travel, and food. The resulting concoction is not as taut as Grisham's earlier courtroom dramas, but it's pleasing nonetheless. <br /> <br />Much of the novel takes place in Italy, a place that Grisham loves and knows well. The narrative at times morphs into a travelogue and at others into language lessons. Since the book made me want to visit Italy and learn the language, I'd say Grisham's writing experiment is quite effective. <br /> <br />The pace of \\"The Broker\\" is much slower than most of Grisham's previous novels, perhaps deliberately reflecting the slower pace of Italian cities. Things don't start to escalate until the final hundred pages or so. The story of the main character outwitting highly trained spies and assassins is a little far-fetched, but still enjoyable. Grisham's finest literary sleight-of-hand is the fact that he is able to turn a main character with a despicable past into a likeable and sympathetic character. <br /> <br />My only gripe is that the book is in need of editing. Some episodes drag on too long, some words are overused (porticoes), and minor characters come and go for no apparent reason. This is what editors are for, and so many major authors (Grisham, King, Rowling) unfortunately think they are immune.
0517123207|5.0|I had an appendix embedded in my body, but it served no useful purpose, became inflamed, and was removed.  This book, along with those by Richard Dawkins (Blind Watchmaker), Ernst Mayr (What Evolution Is), Steven Stanley (Macroevolution: Pattern and Process), Stephen J. Gould (The Structure of Evolutionary Theory), and Geerat Vermeij (Evolution and Escalation) help explain why and how I happened to come by this \\"feature\\".  Once you've finished those, Weishampel's \\"Dinosauria\\" is quite a bit of fun, too, as is Harper's Numerical Palaeobiology.  If you prefer shells to bones, Boardman's \\"Fossil Invertebrates\\" is a great read.  If you'd rather do it on the cheap, Google Scholar \\"evolution\\".  Of the 3.2 million hits, I would guess at least a third pertain to biotic evolution.

0884271536|5.0|This book is actually fiction, although it intended to be used as a instructional manual for implementing a new approach to project management.  As a project manager I think the book is very practical and I think his approach would work very well for many projects.  However, the theory that Goldratt proposes goes against all of the other commonly used project management tools (Gantt, Critical Path, PERT) that are based on timelines and milestones.   <br /> <br />The book is written from a common-sense approach (in contrast to the approach used by textbooks) and some of the problems it addresses are: <br />1. Projects often run over budget but rarely finish under budget <br />2. Multitasking is actually detrimental to projects  <br />3. Constraints arrise when multiple projects use the same resources <br />4. The true cost of a project (which Goldratt says is much higher than most think) <br />5. Negotiations with subcontractors used on a project <br />6. Net Present Value and payback period are inadequate measurements for the cost of a project <br /> <br />Don't be discouraged if you don't understand any of the typical project management jargon.  Goldratt does a great job of introducing each concept and describing the basic, underlying concepts.  The technical concepts are explained in question-answer form that would be similar to attending a seminar.   <br /> <br />Lastly, Goldratt uses two types of projects (product development and construction) as examples in this book.  However, the concepts and his approach could be applicable to many different types of projects.  In my opinion, the determining factor for applicability of Goldratt's approach is the structure of the organization and not the type of project;  the less burocratic, the more applicable.
0375703764|5.0|This book is wonderful. It is written as if it was an art film. It draws you in and forces you to experience what the characters are experiencing. Very enthralling.
B000001E18|4.0|First and foremost, do not start listening to U2 with this album.  It's such a shock to listen to this album after hearing their most played work.  Definitely listen to Achtung Baby before you listen to this album.  It'll make more sense. <br />Beyond the disclamer, Zooropa is a very intriguing album.  Much more mellow than Achtung Baby and almost as mellow as Joshua Tree, Zooropa captures a balance and a forward push at the same time.  The sonic collages that permeate this album are at times gorgeous, at times disquieting.  The title track opens with a sonic mish-mash, and then when Edge's guitar enters, the mood of the song and the rest of the album is set: atmospheric and mellow.  The title track is almost progressive rock with it having three parts: the subtle cacophonic opener, the moody middle, and the anthemic closer.  With the line \\"Uncertainty could be the guiding light,\\" U2 prepares everyone for the soundscapes to follow.  \\"Babyface\\" is a good song, but not the one that should have followed the title track.  It's mellow to a fault.  \\"Numb\\" would have been the perfect second track, sounding unlike any U2 song that had come before it, and still unique to this day.  The Edge carries a monotone drone while his guitar is processed to death.  With Larry Mullen and Bono carrying the haunting backing vocals, this song is an unusual U2 classic.  \\"Lemon\\" is my favorite track on the album.  Even though it hints at the focus of the next album Pop, this track is much more fun and even more intriguing than anything off that album.  A German disco-laden song, \\"Lemon\\" screams irony, and Brian Eno jumps in with the band for vocals.  If anything proves that Eno is a legendary producer, it's \\"Lemon.\\"  Following that is the best track on the album: \\"Stay (Faraway, So Close!).\\"  A blatant love song influenced by Wim Wenders's movies Wings of Desire and Faraway, So Close, Bono sings about love in the Generation X, and the lyrics couldn't be any better.  The rest of the album doesn't reach the heights of the first half, but the two closing songs, \\"Dirty Day\\" and \\"The Wanderer\\" with Johnny Cash, end the album on a high note.  U2 would make their biggest blunder with Pop, but Zooropa, sandwiched between the classic Achtung Baby and the blunder Pop, is one of U2's lost gems.  It may not be their best, but it can definitely be classified as a diamond in the rough.  A recommended listen.
B000002O51|4.0|It's hard to believe that Third Stage came out almost 20 years ago. I remember listening to it on cassette in my ugly red Horizon going to high school. It took Tom about 8 years to finish this album after 1978's Don't Look Back. But it still went to #1 thanks to the single Amanda (which also went to #1). The other singles were We're Ready and Can'tcha Say, both of which charted well too. Third Stage has the trademark soaring harmonized guitar lines that Boston became known for and Brad Delp's vocals are as powerful as ever. There is not really any song on this album that I dislike so I can always listen to it from start to finish. My favorite songs are The Launch, I Think I Like It, and Hollyann. The reason I give it 4 stars is because there are not as many standout tracks as on the first album. Also, the production is a bit too grand on some of the songs. But Third Stage is a good album despite some of the criticism heaped on it.
